Service is usually fast, despite the somewhat small and packed establishment.  There's usually an available table in minutes which you cannot say true for places like either Monta location.   Definitely order the Fukumimi if you hadn't had the chance to.  Being a stickler for good ramen, and having had some of the best that California and New York have to offer, I think Las Vegas's Fukumimi ramen can hang with the best of them.

Yelp 100 Challenge 2016 - 7/100

We're ramen maniacs... So if course first thing we did when we drive into town was get Ramen. We got there after 7:30 pm on a Saturday and there was no wait which was music to our ears  after an 8hr drive!


Broth was very flavorful while being relatively light, not thin but not super creamy. We had a fukumimi (pork base, extra chashu, shio I think) and a tori (chicken based). I liked how you could really taste the different flavors in the different  broths. I really enjoyed the broths! Noodles were good and the honey garlic chicken was nice, tender dark meat and it was good too. But, It was the ramen that was the star.
 
Why not 5 stars? Two things-  one, this is minor but although the fatty bits of chashu were delish, the lean bits were a bit... Tough and blah.

Two - I want to be able to drink the soup if it's really yummy... It was, so, We did, and we were super thirsty the rest of the night despite drinking water during and after dinner ( though in Vegas I guess being thirsty is easy to fix....)


Overall it was quite good and if I were local, i'd enjoy going back. Also, The loyalty card is hard to beat. After one visit we were one bowl or appetizer Away from a free appetizer next time!

Looking for very flavorful ramen, heres the place to go! Its full of flavor and the noodles are cooked to perfection! Have been here multiple times and every time it has been a great experience. All staff are friendly and constantly checking up on each table to make sure everyone is doing well and enjoying their experience. A must try!

I have to thank my cousin Steven for taking me here as this was some dang good ramen!  Trust me, I have eaten ramen from all over Japan and Hawaii has some real good ones too and this place is right there on top.  It was so good that I actually ate this delicious Tonkotsu pork broth three times in my one week stay in Las Vegas. 

On the Appetizer side: the Chicken Karage was recommended, and it came out piping hot.  I loved the crispness of fried skin, followed by the moist juicy tender chicken.  They also have Kim Chee which isn't your typical Korean style but one that is on the sweeter side. Their Edamame was ok.  Would of been better if they had some kind of sauce or maybe a garlic type. 

Over all this place rocks and next year I will be back for sure.

They brought my appetizer after the main meal not happy and i had questions about the menu and the server was very rude and walk away then i look over and the server was talking to her co-worker looking and pointing at us making so obvious there were talking about us not a place i well come back to.

I suggested this to a visiting friend who wanted something simple.  My suggestion was based on high yelp ratings on this place.  We ordered the Tonkatsu Ramen (miso) and the big Chasu Bowl.  I had high expectations and was terribly disappointed.  The Ramen was thick but it really did not have the miso taste.  The Chasu Bowl was tastier but nothing to rave about.  The place is located in a dark strip mall, and it looked like it was popular with students based on the diners already there and the young people waiting in line.  I made a wrong choice and would not be back.

I was done with some meetings and was ready for dinner.  I did a Yelp search and found Fukumimi Ramen pretty close to my hotel.  I got there around 5, it's a small place and I knew if I went there at 6pm I would have to wait for a table.  The service was great an the place was very clean.  I ordered the following:

Tonkotsu Ramen (Miso) $8.20: Small Portion, it came with corn, green onion, bean sprouts, egg and pork.  It was definitely very tasty.  I really liked it.

Kimchi Tofu ($4):  Now this was very yummy.  It's cold tofu, kimchi, onion, seaweed in an awesome sauce.  Ordering this dish was a nice introduction to this restaurant so I will definitely go back again.  

4 stars because of the really small bowls but it was still pretty tasty.

This is a small little ramen house with a simple menu. I go here often and the service is always good and it's cheap for what you get. They have a punch card for frequent goers and every 4th ramen is a free appetizer. I haven't tried anything in the menu that I haven't liked.

Since my first trip to Fukumimi Ramen over a year ago, I have been going a couple times a month for lunch.  The food continues to be wonderful, and the service is always prompt.  It's a great place to eat when you're right on time for lunch - they can get you in and out pretty fast.  Love this place!

This place is the best. The pork is perfectly cooked, the soup is light but filling with awesome flavor and the costumer service is great.  They are so welcoming and feels like family.  I go there every Friday with my fianc.  The should open one in Henderson :)

We were at this place this afternoon, food was good but service was on the down side. A very unwelcoming vibes from one of the servers, very unpleasant, she needs to learn what a Quality Customer Service means. As soon as we were done, I couldn't wait to get out of this place. Definitely not coming back.
Really good ramen--not the best one I've had but quite good. Try their special Fukumimi ramen.

I came here with high expectation because of Yelp and I gotta say, it was quite disappointing. The service was good. The server women were extremely nice and quick. 

Then came the food. I ordered the Kogashi Ramen ($8.20) which supposedly has good amount of garlic flavor or whatever because of my love for Monta's Kuro Ramen aka black garlic. The bowl was smaller than Monta's, good presentation. The flavor was nothing garlicky or full of aroma like I expected. It was good broth, very peppery, but not good enough. I didn't like the noodles. The SUPER weird thing that I HATED was the addition bean sprout, though it was my fault for not fully read the description. The broth flavor was completely overwhelmed by the bean sprout for me. Extremely tender and flavorful Chashu but the pieces were wayyyyyy to small, almost seemed like they disappeared into the noodles.

My friend got a Fukumimi Ramen ($9.50) and it was the most disappointing bowl of noodles. She got it because it said "extra Chashu" but turned out, she got way less meat than I did. Extra means more than 3 but she got exactly 3 pieces. Maybe they were way too small in size that they weren't significant enough. The broth was okay, nothing notable. To be honest she disliked it. I didn't think it was worth it for the price or the way they described it on the menu. We didn't want to compare this place to Monta, but even the people who were sitting behind us mentioned about Monta in their conversation so...

We also got Karaage Chicken which is Japanese fried chicken. It was supposed to be an appetizer but we got it AT THE END of the meal. I was annoyed. But I thought it was okay, but a little over-salted. They used dark meat that's very tender. Very good coating. The thing is, they had like a pile of overdressed salad with very liquidy dressing so it soaked the fried chicken pieces. The chickens were soggy after a while. I don't think the addition of salad was necessary because why???

Overall we just didn't enjoy the restaurant as much as how I anticipated it. I get why they have the stamp system or the "eat 4 ramens get a free appetizer" to attract customers but it just didn't work for me. Everything was missing a notch of goodness to get to that level. Monta is still in the lead by a huge margin. This place is still improving but I won't be around to see the improvements.
Staff are friendly and the best chicken karaage I have tasted so far.. Nice and crispy on the outside and juicy in the inside.. I would recommend this place to friends and family..

5 of us came here for lunch today during peak lunch hour. The parking lot was super easy to park in and we ran inside to put our name down on the list. They had signs saying that they won the ramen award in 2016 for Las Vegas. 

It would've made it easier if they took reservations, but given how popular they are, it makes sense that they don't need reservations. Our wait was about 15 minutes long and the waiters were very efficient at turning the tables around. I was even thinking that next time I might do take away because they were efficiently packing ramen to go, carefully packing the noodles and broth separately as to not mess up their masterpiece.

Once seated, the waitress took our drink orders, then lunch orders. They were quick, kind, and to the point. We ordered a chicken kaarage for the table, which I only took a bite of because I was saving room for the ramen. It was hot and tasty, but the batter was a little slimy in texture--interesting observation, I know! I ordered the Tori Ramen, which is made with chicken broth and has chicken chashu. I was starving and it was delicious! I did think it was a little too salty for my liking, and next time I'd likely add the spice bomb to give it more of a kick, but all in all, it was very good! I didn't even leave a drop--that's how hungry I was. The rest of the table ordered different types of ramen with different added toppings--everyone reall enjoyed their food but also thought it was on the salty side.

The food tasted good, customer service was great, and it was pretty cheap--$7.50 for the chicken ramen! Restaurant and restroom were also very clean. Will definitely be back--and can't forget to bring the stamp card! 4 ramen stamps = 1 free appetizer, and I'm looking forward to trying the gyoza next time! 

Tip: try to go in not peak food hours to get seated faster!

best broth, best noodles, best pork belly!!!
their ramen is better than monta
yes i said it

Yo, Vegas has a ramen joint. TELL EVERYONE.

My favorite being tan tan men, I ordered that and the kaarage (small bites of fried chicken). My friend ordered the Fukumimi ramen, which I believe is a pork-based broth.

The tan tan men was too creamy. Like, grainy creamy. The interaction of miso with the liquid broth was not there. In fact, I barely ate any of mine because of it. Soooo why give this place four stars?

Their Fukumimi ramen was awesome. It had an amazing flavor that I will most certainly order in the future. I'm having a hard time describing it, just, whatever, just go. Kaarage is good too, but I'd personally stick to the ramen.

So sayth our Lord and Savior, Flying Spaghetti Monster.

R-aaaamen.

This delightful ramen joint hidden in plain sight on Eastern and Trop offers some of the best ramen options you may be looking for. From their signature fukumimi ramen to their miso ramen, they have the right gourmet ingredients to hit the spot. And wait... there's more. Not only do they serve their slurp-worthy noodles but they also have flavorful appetizers at such an affordable price. My favorite would have to be the honey garlic karage, in other words, honey garlic chicken and agedashi tofu. I would get to explaining on those two insanely delicious appetizers, but you'd just have to try it for yourself !!
Great find. This place is legit. Love the texture of the noodles and perfectly cooked hard boiled egg. Nothing over $9.50 on the entire menu. Limited seating but worth the wait.
We can't seem to get enough when we're carving Ramen this our to go place. It's always fresh and delicious. The waitstaff is curteous and helpful all the time.
Super yummy. Excellent service. Nice couple beers. Small place, but highly recommend for a nice dinner. Would be 5 stars if they had dessert, but ice cream place next door.
My favorite ramen place in Las Vegas!  Hands down great service, kind people and the ramen is amazing!

A welcome addition to the ramen scene on the east side of town.  Located in an inconspicuous strip mall at the corner of Tropicana and Eastern, this is a true neighborhood ramen joint where one is always greeted enthusiastically at the door and local Japanese residents can always be spotted as regulars.  The decor is minimalist but modern and service is prompt and non-overbearing.  

Appetizers that stand out are the karaage (Japanese fried chicken) and the gyoza (pork/chicken pot stickers).  The chicken is served fresh out of the fryer with a nice crispy exterior and juicy interior with a hint of ginger accentuated with a squeeze of fresh lemon whereas the gyoza have a nice char and the dough skin and filling are light enough to leave room for the main course.  

After consuming 15+ bowls of ramen on multiple lunch break visits from work, the key words describing the soups here are consistency and balance.  Whereas I've had a few instances at Ramen Sora and Monta where the soups were either too salty or too bitter (black garlic oil was literally blackened garlic),  the broths here all have a creamy rich depth of flavor and are not overly cloying in the mouth so the resistance to reaching for additional spoonfuls of broth once the noodles are finished is quite low.  Noodles come in thick and thin varieties with decent texture although lacking any true inherent flavor only found at the top joints.  

The standout broth for me is one of the relative newcomers on the menu: the kogashi (or burnt miso) ramen.  I've waxed poetic before on the Mallard reaction in chemistry  applied to food in a previous review(nerd alert!) but here again is yet another example of the magical powers of applying heat to rearrange amino acids and simple sugars to create a new unique flavor.  By charring miso paste, not only is there an intense aroma given off by the broth upon arriving at your table, but the flavor profile retains the savory note of the fermented soybeans we all know and love in miso but also has additional complex notes with an almost caramelized sweetness and a hint of bitterness that is pleasing on the tongue.  The crispy fried onions topping the noodles further enhance the umami tsunami.   I wish I could comment on the tan-tan men (spicy Szechuan style broth), but alas my first experience was on a full stomach from a previous meal so I must defer one to read other fellow yelper's raves on this other unique offering.

For the most part, the choices here are safe and reliably consistent, much like dating the girl next door, but if you're in the mood for something a little more adventuresome and unpredictable, the krazy kogashi ramen or the spicy and fiery tan tan men are worthy "fuku-mi-mi" one night stands (had to do it,  the name of the joint is just begging for a little humorous acknowledgment!)  

P.S.  Don't forget to partake in their generous punch-card system where one is entitled to a free order of gyoza or karaage with every fourth bowl of ramen purchased!
I love this place ! Every time I go to this place there is always a await time, I don't mind waiting because it's so worth the wait !

The only reason that this location doesn't get 5 stars is because this place is too small. 

However, as far as food, service, etc... This place is excellent! Each dish was better than the last.

Will be going to this place on the regular. Just not during peak times.

Advice to management: Expand. He multiple locations or something. The food sure is good enough

My husband did not enjoy the spicy ramen. Maybe had three small pieces of pork. I thought the miso ramen was alright. We also had the chasu bowl. The pork was sweet and there was very little in the bowl. Won't be trying that again. 
Monta ramen it still Las Vegas's best ramen!
I tried the Tan Tan Men, The taste of the broth was mediocre, but I like their noodle texture. Not really special, but I don't mind to come again to try their other menus

Was back today, 
The staff and chef are nice and accommodating. 
Chicken Tori Ramen is best of all time.
Karaage is among the best of anywhere.

Best Ramen place in Vegas!!!!! 
Monta is #2

This a mammaluke free restaurant.
Really great food,but wish they're waitress would be a little nicer! They also limit you on the condiments as well, other than than it's good.

Ramen was 8/10. Good but not the best I've had. 

It took us about 45 minutes to get seated on a Tuesday.  Service was good, our waitress was friendly.

Ironically this place is so small but large groups come here to socialize, which can be annoying when you're hungry.

First thing first after landing in Vegas, right turn on Tropicana three blocks down, on the left. 

No fair LV has so many choices when it comes to authentic Japanese Ramen, this place rates by proximity and all the killer side dishes. 

Their real standout being Karaage chicken ... Fukumimi

The ramen is average, gyoza good, chicken ok, tofu--appetizer--mediocre. The restaurant though is dirty.  Our table was sticky and had oil on it (not in container).  The staff missed refills and do not know how to split checks.  The receipt was for all and I hope my card didn't pay for it all.  Really embarrassing, I hope they fix their pos systems.

My go to spot for ramen here in Vegas. I prefer this place over Monta. My usual is the Fukumimi Ramen with extra egg and corn. One this I like about this place is it doesn't get as crowded as Monta. Can get in and get out pretty quickly. Not to mention that the ramen is pretty damn good. Service is always on point.

Very small, cozy. Authentic vibe. I'm not a really big fan of ramen, but my friends wanted to go try this place out and I'm glad I did! The soup was really delicious. I had pork miso ramen and it was great. I guess I do like ramen, I just hadn't found the right place until fukumimi came into my life.

OMG, this place kicks major ass!    This could be one of the best Ramen, I had in a decade or two.      
Located on the northeast corner of Tropicana and Eastern, this little hole in the wall will shortly become the "IN" place for Japanese noodles in Las Vegas.    I tried Monta, Sora, and Amine, but in my opinion, Fukumimi take's the cake for broth, noodles, presentation, and service.
Fukumimi is a pretty small place around the size of Monta, but luckily there was a table when I pulled in around 7 pm.    The menu is small, but it's very straight forward, and I ordered the Fukumimi Tonkotsu Ramen and side of Kara-age chicken.    
The waitress was very pleasant, and wait time for my food about 10 minutes.     I was very surprised on the presentation, and the flavor of the broth.    It was so pretty, I almost didn't want to mix it. :)     The broth was nice and milky, and had a nice touch of the black garlic oil on top of it....the soup base was a home run!    The noodles were done right, and the boiled egg was flavored perfectly....I forgot about the pork belly slice, that was pretty killer! 
The Kara-age chicken was okay, and would order it again, but this place was all about the Ramen, and I'm sold  on it.    
Fukumimi does sale Japanese beer, and even have a frequent buyers card for returning customers....WHICH I WILL BE ONE!   
Sorry, Monta, but this place will take the wind out of your sail.

Boyfriend and I went here around 5 and there were a few other people there already and a couple others while we ate. It is a very small restaurant. They have tables and the bar-like seating, too. Either way - you will be sitting quite close to strangers.

We were greeted and seated quickly. We ordered the Karaage and Gyoza to share. I ordered the Miso Ramen and my boyfriend ordered the Spicy Miso Ramen. They have all the toppings in all of the soups so you don't have to pay $1.00 for everything you want like at some of the other ramen shops but the bowl of ramen (one size) is a bit smaller compared to others and only comes with one piece of meat. 

The Karaage (fried chicken) were the perfect little crispy and meaty chicken bites. They have a little seasoning you can sprinkle over them if you want (you probably do want to!), and it comes with a fresh and tasty salad on the side. 

The Gyoza were ok. I would've preferred them to be a little crispier (more burnt!). 

My biggest problem was with my ramen broth!! I feel it was too thick and nutty tasting... it was also kind of cold, didn't even need to be blown on before taking the first bite. Boyfriend had the same problems with his spicy Miso. 

I think I'll go elsewhere every time I want ramen. Two stars for the Chicken and quick and friendly service.

My miso tonkotsu ramen was delish! Meat was tender, and the miso flavoring just right! The half-egg added the right touch to the noodle soup dish, which was very filling! I ate the whole thing, but I think I ate too much!

I love all asian food, but my true love is ramen.  I will eat it in the middle of a las vegas summer, i will eat it in the morning, I will eat it in a house, I will eat it with a mouse, I will eat it here or there....... you get the idea. 

Fukumimi is an oasis in our (up until recently) ramen desert. It is traditional while still offering enough options to keep those that need variety happy. The staff is friendly and attentive and always willing to make recommendations. Located outside of  asian food alley (spring mtn)  it is not as convenient for those traveling from the edges of town, but i promise you it is worth the trip. 

The tonkotsu ramen is my goto dish.  The pork is the perfectly cooked  with just enough fat to enhance the flavor without ruining the consistency. The noodles are cooked to perfection. The flavors in the broth are pleasing with out being overpowering.

The portions are fine for a normal lunch or dinner. When i am super hungry I will usually ask for an additional order of noodles as soon as my ramen arrives. The second helping will arrive about half way thru the first.  Pro tip:  Try to save your broth for the second helping.  

If you are tape worm hungry get an order of kimichi.

Remeber to slurp your noodles.
Never had anything like it! Very small place but it's a whole in the wall. I go every month since it is next to my school. Love their bowls with shredded beef.

Best ramen I've ever had. We both ordered the fukumimi ramen, with edamame as an appetizer. Pork belly fat in the broth makes it umami delicious! Service was friendly and efficient. Small place. Noodles were perfect and I discovered that I like fatty broth over the other kinds. Figures lol If I lived in Vegas, this would be the place I'd go for ramen.

This is the first ramen bar I have ever been to. I wasn't sure what to expect as the only ramen I've had before was bagged or cupped, granted, those are also tasty versions of the Japanese dish; but far less than authentic. 

I ordered the Tantan Men and my friend ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen. (Pictures included) We also got the edamame for an appetizer. Of course, edamame was delicious. Always is, those things are little podded seeds of love.   

Adam was not a big fan of his Tonkotsu, though I thought it was delicious. It was salty, but I prefer my meals do be so. For him, however, the flavors didn't mix well together as the garlic oil seemed to over power the rest of the dish. 

I ordered thin noodles in mine and was very pleased! It was both spicy and sweet with a plethora of flavors dancing around on my palette! I also added egg and it really made the dish pop. (Adam has since gone back and ordered my dish because he loved it so much.) 

Thank you Fukumimi staff, you were very pleasant and accommodating. My drink never emptied and the atmosphere was positive. 

Cheers!

NO JAPANESE CHEFS HERE AT THIS TERRIBLE JAPANESE NOODLE SHOP!!! The OPEN KITCHEN consists of 4 Hispanic Cooks. YOUR CREDIT CARD INFO STOLEN HERE! See photo how they leave your Credit Card receipts WITH YOUR SIGNATURE ON IT right by the front door for any undesirables to steal. NO ONE THAT WORKS THERE SPEAKS JAPANESE. Mostly Spanish and Vietnamese; tryinging to force diners out half way done with their meal so they can turn tables and the waitresses speaks and acts as if everyone in the world owes them money. FOOD IS HORRIBLE (Frozen then de-frosted smell)!!! SERVICE IS THE WORST!!!!! Zero clue why this place was rated any good. Maybe it was good in the past with the previous owner but DEFINITELY TERRIBLE now (February 2017)! Very, Very Perturbed and Very, Very Disappointed!

When in Vegas, you don't think of dining at a ramen place... But after eating a large buffet lunch, ramen or something light doesn't sound so bad!!

The ramen was fresh and soup was pretty good. I got the one with the heavy garlic oil (can't remember the name). My only gripe was that the pork slice was only a single slice. It was prepared very well and delicious. 

They offer small and large size rice bowls. My fianc got the small char siu bowl with shredded egg. It was a simple dish and it's not the typical char siu you normally get at a Chinese restaurant, it's a subtle stewed pork. 

The atmosphere is your typical Japanese ramen or izakaya joint (everything is wood and there is sushi bar seating).  

Overall their service is friendly and their prices are affordable. They even have a stamp card, but four ramen bowls and get a free appetizer!!

3.5 stars

Yelp 100 Challenge - 36 of 100
Not the best ramen I've ever tasted, but a nice stop for a cold night. Service was fast and staff was nice, generous portions and good prices.

My husband and I had our first ramen experience here and we really enjoyed it.  This is a small restaurant with quick and friendly service.  It was a Monday night and the place was crowded.  We both had the Fukumimi special, thick noodles, and my husband ordered his spicy.  It was served with a generous portion of pork belly and green onions, half an egg and garlic oil.  We had gyoza and kimchi as appetizers, both very well prepared.  Highly recommend for a quick tasty meal or hangover helper. ;)

Maybe things taste better when you are sick. Ran into this place before catching my flight. Quick service! Sat at the bar and maybe 10 later - hello ramen! Yum yum  the broth was deep and creamy, pork belly always a plus and oddly, I liked the seaweed. Will definitely come again!

I went here with my brother and father around 2PM. The place was not packed or anything, def chill. We got our noodles rather quickly, I ordered the Miso Ramen with thick noodles. For how many reviews this place got I was not impressed with the food, neither was my family. The broth seemed bland, the noodles tasted old rather than fresh, and it appears that the amount of corn they put into the bowl was like 2 tea spoons full. I had to put a ton of Sriracha and Chili Oil in my ramen to give it some sort of flavor. Will not be back....

Our family of four ordered karaage (Japanese Style fried chicken) and gyoza for appetizers. Chicken was crispy on the outside and tender on the inside. Gyoza was cooked great as well. They have a good selection of appetizers all under $5. For entrees we ordered 3 fukumimi ramen and 1 classic ramen. Broth was full of flavor, pork belly chashu was soft, tender and tasty. If you are a fan of Kim chi, order the Kim chi bowl which has a small bowl of rice, topped with some greens, Kim chi and shredded seaweed that once mixed together makes a great medley. 

There are a couple seats at the counter and a couple of tables so there could be a wait depending on your timing. 

As a resident of Henderson, this location is very convenient. All the other good ramen spots are west of the strip near china town.

Been looking for a decent nearby Ramen place since Monta Chaya closed. I think I found it. The food is excellent. The service could have been better, but the strength of the food allows me to give this place 4 stars. I had a delicious Tonkatsu Ramen and the Karaage was filled with flavor. Definitely coming back here to try the other ramens.

Like the place. Although when they are closed the place looks bigger. But its small and cossie; I like that. I do feel they need something more inside. Not so much more as in having tons of pictures/ornaments, but just enough to keep the same feel for the place and not lose the feel how it looks inside. Maybe a picture or two of a flower. I don't know if anyone else has ever thought of this but I felt like the cooks and the rest of the small staff had a great working relationship. I just felt that because I sat in the bar rather than the tables. 

  I had the spidy miso ramen. The noddles tasted good! Wish it had more. The chilli taste was not so hot, but good cause I just came out of work and it was the first day of the new year where it was pretty hot outside, so I was not looking forward to start sweating, but also I do not want something without spice. Great taste tho. Nice presentation of the dish. Place is clean and no irritating kids.
Definitely my go to when I'm craving ramen. They have the best karage to go with any ramen you choose. Service is fast, food is great.

My paborite ramen spot in Las Vegas, NV. Discovered this place on Yelp about 3 years ago and still remains my favorite ramen spot, nuff said. I wish they opened more locations. I would love to franchise my own Fukumimi if they ever decided to go that way.

Small ramen bar WAY off the strip, it was about a $20 taxi ride from our hotel

They have some bar seating and some tables but if you're coming with a large group id advise coming at an off lunch hour 
---agedashi tofu: not bad
---kimchi: nice side dish
---tonkatsu ramen made spicy and with thick noodles: you can choose your noodles, good spice to the broth and yummy pork belly 

NOTE: $5 minimum credit charges
Proabably my new favorite ramen place in vegas. The tan tan men is the necessary move when here. It's rich and nutty and really amazing.  Worth the drive from the other side of town for sure

My first time having ramen . It's a small place probably seats about 30 people max . The ramen was delicious . My Japanese friend took me and he said the ramen reminds him of Japan ! So I know it's legit . 

We started off with karaage , agedashi tofu , and gyoza . Everything tasted really good ! I had the miso ramen and he had the fukumimi ramen which is their most ordered ramen . The fukumimi comes with more meat it's a better value .

I love this place but when I tried ordering the tan tan men, our server asked the cook if he could just replace the broth of the tonkotsu ramen with with the tan tan men broth and he said yes. However the head server did not want to do so but I don't understand why because I was just asking to replace the broth. They told me if I wanted to do that, that I would have to pay extra for everything I wanted in it when I was just trying to replace the broth in the first place!!! Good ramen but very bad service!!!!!

I usually love this place but I just spent 40 minutes waiting on a order to come out. I sat and watched as three tables were sat and served. The waitress was kind in explaining that the cook lost my order and about 20 minutes into it and that I would be served I the next 5 minutes, but that didn't happen. Water for lunch today. With the number of Ramen options I'll not likely return.

We had lunch here today.  We were there at 11:00 and was promptly seated. We had the gyoza and they were perfectly done. I had the thin noodles and she had the thick. The broth was heavenly and the pork was delicious. We both slurped our bowls to the bottom. This is a great little hole in the wall close to home for me so my return will be soon.

This place is soo good! It's authentic what more else can you ask for?! Anyways despite the place being soo small it's very delicious! I had the Tonkatsa Ramen with a boiled egg! Ahhhhhh hits the spot! I also ordered the chicken karaage! Hands down  go ahead & try it out!

I've been to Monta Ramen, Ramen Sora and Ichiza. This place wins above them all! The place looks and feels like authentic Japan. The food is by far the best! Every ramen assortment I've tried has been so tasty and again, authentic!

They have a stamp card, so if you buy 4 ramen bowls, you get a free appetizer! This was easy to get in just one week bc I came back everyday...guilty for this, but so worth it.

I've brought my friends and family, they've all agreed that this is the best place for ramen in Vegas!

P.S. Try the curry bowl, super delicious and just like they make in Japan! I always split a ramen and curry bowl w my husband when we go! Enjoy :)

We came here instead of Monta because my partner prefers Chicken and Monta doesn't serve chicken. Never been to Monta so I can't make a comparison. 
The place is small but pretty nice. We ordered honey chicken and chicken rice bowl for my partner. I didn't eat the rice but the honey chicken Karaage is delicious. Tender in the inside, a bit crunchy outside.  The sauce is a bit tangy and has a good taste. 
Now the main menu: noodle is pretty decent. Al dente - just how I like it. It has a good flavor but I taste better somewhere else. The broth is spicy and has a very strong smell. Do I mind? Nope cause it's delicious. The egg is okay. Nothing to writes home about. Now, the chasu!  That's a different story. I got extra and I am not sure how much they put without the extra. But man...it was plentiful in my bowl and soooooo good. It's the kind that melt in your mouth. Very tender and delicious. Will I come back? Definitely. Recommended? Definitely. For me, the chasu speaks for itself. Will be back if we ever visit this town again.  
Update: 9/6/2015
Had to come back before going back to Houston. I like the noodle more after the second try. And the egg was actually tastier this time. Overall, highly recommended if you like spicy ramen.

Lunch on Presidents Day. This is a great ramen spot on the east side of Las Vegas, only minutes from UNLV. We had the Gyozas for appetizer, which were delicious. I had the Kogashi Ramen. Flavored with an awesome fragrance of garlic  fried onions and small ramen noodles. Yum!!!!! Come down now and have a bowl of soup, you won't regret it.  The dining area isn't very big, if you don't count the 6 chairs at the bar area; so you might wait a few minutes to get a seat. But remember, LasVegasJapan Times.com rated this place better than Monta! This place also serves Miller and Sapporo alcohol.

Its not on my side of town but I went out of my way to try this place and I was glad that I did! Good to know that if I'm heading out to Henderson or the southeast that their is an Authentic Ramen shop to satisfy my hunger! Japanese owned! Great Staff

Pretty darn good.  Not as good as the Raman Yamadaya chain in LA.  But, good noodles.   They have skinny ramen and will customize to make it the way you like.

Yummy
Great little find. Would definitely return. Portions are just right, staff friendly and part inexpensive.

Quality of food is great portions are small not a good value for the cost. Service could have been better , I ordered an appetizer and it was served with my meal, drinks were never refilled.  Ambience is great , small dining area that reflects the product. If you want ramen in the vegas area try ramen sora

My boyfriend and I love ramen.  We make it at home and we always order it when we go to Ichiza in Chinatown.  We currently moved to trop and pecos and we would drive by this place Fukumimi Ramen a lot and always wanted to try it.  So tonight we finally did.  

It's not a very big place.  I'd say it seats about 20-30 people.  One thing to note is that though the hours of operation are listed as they're open until 11pm, they take their last order at 10:30.  We arrived at about 10:15pm and the waitress turned the open sign off promptly at 10:30.  

We ordered the karaage and the gyoza first.  Karaage is Japanese fried chicken.  Gyoza is a dumpling/potsticker.  Both were really good.  I thought the chicken was perfectly cooked.  The potstickers come with a special gyoza sauce which was a yummy combo.  For the ramen we ordered the fukumimi ramen, they're specialty.  There are about ten other ramen dishes to choose from.  The fukumimi ramen comes with pork belly in it.  Sooo good.  My boyfriend and I split a bowl of that.  In total our bill came to $22 plus tip.  

My only problem is that I left feeling slightly hungry still.  Maybe next time I'll get my own bowl of ramen instead of sharing (;

5 stars for the:

1. Fukumimi Ramen. Fantastic broth, lots of pork, good noodles.
2. The spicy miso ramen. My wife was very happy with it, and I thought it was quite good too. 

3 stars for the tantan men and portion size. While the fukumimi ramen has plenty of meat, there aren't a ton of noodles. The same could be said about the amount of noodles in teh tantan men. 

Overall a good spot that's worth going to. Definitely recommend.

Really yummy... a nice surprise to find in a strip mall in Vegas. Very umami flavors, super friendly service, a cute little authentic ramen-house vibe. It's the real deal and a SUPER filling meal for under $10!

During a visit to Vegas, I followed a review on Yelp to this Ramen shop because the food at the strip are overrated and overpriced.  

What can I say?  It's hard to find a good Ramen place anywhere in the States.  But, let me tell you, I was a bit amaze at this place.  It's no more than 2 miles from the Vegas Strip and the Ramen was really good.  This place must be one of the best Ramen shop I had in the States.

The Chef and waitress remind me of eating Ramen in Japan.  Upon arrival, we were greeted with a friendly greet.  Sat at our table and ordered Ramen.  


They put pork in almost all of their Ramen, I ordered the Spicy Ramen and asked the pork to be placed on the side and I gave it to a friend (I'm not a pork guy).  The Ramen soup was flavorful and it wasn't too spicy and salty.  The noodle was pretty good as well, it wasn't too chewy but I was hoping it would snap in my mouth as i chew and the feeling of a traditional Chinese hand pulled noodle.  The price was about 8 dollars, and you'll finish your noodle fairly quickly so I recommend asking for more noodle.  But nonetheless, the Ramen was amazingly good.  

I highly recommend this place to anyone who is visit Vegas.

Wonderful place for some local delicious ramen. The rewards cards (gifting a free appetizer every 4 bowls of ramen) are a great incentive for coming back.

Ordered the Miso and it was great, though wish there was more than just one slice of Pork Chasu. 

Overall, would recommend, but just not as great as other places I've been to, especially for the price. Still very delicious and will return since it's so close to where I live.

definitely the best ramen spot in Vegas. not comparable to Little Tokyo spots near Los Angeles for amazing ramen because of distinguishing differences in thickness and quality of broth, but overall the best in this town. spicy miso is my favorite and I always get extra chashu. chashu is perfectly flavored with smokey after-bite. ramen broth is deliciously flavorful and not overly thick, so you want to finish it. noodles are usually always cooked perfectly. 

gyoza is good. nothing extraordinary, but comes out quick. the honey chicken karage is good, but sometimes over glazed with the aioli. Not a huge fan of eating ramen everyday, but this is my best friend and my spot for it when we crave ramen in Vegas. beats jinya, monta, & misoya ramen. service is what you would expect from the typical Japanese restaurant in town; friendly people that take your order, smile, & don't interact much beyond that.

I agree with one of the other reviewers... Monta is good, but Fukumimi's is mo betta. The Fukumimi Special is definitely my type of comfort food.  Each time I've eaten there, the broth and noodles have been perfect.  
Highly recommended...

I had to get the Fukumimi Ramen because it's like their specialty or whatevves. I had high expectations. Once the ramen actually came, well I almost didn't want to eat it. No, not because I lost my appetite, but because it just looked so damn pretty!

*RAMEN BREAKDOWN*

BROTH: It was good, but not the best. It sort of lacked a richness and complexity that I'm accustomed to. 4/5

NOODLES: They were thin straight noodles. Pretty good. 4/5

EGG: Leaning towards the soft-boiled spectrum of boiled eggs. It tickled my fancy. 4.5/5

CHASHU: Okay so I rarely ever have Chashu cut so thinly, but wow that shit just straight up melted in my mouth. ACTUALLY, usually it just melted away as I was trying to pick it up with my chopsticks, but if it ever made it to my mouth still intact, it melted away, like BUTTA. 4.5/5

PRESENTATION: Beautiful. 5/5

SERVICE
The servers were pretty, attentive, polite, and knowledgeable. I'm not sure if they were Japanese though, but they both did have accents. I don't care about that anyway. They're everything you look for in servers.

ATMOSPHERE
Looks just like a Shinsengumi in terms of the layout and that's a good thing. Well, the Shinsengumi by my house, at least.

I approve of this ramen joint, but if I'm going to Las Vegas again, I might skip it so that I can try all the other wonderful Japanese restaurants around. Nothing personal though! I'd recommend it!

I believe in Las Vegas, this ramen place is as good as it gets (especially since Kai Gen Ro is no more). I had the 

Fukumimi Ramen: the broth is milky, not as milky as Ippudo in NY, but still really milk of bone milky, not cream milky. The noodles are very similar to a thin egg noodle I used to get from a company called Quon Yick, but although they are similar these noodles are definitely very tasty and cooked perfectly. They are not overcooked and the color is slightly translucent but still opaque enough that you can tell they are done with care. Seaweed is the normal nori that you would find in large sheets cut up into squares. Their chashu is pork belly slow-braised and sliced thin, seasoned well and not overly salty. 

You can get kaedama (another mouthful of noodles) for $1. It's not on the menu, but you can request it. It comes in a little rice bowl and is less than the amount at Monta, but Monta charges $2 for their kaedama.

I also tried their

Curry Rice Bowl: their rice bowls come in small or large. The curry was okay, but I'm not as big a fan of Japanese curry as I am of Thai or Indian curry. The ginger was somewhat special to me because I noticed they took the time to include pickled turnip which was also red. It's interesting because normally the red pickled ginger is only ginger, so it was a nice little surprise. 

Their front of house staff mainly speaks Japanese, but understood enough English to take my order. The interior is mainly decorated in wood, very simple yet chic. It speaks and says, we're here for you to eat and enjoy a moment of zen. I enjoyed my moment. It's also more spacious and they don't try to turn and burn, like at some other places... eh hem. 

They cleared away dishes discreetly and added water appropriately. Their service was apparent, but not brash. I also forgot my sunglasses and they chased after me to return them. From start to finish, I enjoyed my meal very much.
Love their Ramen !!!!!  And i usually do not like ramen from anywhere!!!  They have me hooked for life !!!

Delicious ramen. Great options on the menu and a loyalty card (gotta love any deals). Loved the Kagashi Ramen, the broth was not too salty or heavy. Loved the toppings and the pork was excellent. Service was attentive and they offered to split the check from the beginning. I just wish they had more seats!

Don't see what the hype is about. 

Service slow, had to ask for our water several times. Appetizers were served after ramen was served, and in my opinion it wasn't all that. I've had better. 

The ramen broth was not rich enough and the meat didn't have a great texture. Everything was overly salty, even the egg in the ramen. I'm not wowed.
I had a ramen craving and stopped in to try this place. Had the Fukumimi ramen. Definitely hit the spot.  Atmosphere reminded me of Japan. Great place to stop in for a quick  bite. Highly recommend.

My favorite ramen on the Eastside! So glad I don't have to go all the way to Chinatown to get some great ramen. Our server is always so nice and sweet & she practically knows me already! My favorite is the Fukumimi Ramen with thick noodles and extra egg! YUMMMMM!
My favorite place! It gets crowded once in a while... But that ramen soup is awesome!!! I recommend the Kogashi soup. Love this place! Check out my pic of the soup!

At the moment My favorite ramen place , you have to try everything and the staff is so nice. Usually order the spicy miso but it's not as  spicy for my taste .its just probably because I like my food rely rely spicy , my second favorite is probably the tan tan men . My husband usually orders soy ramen and the karaage chicken.
My military husband was impressed. He Said,"just like they served it in iwakuni". Easy on the wallet. $2 beer. Hot and deliciois. 4 bowls gets free appetizer and a punch card.

2 of us got Fukumimi miso ramen, akadashi tofu & honey sesame chicken.  One of the best ramen...perfectly seasoned broth (not too oily or salty), tender pork.  HS chicken above average but tofu was nothing special.  Friday night around 6p wait time only 30mins.  Would definitely come back for ramen.

The tan tan men here was really good. Not at all what I expected, but I enjoyed it. 
We also had the chicken karaage, which I liked. My boyfriend thought it had that freezer taste. I thought it was tender and juicy, so whatever, more for me. 
My boyfriend's ramen was not impressive, however. The broth was a little too light for him, and in spite the fact that it was supposed to be ramen.. It came with soba noodles? My tan tan men had ramen, so I know they didn't just run out of the right noodle. 
The tables were oddly sticky, which I found kind of gross, and the service was pretty slow.
Will I be back? Maybe, if I wake up with a burning desire for tan tan men. Otherwise,  there's better places for your ramen fix.

It was just ok. Quick service, nice ambience, decent prices.

I ordered the traditional ramen as it was new on the menu, but it lacked seasoning. Large portion of noodles and broth, but I wish there were some depth to the broth. I'll be back to try a different dish just to make sure I didn't misjudge this place. Until then, three stars it is.

We've all become accustomed to waiting in line for the most popular LV buffets, but dang it not for a bowl of ramen too... astounding...

I shouldn't be that surprised since I know that people will wait for good ramen all the time everywhere, but as funny as this may sound, my time seems more precious to me while I'm on vacation and I sure don't want to spend it waiting for a bowl of noodles.  Fortunately due to the diligence of a couple of Yelp friends, they've trail blazed their way to Fukumimi's, a modest unassuming place East of the strip where you can get a good bowl of ramen without a crazy line to get in like the one we encountered at Monta's...

Two of our favs for apps happen to be Agedashi Tofu http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/fukumimi-ramen-las-vegas?select=F-LSBeG2Chhi6ZNlx2o2nQ#uH7PEnc0RPMmmJ4mSKvzJA and Karaage http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/fukumimi-ramen-las-vegas?select=F-LSBeG2Chhi6ZNlx2o2nQ#F-LSBeG2Chhi6ZNlx2o2nQ;  both of these were nicely done.  The tofu was silky soft with a gentle crispy cover, slightly mitigated by the sweet mirin.  The presentation was superb as each block was topped with negi on one, hairlike strands of nori on the other, and bookended by a single baby bok choy.  The chicken was nice and juicy with a seasoned crust, accompanied by a citrusy green salad on the side to cut through some of the saltiness...

We both got Tonkotsu Ramen, the one that favored salt has flavored garlic oil http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/fukumimi-ramen-las-vegas?select=F-LSBeG2Chhi6ZNlx2o2nQ#HFqyXLlE-6uJ134LGBgxzg, and one that favored soy has a single sheet of nori http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/fukumimi-ramen-las-vegas?select=F-LSBeG2Chhi6ZNlx2o2nQ#0oIEfHKL4HBSBS4pUC5WOQ.  Both come with chasiu, half a seasoned soft egg, sprouts, and more chopped negi.  Not the richest kottari pork broth that I have found, but despite it's thinner consistency it was still a tasty soup that  managed to really hit the spot without inducing an impending after lunch drowsiness.  The egg was beyond runny but still on the soft side.  The chasiu with its familiar outer  ring was sliced thin, slightly collapsing when tugged at by chopsticks...

Service was cheerful and polite, in that Japanese schoolgirl way, but short of obnoxiously annoying like you feel when being patronized. The best thing about everything was the casual speakeasy feeling about being able to sit down immediately when you walk in and getting service right away without any hovering or rush.  Parking is a non-issue in the very expansive mall that Fukumimi resides in.  A very refreshing experience for something as mundane as a bowl of ramen while on vacation...
Came for the Fukumimi ramen, and it was really good, wasnt creamy like Monta which i prefer. Kaarage was good for the price. Would come back.

It was close to our hotel and had a lot of great reviews. 

Tonkatsu ramen (soy) was too salty for my taste. 

Honey garlic chicken was too sweet. Wish it had more garlic flavor than honey. It was drenched in honey and made the chicken soggy.

Great place! 

Everyone was friendly, fast service, excellent flavors, reasonable prices. 

First we ordered the honey garlic chicken. We soon fought over the last piece.

I got the ramen with the same name as the restaurant. I liked it. Lots of pork. Filling and tasty. They covered the inside of the bowl in seaweed. The noodles weren't too soft. Good ramen.

Will got the one with the ground pork. The pork was sweet seasoned and it was a good contrast. The broth was creamy and savory. It had a little spice. He added the marinated egg and it had plenty of flavor too. The thick noodles had a great texture too. 

We thanked the kitchen as we left and they all yelled happily back. If we lived nearby we might be regulars here. 

Eat here, it's a gem!
Good ramen place but with very limited menu. For non-pork eaters, there are only three chicken dishes.

It failed to disappoint me the second time! It's a small place so the wait time is not that long.. get their Ramen card so you get a free appetizer for every 4 ramen bought! Tryin the curry rice it's sooo good!

This review is for 3.5 stars.

Fukumimi is a nice option if you're on this part of town, butI'm still partial to the China Town and the south durango/rainbow ramen joints.  The prices here are very reasonable, but the broth and noodles didn't leave me craving more.  They specialize in tonkatsu which is my favorite so my hopes were high coming in.  I had the spicy ramen and added extra spicy paste and corn.  They sell sapporo and miller for alcohol so selection is bleak, but both are under $3.  The ramen broth was a much redder variety and was saltier than I typically like.  The noodles were fine and the chasu wasn't memorable.  And the ramen only came with 1 piece which was disappointing.  The price is the best attraction of Fukumimi.  They have some nice appetizer options for under $4 that are pretty big considering, so that's definite plus.  For th price Fukumimi is fine, but I'm not gonna go out of my way to come here.
Had the Kogashi Ramen and quite enjoyed the flavor.  Nice little restaurant and very friendly service staff.  Would go back to try different soups.

This place is located in a deserted shopping center.  I hear this area used to be the place but people have started to move out so it's all on its lonesome now. There are a handful of tables down a long row.  The place is decorated pretty nicely with colors that remind me of other ramen shops.

Tan Tan Men: Not exactly what I expected when the bowl came because I am used to the Chinese version.  I expected it to be thicker and with less soup/sauce but the noodles never slurped up the soup that I had expected.  The taste was not as strong as I would have liked either.  The peanut flavor is pretty light.  The ground meat was sweeter than expected but at least it was hot and decent meal.

Small Curry Chicken Rice: Ordered this as a supplement to all of our ramen soups.  The curry flavor was not extremely spice-y.  It was also pretty light in terms of curry flavor.  Little pieces of chicken within the curry and also included were pickled radishes.  I actually enjoyed this more than my tan tan men but overall it was around a 3.5 star level.

Ramen is pretty big in Vegas and there are tons are other places I have found on Yelp.  This place is decent but it was a let down.  It was like a healthier version of ramen I had wanted since the flavor of everything was not strong.  Service was decent but you gotta WOW with your food and this place wasn't WOW-ing me.

Servers are quick and nice. They're very approachable too! They have stamp cards here so if you're a ramen addict, it's a plus! My favorite in their menu is the HONEY GARLIC CHICKEN! Taste is perfect! Servings of ramen is really just for 1 person. They have restroom located at the back. The ambience is pretty chill, nice ramen place to bring your friends and chat! It is located at TROPICANA/EASTERN. The parking space is huge so no problem if you get there late.

After a long day at work, I decided to come in on a busy Friday night for a bowl of ramen because I had a craving.  I was just a single party of one at the bar around 6:30pm.  They took my stamp card and redeemed my free appetizer.  My green tea came promptly and I got gyoza after 10 minutes.  The wait for my ramen took about a half hour, they served a table of 4 people that came in after me, and they screwed up my order because I originally wanted a Classic ramen, but on bill was Kogashi ramen. After I brought that to waitresses attention, they could not change ticket because that was what they said I was served so I was annoyed because it cost a dollar more than I wanted to spend  and they refused to correct even though it was not my mistake.  I was so tired, just wanted to go home so let bill slide to just get out of there after an hour.  Ramen was alright, not as flavorful as previous visits so had to add condiments and the gyoza didn't have any taste just texture even though it looked like tiny meat in there, had to use chili and gyoza sauce.  This used to be my favorite ramen spot on Eastside, but may not return.  I miss when customers were able to get what they wanted, but I guess that is too much to ask for.
Great food and great service.  Prices are reasonable. Definitely recommend this place. Although sometimes there's a longer wait to be seated due to limited table and seating.

Meh. I don't know what it is about this place, but I'm really not a fan. I had the spicy miso ramen this time. First of all their ramen serving is like half the size of others. Second, I feel like the spicy paste they use overpowers the actual flavor of the ramen broth. Other ramen places in town that I will not name right now, you can taste the spice, as well as the broth. 

Don't think I'll be back again. Too many other competition in town that are better and have bigger servings for the price.

Yay a ramen hut that's not in Chinatown! If you are looking for hearty tasty fatty ramen broth, you've come to the right place!  No other ramen place in Vegas adds garlic oil to their ramen.  Their chaschu pork is so soft and tender (similar to Monta).  They give you the perfect serving amount.  Best ramen hut in Vegas!  Also, they give you a punch card where you can get karage or gyozas for free!

If you are a person who puts Tapatio in regular ramen you NEED TO STOP EVERYTHING AND EAT AT THIS RAMEN RESTAURANT!

They can add 'Spicy' to most ramen dishes, which is amazingly good. Also since no one knows about this place, it's generally not busy but IT'S SO GOOD.

WAIT. I'M NOT DONE. 

If you are a person that enjoys salty foods and fried chicken

GET THE KARAAAGE!!!!

It blows away every single piece of chicken I have ever eaten. Watch out though, its very hot (temperature wise).

UPDATE!!

One day my boyfriend was sick. He was nauseated and not feeling good and was unable to eat most of the day. He was feeling really bad. I, being a good girlfriend, picked up Shoyu Ramen at Fukumimi. I thought he would only eat a little bit. I ordered it takeout and brought it to him. I mixed it up for him and he ate all of it. The next day he was back to normal and eating. I was amazed at the power of Shoyu Ramen from Fukumimi. It was like giving my boyfriend a Phoenix Down.

Wanted a quick ramen fix when i was in Las Vegas, and this was close by. Pretty tiny restaurant. Pricing was around $8 for a bowl of ramen, which didn't really come with that much meat, or rather, it just came with one piece. Not really that worth it, but obviously, I'm from the San Gabriel Valley area, where Asian food is all over, so I have a more biased point of view. Soup base is ok here as well.

I had the gyoza and the Fukumimi.

The gyoza was like any other. It was $4.90. It was good. Don't really have anything to say about it except that it came after our ramen which I didn't really like. It got to the point where I was wondering if they had forgotten my order.

The Fukumimi was $9.50 and I thought it was a good amount. It filled me up for sure. It has pork belly, egg, seaweed, and scallions. The broth I thought was really good. The flavors were great. One didn't overpower the other. It was a bit salty which I liked--it does have salt sauce. 

The service was great. They were really nice! You can get a loyalty card. After your fourth stamp, you get a free ramen! 

Definitely recommend this place and i would come back again.

The food was delicious. At first, I compared it to Monta ramen but I think that this restaurant is its equal. The only thing I have to say is that it's a little dirty here. They should wipe down their walls and clean up a little more. But service was immediate; the hostess greeted us upon entering & quickly asked us what we would like to drink. Soon after, we ordered an appetizer and our noodles & while we waited for the noodles, the appetizer, Agedashi tofu, was AMAZING. And that's saying something, considering I don't even like tofu. Our noodles were perfect & DELICIOUS! Check out the pictures I posted! 

Although I would definitely come back again, I don't think I will very often because it's far away from where I live.

Up there with Ramen Sora, Fukumimi is my other favorite ramen spot in town. 

Just like at Sora, I always have the usual, the Fukumimi. It comes with all the nessescary essentials: pork, miso broth, thin noodles, nori, green onion, egg... But as an added bounus, you get their yummy black garlic oil poured on top.

I have tried the Tan Tan Men as well. I really, really think that you should order it, at least once. It's not everyone's cup of tea (right Khatherine T.? Heh heh), but when I tried it, I have to say it was a nice change of pace.

The minced pork is almost sweet, with the broth being quite even and mellow. There almost seems to be slight nutty flavor to it. It's nice to break away from the usual once in a while.

One of the awesome things about Fukumimi is their rewards card! It only takes 4 stamps to earn either a free karage chicken or gyoza on your next trip! So it really doesn't take a million trips over there to earn it, unlike some places where you have to buy 10 or 15 of something to earn some small reward.

There's not much room inside, so it can get crowded fast. Most of the time, it's not, so don't worry. They should look into serving a bigger selection of adult libations. You can only order a few beers and (I think) sake. There's such a high profit margin to be made an alcohol, I don't see the harm in trying it out. 

This is a little Vegas gem. Make a special trip!

I went to Fukumimi because I want to try other ramen shop other than Monta. I absolutely do love Monta, but I want to keep my option open because Monta get crowded too much. 

I got the Tonkatsu(soy) which already have an egg, chasu pork, and sea weed wrap. 
I have to say, it's a great deal. 

The noodles were good, a little too firm than I would like them. However, I also prefer thick wavy noodles, and they only had thin ones. 

The broth was okay, nothing special. I thought it was a little bland. 

Now if their pork was as soft as Monta, I would have been sold, but it was. They felt dry, and the main reason why I love Monta is because of their super soft melt in your mouth tender. 

All in all, I give it a 3.5 star because there was no line, close to work, and the location is easily accessible.

This place has some pretty good value.

Coming from Vancouver, I wasn't expecting much in terms of ramen, but Fukumimi can definitely compete with some of the best. My friends got the fukumimi special, and I got the Spicy Miso variant, and they both tasted pretty damn good.

What I really enjoyed though, were the side appetizers. The karaage, gyoza, and honey garlic chicken were all really good, and we ordered them the two times we went there.

Definitely worth it!

It's right next to the Baskin and Robbins on Tropicana and Eastern. It's a new place that just recently opened up. Wouldn't have found out if a friend didn't tell me. 

So far I would have to say I like it a bit better than Monta, but not by much. I grew up in Japan and ramen there has never made me nauseous or throw up until I've came here and tried Monta's. 

The service is typical, with a greeting at the door and a waitress came and seated myself and a friend. There weren't that many people there, actually only one party of two on the other side of the restaurant, when we went in. Thought they seemed to be a bit confused with which table ordered what at first, but that was sorted out quickly. 

It was a cute place, with the kitchen being maybe a third of the restaurant which is a open bar style, with a bar seating area right in front of it. There were tables and a bench seating area to the right upon entering. The bench seats also double up as storage, my friend pointed out that they look like they moved and so I got curious and got up and wanted to see if they could. =] 

So we got the Tonkotsu ramen (pork based broth), my friend got the salt and I got the soy, both priced at about $7.50 which wasn't too bad. The salt included garlic oil, one piece of chashu, green onion, egg, bean sprouts, and ginger. The soy included, nori, one piece of chasu, egg, bean sprouts, and green onions. I personally felt mine was saltier than the salt one, but my friend had a different opinion. (We'll have to try it again some time and determine which is saltier)

The soup base wasn't too bad I've still had better, it wasn't very strong, the noodles they used were the really thin ones, but were cooked pretty well, as they weren't too soft or too hard. I don't usually eat pork but I took a bite out of the chashu and gave it to my friend as I knew it would have made me sick. 

There were other items such as miso and spicy, along with their Fukumimi ramen, which seemed to include extra meat and corn. You can add other items to your ramen, such as corn, extra meat, egg, etc at a small extra cost. They have the extra noodle option but it's not on the menu. 

It's a good place close to UNLV, so you don't have to travel deep into china town for ramen, or for those of us living on the east side it's a bit closer. =]

I am so in love with Fukumimi! 

Quick lunch or dinner... Afternoon snack or After Dinner Snack. Anytime is a good time to dine here. With 

Fukumimi offers ten choices of Ramen bowls! 

Tonkotsu Ramen broth is the house original pork flavored soup base, rich and smooth. They are topped with  chashu pork belly, seasoned egg cooked medium, green onion and fresh bean sprouts. Bowls in this category ranges $7.50-$9.50. My favorite is the Kara-miso Ramen ($8.50) because I like spicy soup! This delicious broth is thicker than the others, blended with miso and bean paste, topped with corn kernels . My kids love Tonkotsu Ramen ( miso), broth is thinner as well as the Tonkotsu Ramen (spicy) ..both at $8.20 a bowl.

The house also offers chicken ramen. Each bowl is topped with seasoned egg? Green onion and bean sprouts. There are only two selections in this category. The Tori Ramen is flavored with a salt based sauce, topped with chicken cha shu and garlic oil. Then there is the Classic Ramen bowl in which the broth is flavored with soy sauce, topped with pork belly cha shu. They go for $7.50.

We like supplementing our meals with:
Karaage chicken $3.90  (two thumbs)
Honey Garlic Chicken $4.90 (two thumbs) 
Gyoza $4.90 stuffed with pork and chicken
Agedashi $3.90 

Don't forget to get frequent dining card. For every five bowls of ramen, you get a free appetizer!

Great place, great food, great prices!

Expect to wait, it is a small place and no matter what time of day you go they are always busy. 
Menu is simple, makes it easy to try everything in just a couple visits. 
I always stick with a starter of gyoza, or karaage and the Miso ramen. Hits the spot every time.

If you're looking for a great ramen spot in Vegas, Fukumimi is the place to go! It's a small but very cozy, family-owned restaurant that provides quality service and food at great prices. They stay busy all day, everyday. Your order is ready within minutes and they even have a stamp card that will keep you coming back. I'm a regular at this restaurant and my favorite soup is the Kogashi Ramen soup. Definitely recommend it for all the "Ramen lovers".

Fukumimi has about a dozen ramen base x flavor combination options and all the ones I've had are great, other than the chicken base one. It was fine, but I think that's just because chicken doesn't have a lot of flavor in itself and is more meant to soak up flavors. The staff are efficient and I haven't had any issues with them in the many times I've dined in or out.
Could be better, could be worse.  The ramen is average, but affordable.  The best things about this place are the appetizers.  The salad, the curry, and the karaage are the standouts.

My friends and I heard about this place but hadn't gone. But now we go all the time. I got ramen the first time. It was so good and flavorful. We also got the Karaage and that was so awesome. It's the best!!! The wait staff is friendly. Can't wait to go back again!
Above average. A lot better than other ramen place in town and inexpensive. Highly recommended to all ramen lovers......

I just simply can not get enough of this place!  If you are looking for outstanding traditional Japanese ramen & the best Karaage I have had outside Japan, LQQK no further!  Their Miso Ramen & ever so delicious Karaage is "on par" with some of the best I have ever had while living in Japan!!!  Hands down the BEST in town & it's not just me saying this.  Check out their awards on their walls!  You won't be disappointed.

First ramen place I've tried in Las Vegas. I can see why it has such good reviews! Service is amazing and efficient.

They do not have hot tea just canned tea which is alright! 

I got the tantan bowl and it was supposed to be spicy but being someone enjoys a really spicy bowl of ramen it definitely was not spicy at all. I soaked that bowl in chili powder and siracha! Then it was delicious!

Other then that it's in a odd location but plenty of parking and the place is pretty small. They won't sit you down unless everyone is present type of thing.

I do recommend this place but if you like a spicy bowl you won't find it here! But everything else was perfect (:

This place is a simple ramen place. Food is average and service is average. Their bowls are small so always order extra noodle if you don't want to leave hungry. This place is usually not crowded because it is not in a good neighborhood. There are homeless people around. We come here a lot because it is nearby and we don't have to wait. I recommend here if you just want to have simple ramen quickly.

No stat!!!!!! This restaurant is ridiculous. The waitress is rude! I came in with my family and waited in line. The waitress just skipped us and took another group of people without saying anything right in front of us. I never seen such a rude service.
Excellent food. Always prepared perfectly whether it's take-out of eat in. Staff is friendly and efficient. My favourite spot for noodles.

Expect to be in and out quick.  I enjoyed their ramen and the broth, but I somehow ended up enjoying the fried tofu even more.  It was a few bucks, but definitely worth it!  It's a very soft tofu on the inside, lightly fried on the outside, garnished with green onions and unsalted seaweed.  Eat it when it first comes out.  If you come back to it after your dish, it won't be as good.

If you plan to be back, ask for a stamp card.  4 bowls of ramen = one appetizer, aka the fried tofu (:

The food is a tad salty.  Unfortunately, the service sucked in which we waited 15 minutes and observed how the people who walked in after us were given immediate service.  As a result, I recommend you eat elsewhere that provides better food and fabulous service.

This has become my go to ramen spot. The service is generally pretty quick, and while the staff isn't totally personable, they are friendly and efficient. 

It's a little hidden and from the outside it looks a bit run down as the windows are covered and you can't see inside. When you get inside, it can be a little crowded when they're busy because their waiting area is small. But that gives it a very intimate feel. It's a cozy little spot, and while it's pretty busy, the longest I've had to wait to be seated is 10-15 minutes. 

My usual order is the Tonkatsu Ramen (miso). I like the thicker noodles and buttery broth. My husband orders the Spicy Tonkatsu, which he enjoys, but then he is always taking some of my broth because he says he likes it better. 

It's not the most amazing ramen I've had in my life, but so far it's the best I've had in Vegas. The bowls are smaller and there's not as much meat as other ramen places I've been to, but the quality and price is good. It always hits the spot when I'm craving ramen.

I do wish they did free refills for soft drinks. You can only order by the can. Regardless, I still plan on coming back and trying other things on the menu!

One of the best Ramen places in LV.  The soboro Bowl was flavorful and packed a great punch for such a tiny item.  My wife and I were fighting for the last bite.  I enjoyed my Spicy Tonkatsu Ramen.  The noodles were perfect, the bit of pork and the sweetness of the added corn made it heavenly.  When it comes to Ramen Houses, its all about the broth.  It was great!  I highly recommend this Ramen house.

I'm the pickiest when it comes to Japanese restaurants. So, I gave this place 3 stars because I've been to way better ramen places. To me, the broth tasted watered down and the karaage had no taste. But for the rest of my family, this place tasted good and they loved the ramen. Also, just wanted to throw it out there, but if you guys are ever down in San Diego, you need to eat down on convoy street because they have some of the best asian restaurants.
How can you be out of soup? Closed? What if I didn't want soup? Just say it's closed and that's it?
Good ramen and appetizers for its prices. Not the best ramen in Vegas, imo, but a solid option. Don't dismiss Fukumimi!

First of all I have been eating ramen my whole life. My expectations were meager. First we had the curry rice and it was super flavorful with a hint of sweetness. Miso ramen is the benchmark of ramen and the broth was full and powerful but the real star was the noodles. Very thin but must be homemade because the held firm to the last bite with a great flavor. And the karrage was some of the best I have eaten. Served with a little seasoned salt for dipping and a green salad with a tasty miso vinegrette. Look out Monta it just got real.

You know you're a regular when the host says, oh you're here with your whole family! Normally it would be the frequenter, stamp card holder that has converted 4 free appetizer. 

***No hot beverages here, as noted on the menu. 

The honey chicken was good, not too badly priced for $4. It's like a fried chicken bite with a honey, lemony sauce. 

The wait was a tad long by our ramen standards, but not too bad. The decor takes you back to a place of orient origin, you'd forget that you are at a strip mall with a Dotty's next to it. 

Price-wise, normal ramen price range. Flavor was good. Pay attention to the extra's and types of noodles that come with each bowl selection. 

I'm sure this place has more regulars than just my two pair of Las Vegans.

Stumbled upon this place and I couldn't be happier. I come every friday and everything I have had here has been great. I've tried other Raman places in town and this one blows them out of the water. The staff is super friendly and the prices are very reasonable.

I am here every week. If not, twice a month. 

I always have the Miso Tonkotsu Ramen (with extra butter & extra corn, of course) & Gyoza. Sometimes, when I feel like I'm a whale, I order the Mini Chashu Bowl & the Honey Garlic Chicken Karaage. DROOL. Everything I order is consistently good. I cannot complain about the service. They are friendly and pays attention to what you need just by looking at your table.

Tips: 
1. If you're bring in a big group, call in advance.
2. If you fall in love with this place like I did, ask for the stamp card.

One of the coldest days in town so I was looking to warm up. A ramen place on the east side of town, interesting and exciting! I went in ore one thing and one thing only, miso tonkatsu ramen.
Food came out quickly so I jumped in to get the chill out of my bones. Slurped through the tasty broth then took own h pork and noodles. Definitely a good bowl of ramen. Can't wait to plan my next trip.
The servers were very friendly and made several visits to our table to make sure were satisfied. Yes we were!!

(S)o much buzz on Yelp lately
(T)etsuro P. highly recommends the Tan Tan Men 
(I) asked about it, but they were already sold out at 6pm...:(
(L)ittle space inside, and it fills up very quickly
(L)ine out the door when we were dining there...good sign!

(P)rofessional chefs and service staff here
(R)ice bowls are available if you don't feel like slurpin'
(E)xtremely rich, hearty Tonkotsu based broth, but like they say.....Fat is flavor!
(F)ukumimi Ramen is very flavorful and filling
(E)gg with your ramen is an absolute must!
(R)eally liked their curry bowl with pickled veggies

(R)easonable prices here that won't break the bank
(A)mple parking outside...You'll have more trouble finding space inside!
(M)onta Who?????
(E)xcellent meal, 4 Stars!
(N)o Gyoza yet? Gotta have gyoza with Ramen!

(S)oboro bowl was another great suggestion by our waitress
(O)verall, I am a fan...:)
(R)amen lovers should check Fukumimi out!
(A)LOHA!!!!

This stuff is way better than the 
pre-packaged 79 cent noodle packs you can find at any grocery/convenient store. I'd recommend trying their Spicy Ramens with Pork Belly. I would definitely pass on the chili oil which leaves a bad aftertaste. This place is pretty good overall.

not bad - I may go back in a pinch of needing to quench my Ramen craving but that probably won't be anytime soon. 

This may be a bit of a snotty review. 

my favorite ramen spot in the world called silver lake Ramen in Los Angeles  destroyed all of my later Ramen experiences because their broth was hands down the best I've personally tasted. 

So I'm not being a total jerk and just giving this place one star, they are good and worth a try.

This place has limited seating so get here before peak times. Just like many Asian restaurants, service (waiters/waitresses asking you if everything is OK, filling up half cup water, etc.) is mediocre. So if you're here expecting them to bow down to you, then this is not the place for you. I personally don't really care about service, I'm here for the food.

I got the Fukumimi special the first time I was here. The noodles was perfect, not too the soup was a bit salty though.

This time we got the gyoza and karaage. The gyoza didn't taste like they just defrosted it, very crispy on the outside and juicy on the inside.

This time I got the Tonkatsu Spicy. There was a good amount of noodles. It was not soggy and just the right amount of firmness. Soup was spicy but really salty again.

This wasn't the best ramen I had but it is up there. I had the best ramen in Honolulu, and have not been able to satisfy my ramen cravings. Still need to go to Japan to try the original but for now, if I'm in Vegas, I'll be going to this restaurant for ramen in the states.
Tonkotsu ramen had excellent flavor. Gyoza was great, too. Will definitely be back next trip to Las Vegas.
Cool inexpensive spot. Lots of college kids. I would eat here again ! All ramen dishes

The food was good. I started with the karaage which comes with a small salad. The chicken was juicy and good on its own, but I added a sprinkle of lemon and salt for a complimentary flavor. Then I moved on to the ramen. I got the Tonkotsu Salt based ramen which is pork based and comes with thin noodles, pork belly pieces (of decent size), green onions, bean sprouts, pickled ginger, and a cooked egg on top. The base is hearty and fatty without being overpowering and I love that all the flavors really compliment one another. All in all I would definitely visit here again.
Very good Ramen. I ordered the basic ramen and the broth had a really nice flavor. The service was fast and the waitresses were very friendly. This was a great meal before heading out of Vegas.

I needed to eat something soupy and great for a cold.  What else would've been better than ramen?!  

Picked out this place based on the reviews and the pictures.  We went there for dinner and there were lots of parking available.  We were seated right away, I guess we got there at the right time for dinner.  I ordered the tantan men and karaage.  I really enjoyed the broth of the tantan men because it was perfect for my cold, flavorful and little kick of spiciness.  As for the karaage it was great!  It wasn't oily and it was cooked just right.
The service is bad the lady was rude.We order chicken karage and I ask for a mayo and she gave me dirty look...... the ramen is horrible. I won't make another visit
It was a decent ramen...sour was tasty and noodle had the right texture. However it was warm, not HOT like you expect from Ramen. That was the only disappointment that I had.

yelped ramen in vegas and this was the top rated result

came in with a terrible hangover and a overall bad vegas trip, this place sort of salvaged it.

got the Fukumimi ramen, with added spicy paste.  

Everything melded well together, noodle texture was great, brother was bomb, and the chasu meat was top notch.  Only thing i wish they added was bamboo (personal prefernce)

Service was great also, friendly waitresses. will be back next time! hopefully minus the hangover
The Tonkotsu has better flavors then Monta in my opinion and the wait is short which I like. get a stamp card eat 4 bowls get a Gyoza or Karaage free. It's a plus that it's on my side of town.

Fukumimi Ramen is a spot that my wife and I frequent as it is one of the few places on the east side that serves good ramen.
