I usually opt for the ramen with the chicken broth when I come down to eat at Fukumimi and it always hits the spot.  However, when I'm not in the mood for ramen and somehow end up here, I grub on a kimchi bowl with a side of egg. I absolutely love the shoyu egg here.. perhaps more than the ramen? It's just that good. What can I say, I love eggs haha.  I have to find out how they make it... But in the meantime, I'll be frequenting often to get that ramen / egg goodness. Yep, I'm weird.. I know.

Anyway, good ramen eats on the East side! Definitely will be back soon! (This review is actually being done from Fukumimi while I wait for my food.. oh, here it comes! Gotta go!)

2nd best Ramen Place I've had. My partner and I were in town for business from California. LA/OC area to be precise. If you've ever been, you know there are MANY places to eat ramen. We've tried a great amount of them and this place definitely makes it top 5. 

 We were starving and craving ramen so decided to give it try. Service was fast and smooth and the menu wasn't saturated but had just enough for every taste. 

The place was cute and nicely decorated. I had the spicy miso ramen. I was very happy when I started eating because it wasn't the type of spicy that ruins a meal. It was just the right amount and very delicious! Did I mention this place is VERY affordable? My friend and I had each a bowl and a drink and the total was 20! (After tip) I'm very satisfied and will definitely come back !

Overpriced! Bad service. Waitresses were unfriendly. The ramen was good but for over 9 dollars it could have had more than 2 pieces of meat and half an egg. Food quality was good but not worth the price.

I went with a friend for dinner here. As soon as we arrive and we were greeted and seated right away. The place was small and very homely. They were busy. Our waiter came and got our ordered. We ordered the Tonkotsu (salt) and the Karaage. The Karaage was super delicious and came with 6pc. with alittle salad. The ramen was also delicious  The soup was very rich in flavor so i could only have a little of it. Service was good. Staffs were very nice.

Their quality of ramen is pretty good. I'm not completely sold to choosing them over Monta, but their slice of pork is pretty thick and impressive! Also tender. I highly recommend their tonkatso miso ramen as I love that nice thick broth. It was filled with corn, green onions, and medium boiled egg. 

The noodles have a nice chew to it. Not too soggy and not too under cooked either. The broth was full of flavor. The pork had that nice consistency of chewiness, and the ramen all together was full of flavor. 

I also recommend the fried gyoza as a side, and their homemade kimchee. Not up for ramen. I highly RECOMMEND the Chasu bowl (pork and white rice, with ginger). It's so delish and it too is full of flavor. It has a very subtle sweetness to it which I love and is also very tender and nicely marinated. I think if the ramen doesn't win me over from Monta, I'd say their Chasu bowl does. 

The vibe also brings out that nice grassroots local Japanese feel with the small establishment, wooden seats, and specials hand written and posted on the walls. The location is very off from what most typical Japanese restaurants are, and is a bit out of the way for me, but if you're in that side of town or have that nice gap between classes from UNLV it would be a nice place for lunch. I have yet to try their sesame broth which I think is also one of their signature ramen bowls. I'm not fond of the sesame flavor though as those flavors are typically too strong for my taste buds. If you do, definitely let me know how it is!

Came for a quick lunch - boyfriend was sick and insisted we get something steamy to help his sinuses. Fukumimi Ramen was our choice, and our choice was a great one!

The restaurant is small (but not cramped, per se) making for an intimate atmosphere. It was surprisingly busy for a Monday afternoon, but we were seated at the last open table almost immediately. I can imagine there's quite a wait during dinnertime on the weekend!

To be honest, I'm a ramen newbie. There's still some flavors involved that I just can't get used to, so I took my usual route: Tonkatsu ramen with a miso broth. Fukumimi has by far the best I've had yet. The only critique is maybe adding a lil more meat to the bowl? Other than that, it was delicious!

Along with a bowl of some spicy ramen, my boyfriend got a bowl of rice, pork, and egg that he shared with me - the dish has a name, but I cannot recall what it was exactly... Anyway, that dish was probably my favorite part of the meal! Super flavorful and the small size was a decent amount of food, for only $4.

After reading all the rave reviews about this place, I decided to give it a go. To start things off I ordered the kaarage which came with a salad on the side.  The salad was very tasty, but the kaarage was a bit on the greasy side (didn't agree with my stomach later).  For the main dish, I decided to go with the "classic" miso ramen.  Perhaps I didn't read the menu in detail, but that miso ramen was spicy!  I was sweating bullets.  Overall, the ramen was good for Vegas, but not "the best I ever had, the best I ever had".

I'm telling you if you love ramen and Japanese tapas this is the place to go to. Really impressed with the freshness of the food and the quality had to go back there after 2 days and do it all over again.

I've lived in NY, SF, and LA and would have never thought that Vegas would have good Ramen.  Many LV restaurants, especially by big name Chefs, have failed to impress me but this place is the real deal.  It was inexpensive, service was great, and the Ramen tasted authentic.
I found this place on my last visit to Vegas.  I had an hour to kill before my flight and decided to give it a try.   It's in a very plain shopping mall, like all good food is in LV (see Lotus of Siam), and the shop is small.   
I got the Fukumimi Ramen and the Soboro Bowl.  Ramen was great, pork was tender and broth was flavorful.  The Soboro bowl was also good but a little too sweet for me.  I'm glad I tried it but will probably try another bowl next time.
Love this place- I crave the miso soup- so glad that we moved close by AND that they have a punch card.

This ramen is the definition of mediocre. A lot of my friends have sworn by this place and I've given it multiple opportunities but each time it is more and more disappointing. The ramen has no bite to it, the and broth is near flavorless. The egg's yolk should be running but it's not, and the chashu pork is too chewy. Very unsatisfied and upset each time I visit here. 

Their garlic chicken isn't bad but you don't go to mcdonalds for the salad.
Ordered the Fukumimi ramen----very delicious. Will come back again for more. The Chashu bowl is great too.

Exceptional authentic ramen and other small dishes at a very reasonable price. The restaurant is small, but it is decorated properly, like a little place in Tokyo. The place has a critical audience of Japanese people, which is a great sign. You often have to wait a bit to get a seat... but that's because people really like the food and the word is out.

We come here whenever we visit Las Vegas. We don't go to the other Ramen places anymore.  This is by far the best.  The Tonkotsu ramen broth is excellent, not too salty.  We tried the Tori Ramen for the first time this visit. Yah, chicken... not pork.  It was flavorful. Had a rich depth you want in a ramen broth.  Tasted like genuine ramen broth that requires hours to stew.  I would eat it again any time. 
Karaage is top notch. The batter is light. The chicken is moist. It comes out piping hot. It is amazing. 
Next time will try the tofu with kimchi. We saw the next table over enjoying it.  Looked pretty good. 
Bathroom was so so.  Not smelly or soiled tough.

Mediocre meal, prices are very reasonable. 

Came here one day for lunch, and we each ordered a bowl of ramen. The ramen was decent but nothing exceptional. I got the traditional Tonkotsu ramen for $8.20, the ramen noodles were a bit hard and not very bouncy like they should be. Also there's a very tiny bit of veggies and meat in the bowl, very little substance. We also ordered the fried chicken as an appetizer and that was slightly better than the ramen. 

With all the other great ramen places in the area, this wouldn't be my first choice.

So my friends and I arrived 7 minutes before opening, we opened the door and a lady promptly pushed us out. No big deal, but another party came and the same thing happened. So, it's now 2 minutes to opening and we hear a distinct click of a lock - no one else had tried to breach the entry. 

So now it's 3 minutes after opening and they still haven't unlocked the door. I should have suggested that we leave and go somewhere else, but I was hungry. She finally opens the door, we're seated and given tap water - gross. 

The food was okay, small portions don't really do it for me. I did enjoy the agedashi tofu, but everything was basic, nothing special. 

I won't find myself returning. I can understand not wanting us in before opening, but to lock the door 2 minutes prior to opening and then opening late when you have at least 12 people waiting outside, is not good customer service.
My favorite place for ramen in Vegas. Place is small, but tables turn fast. I waited 10 mins for lunch. Not bad for a highly rated place during a busy lunch time.

Awesome place!  Very small so expect a wait but it's well worth it.  I got the chicken based Ramen which was delicious! Although it only came with 3 slivers of chicken it was more than enough food.  I opted for extra egg which meant 3 total halves! I also got the spicy paste which didn't really add any heat to the broth but there was Sriracha available so I doctored it up. 

The 2 unsung hero's however were the house salad, the sesame ginger house dressing was delicious, although it was just greens and dressing I could have eaten a pound of it! The other unexpected hero was the kimchi. The portion was small but it was quite possibly some of the best kimchi I've ever had.  So good I'm pretty sure it could convert a non kimchi liker into a lover!  

Definitely coming back for some more Ramen and kimchi!

I ordered the fukumimi Ramen topped with egg, green onion, dried paper seaweed, and pork chasu.  The noodles are thin, had a good chew and held its texture till the last bite.  The broth had a nice strong flavor and not overly salty. The oils had a good sheen to it. You can add more spice or oils to accommodate your own taste buds. The pork was pretty fatty and the egg was more hard boiled than having a runny/soft yolk. 

Try out the appetizers such as their Agedashi tofu, gyoza and honey garlic chicken! It very much compliments your entire meal

Overall, the price was a bit steep for for what you get. The portion size was smaller than most Ramen spots I been to but I was still satisfied with my meal. It still filled me up. On the plus side, they have a bonus stamp card that can lead you to a free appetizer when you complete 10 visits. The atmosphere is welcoming and not overcrowded at all. You can walk in and sit without having to squeeze through to get to your spot.

P.s. There is no dessert at the end of your meal. Lol but you can always go next door to Baskin Robins for ice cream after.

I had the Tori Ramen and it was delicious! Broth, chicken and noodles were tasty. I added the spicy paste and corn and it gave it a great spicy flavor. Hubby had the chicken bowl and he enjoyed it and some edamame. Service was great. The restaurant was small but cozy. Prices were great! For two of us it was under $20 bucks.

Finally got to try Fukumini and I enjoyed myself! I can't even remember how long I have had this place bookmarked but I digress. 

Fukumini is located down the street from the airport and UNLV is an otherwise unassuming strip mall. It is very easy to miss, especially in the dark which is when me and some friends went. For a group of 4 on a Tuesday night, we probably waited only 10-15 minutes. Not terrible. The space is on the smaller side so I would not really recommend coming with a large group. 

I ordered the Tan Tan Men which comes with thick noodles. The broth was very flavorful and the noodles were cooked great! Still had a nice chew to them. My favorite. My friends also recommend the Fukumini Ramen, which sounded like a shio/salt based broth. It's their most popular bowl I believe! They also have several rice bowls and appetizers to accompany your meal. 

Parking is not an issue at all since it's in a big strip mall. It's right next to the Baskin Robbins in case you get lost!

I came here when they first opened and the issues that have plagued their broth since their initial launch has yet to be addressed when I came for dinner a couple nights ago. The spicy miso ramen is flavorless and the chashu is similarly tough and bland. The broth is the foundation to build upon for any ramen but it ultimately just ends up tasting like lukewarm water with spices floating on top instead of imparting any flavor. The chashu pork paradoxically needs a ton of salt to even have any taste. The noodles are nothing worth mentioning and the portions are meager.

Our server placed our bowls at the edge of the table and I had to scoot it to the center myself. They were attentive with pouring water but it made no sense to me why they didn't place our bowls front and center of us.

Really, Fukumimi needs to revisit the fundamentals of building up a solid broth in which to build upon. They would have much to gain to learn from Monta or Jinya who have much richer, flavorful and dense broths with tender, salty pieces of chashu and larger potions.

Until then, Fukumimi isn't worth a single visit.
Love the Tonkontsu Ramen and Chicken Karage !! The soup base is very rich and the chicken is tender.....will definitely come back again !!
They have a wonderful and rich broth. They run the average price for ramen around town and it's nice not to have to drive to the other side of the strip for good ramen.

Ordered the karaage which was served with a side of lettuce. Unfortunately, we found a substantial amount of rotting/wilted lettuce in the mixed greens. I ordered the fukumimi ramen - the broth was quite good: sweet and rich while avoiding the bitterness that plague other restaurants. The noodles were a bit undercooked for my liking and require a quick rinse to avoid the starchiness that clouds the flavor of the broth. Service was prompt and friendly.

My new favorite ramen place, which is perfect because I live in the area (yay!). This place has been opened almost a year now and I've only been here twice, my first being in August and the second visit was a few weeks ago. Kind of odd to see a legitimate ramen place on this side of town, but they are always welcomed by me! Since we are on the east side the patrons eating are more diverse, unlike the eateries on Spring Mtn., which tend to attrack mainly Asians.  It is pretty small and only has a handful of tables so the last time I came it was pretty packed. Service has been good on both visits considering they are in a small area. I have ordered the tonkatsu ramen both times and I like it! I particularly like the corn. I prefer Fukumimi much more than Monta, but that's just my opinion. My friend ordered the Tantan and it really reminds us of Filipino karekare (peanut butter stew) a little different, but very similar. She enjoyed it and gave me a bite which was delish from what I remember. Last visit I also had the chicken karaage, this was good too and not too greasy. I also love the fact they have a stamp card (4 ramens earns you a free karaage), unfortunately I didn't get one on my first visit or else I would of gotten my free karaage already! Fukumimi will be seeing me regularly!

Been meaning to try this place out for a little while now. So after hitting the gym on a Wednesday night, decided ramen was what the tummy craved. 

Came in about 730ish and the place is tiny. 8 tables and 6 bar seats. It was about half full, was greeted briefly at the door and took a seat. The server offered drinks and then have enough time and space to look over the menu. Most of it sounded line ramen from any of the other ramen place in town.

I asked for a suggestion and asked if I like spicy. I do, do I was recommended the karo-miso spicy ramen. Also ordered the Soboro bowl. Both items came out really quick. The bowl was rice with ground meat with onions and scallions. It was tasty. Savory with a touch of sweet.

I like spicy food a lot, and many times restaurants that say their food is spicy, it doesn't hit the spot, however this ramen has a good kick. It isn't Hannah or anything, but enough that extra spice isn't necessary. The broth is rich and flavorful, not too salty. The noodle itself has a nice bite to it. Was once told that good ramen should have a elastic spring when you bite it. Which these definitely do.

Lastly the prices are decent. Definitely will return. For the location it is in and the size out would be misleading to judge by looks. People were coming and going the last 20+ minutes I've been here.

So my bf says he actually likes this more than pho restaurants, and he has a lot more experience than I do. But either way, this place has some really good food. He keeps ordering the Spicy Miso. I've tried the Chicken Tori Ramen, the chicken rice bowl, and tonight I'm trying out the Miso Ramen with seaweed. So far, my favorite is definitely the ramen
We have eaten here about ten times! Always a great server and always great ramen! I get the curry bowl and green tea. Yum!

Horrible service we came in when it wasn't that busy and none of the waitress offered to sit us down when they had plenty of openings. We asked for Sprite and Coke and got water I didn't want corn or egg and got that we had to keep calling are waitress she wouldn't come to us.people next to us were waiting for water and they had to aspirate and got their food before they even got the water so it's a girl couple of minutes for her to give them the water after they had already gotten their food. SUCKS I HATED THIS PLACE

My family and I were visiting Las Vegas and wanted to try a couple of the local ramen hotspots.  Of course, we'd eaten at a few of the big Strip joints too.  But wandering off the Strip and eating some non-touristy food had some real appeal.  We'd already had a great meal at Jinya but had been turned away from Monta.  (This is important: they'd told us that the wait for a party of five was almost 90 minutes.)  So we pulled up Fukumimi on Yelp and headed off to what we hoped would be another wonderful meal.

Unfortunately, we never got to eat.  When we arrived, there were only a handful of people waiting for tables, so we were optimistic.  We signed in and were told that there were just four groups in front of us.  "So how long for a party of five?" I'd asked.  "About 20 minutes," I was told.  It's a small place, but everyone seemed to be eating already, so we weren't too concerned about the wait.  Then, after a few minutes, I actually got a glimpse of the waiting list.  There were indeed just four groups ahead of ours.  Two were singles.  One was a group of three.  But the last was a group of nine.  I immediately began to wonder: "Huh?  How are they going to seat us with a group of nine ahead of us?  The entire place will have to empty out before they can clear up five seats?"

20 minutes passed.  Then 30.  The two singles were seated, then the party of three.  Around the 40 minute mark, a table of four cleared out and an offer was made to the group of nine (only four of which had been waiting inside the restaurant): "Can we seat four of your group now?  We'll seat the rest when tables open up?"

That's not terrible--and I'm not being critical of it.  The group was there before us and deserved to be seated in accordance.  Still, it was now apparent that (even though we'd been told we'd be seated in 20 minutes and had been waiting for almost 45--see Monta reference above) we still had a 20-30 minute wait ahead of us.

Then two things happened in quick succession: after a few of his family members headed to the table of four, the father-figure of that party purposefully blocked my way from securing on open chair for my 72-year-old mother-in-law.  She'd been standing for 45 minutes and I wanted her to have a seat.  He held off so one of his teenage family members could grab the seat herself.  (I know, I know: it's hard for restaurant staff to referee this kind of thing. Still, my blood was starting to boil and, like it or not, that is inherently part of my Fukumimi experience.)

Then: there'd been a party of five guys sitting at the bar.  They'd already had their food when we first arrived.  Now, two of them got up and left.  I mentioned to my family: "If the other three leave soon, maybe we can just sit at the bar."

Then, two other guys wandered in the front door.  They asked how long the wait was.  Immediately the hostess offered up, "I have two seats open at the bar."

I'm sorry but . . . if you've had one party waiting for twice as long as you've promised . . . and you've already negotiated a staggered seating arrangement with another party . . . you should at least offer us the opportunity to take seats at the bar.  It's not hard to say, "Sorry you've been waiting so long.  If the rest of that group at the bar leaves, do you want those seats?"

As it is, I crossed our group off the waiting list and went to get our dinner elsewhere.  If a restaurant can't manage it's own waiting list, I'm not sure I want to know how it handles food orders.

And for the record: three members of my group were family members visiting from Japan.  We'd already decided that the aromas coming out of the kitchen--while good--weren't nearly as appetizing as what we'd experienced at Jinya and Monta.

And the sight of blackened potstickers and dry kuraage chicken coming out of the kitchen should have told us to leave sooner anyway . . . .

We've been to this place a few times and came to the realization that this place is.. ok. Its not the amazing ramen you get from a place like Sora, and its not a runner up to a place like Monta.. But you do get good service and the food is not terrible. The Honey garlic chicken is delicious, the ramen isnt amazing.. but its not bad, and the gyoza is perfect. The service is really good and the staff is very friendly and attentive.
I have been here like every other week, they have good quality of food and they have stamp card. Love this place very much!!

Very affordable and nice place! I usually go here if I'm too lazy to cook and don't wanna spend too much money on a fancy dinner. The best ramen in the neighborhood. Peaceful atmosphere and great service.

I have managed a Restaurant on the Strip.  I was totally dissatisfied with my experience at this location!  

I expected much more!

I will say that the waitress was OK, however she did not check back with the table to make sure all "food" is OK, she did not ask at anytime if we needed anything else to include drinks!

The food I ordered was A Bowl of rice topped with sweet ground pork!
It was very dry, the pork was very little "like they say, where is the Beef" and the sauce was not enough to last with the total overload of rice!

I have been in many countries around the world, and actually when it comes to the ambiance "the feeling of wanting to dine-in became less than desirable", I felt uncomfortable!  The tables & chairs "so cheap and cheap looking", and minimal room!

They have truly much work to do to make this a 3,4,5 star business!  It can be done with some TLC!

I will never go back there again and I do not recommend anyone to go there.

There are so many Ramen restaurants in the valley, seek and you will see!  

For Now, Jake Out!  :) God Speed!

Tried it as I was close by. Glad I did as I will be back quite often. Had the Miso tonkatsu ramen and the karaage(fried chicken). Both were comparable to Monta. Rich savory broth full of flavor and the fried chicken was amazing! True, the portions are a little small, but looking at the average fat slob complaining about the lack of a bucket sized serving of ramen ,Portion control is not a bad thing. It's quality over quantity. If you prefer the latter then head to a Asian buffet for $11.99.  Prices here were very reasonable and service was efficient and personable. But the true stars on this day was my excellent food.

Good food, good service, good price! Hands down, it's the best place in town for ramen. I usually get the Kara-miso (spicy miso) ramen, but with the thin noodles - the spice level is just right. The bowls and appetizers are pretty tasty too. Our family loves this place and we could eat here every week if they had a closer location to our house.

I ate here solo. Took 20 mins to get sat. Got my order in about 3 mins after that, just one bowl of spicy ramen. Took 15 to get it delivered. The noodles were about halfway done. The toppings were about a tablespoon of green onions and half of a hard boiled egg out of the fridge that was still cold. Broth was awful. About as spicy as black pepper on a cesar salad. After i finished i sat there for another 13 mins before they asked if i was finished. 8 more mins for the check. 15 more
Mins to get my card back. Spent about an hour and a half for some terrible gas station type ramen. Just go to a 7-11 and get some instant ramen in a plastic tub. Itll be better and you could save yourself an hour and a half

Visited this place one night by word of mouth. I've been to a few Ramen joints but this by far has the most flavorful broth and different concoctions. I can appreciate the several choices they have on their menu. It's a bit of a drive for us but we will definitely be repeat customers. I highly recommend the Fukumimi spicy with the large noodles. This will satisfy your ramen craving! Wish I had a bowl right now!!

Best ramen in town! My favorite is the Karomiso ramen with added butter. The chashu is yummy everytime. The place is small so expect 30-40 minute wait to be seated most nights for dinner. Most of the staff here are really nice and friendly, only a few times they were rude. Good thing the food is so yummy or I would care :-)

Stopped in for lunch with the family. This is a good bowl of ramen but it doesn't beat my favorite place in Portland. The flavor was on point, good amount of noodles but lacking pork. It had one small itty bitty piece which i could have consumed in one bite but instead of took small bites here and there to enjoy it throughout the bowl. 
TIP:: No hot beverages here, but good prices on beer.

Thanks to my brother-in-law we were able to find a reasonably priced Ramen restaurant with AMAZING food! I love love love Fukumimi. I wish I lived closer to it so I can enjoy an $8 bowl of Ramen every day. The restaurant is located on Tropicana and Eastern in the Tropicana East Shopping Center. There is ample parking, but the restaurant is small. It can fit probably 30 people with bar seating. We came there on a Wednesday night around 6:30 PM. It was slightly packed, but we beat the rush. When we were done eating there were at least 11 people waiting by the door to get seated or pick up their to go food. 

FOOD: The ramen here is so good! Not only are the noodle delicious, the soup is tasty, but not salty. There's also a spicy paste that gives caliente lovers the kick they've been searching for in their Ramen dishes. You can order the spicy paste on the side or have the Chef add it in. We had the following dishes: 

1. Karaage Chicken ($3.90): the chicken came out fresh and crispy. It's the best I've had in Las Vegas! THIS IS A MUST TRY!!! 
2. Honey Garlic Chicken ($4.90): Gosh this Honey Garlic Chicken is what I dream about on a Friday night. It's so gooood. Whatever they cook this sauce in is bomb. 
3. Tonkotsu Ramen Salt ($7.50): The soup was tasty and not overly salty. You won't walk out swollen and dehydrated for all the sodium you consumed like most ramen places. This bowl comes with thin noodles. 
4. Fukumimi Ramen ($8.20) This is the ramen I had and it's my FAVORITE! I would come back to eat it again all day errrr day. :-) It's a big bowl with a lot of pork belly chashu so I recommend sharing this. The chasu pork is so soft and fatty. You'll never experience chashu pork like this ever again unless you're at Fukumimi. 
5. Curry Rice Regular Size ($6.50): This was my least favorite dish, but it was good. The curry is well seasoned on top of rice. I think there was too much rice and the curry lacked chicken. 

PRICE: You can dine here for under $10 and leave satisfied. The value for this place is awesome and I would recommend anyone dining on a budget to come here. 

SERVICE: Service was sub-par because they were understaffed. The girl who was taking care of us forgot to bring us water for 10 minutes. She also took care of other people's orders that came in after us. These people were sitting at the bar so I think they were in her view more. That was a little annoying, but I'll let it slide because the food was THAT good. 

Overall, I loved this place and I recommend anyone who loves Ramen to come try it. 5-star's for the food and value, 3-star for service and overall experience is a 4 star. 

Happy Dining, 
J Tran

Ok, this place served the best bowl of ramen that I've ever eaten. I admit that I was skeptical at first when my friend told me about this place. I've had their signature Fukumimi ramen and their Tan Tan Men. 

I prefer the Fukumimi ramen. In my opinion a good tonkotsu should have flavorful broth but not to the point where you feeling like you're drinking liquefied lard. This bowl fits the bill. The noodles are the straight kind, the kind that I like.

If you like a good spicy bowl of noodles then definitely you should try the Tan Tan Men. The broth was a bit too thick and creamy for me, but it was still good. The broth was begging to have extra noodles added! It was spicy but not overly spicy where you can't taste anything.

I also had their karaage. It was very juicy and tender. One of the best I've had.

Their service was really quick and friendly.

This place definitely is the best ramen shop in the Vegas area. Monta used to be my go-to place, but now it is here!

PROS:
-Good service and decent prices.

FOOD 2/5:
-Tonkotsu Ramen Miso ($8.20): The ramen did not taste like authentic Japanese ramen. It didn't have a good broth and it tasted water down. 
-Fukumimi Ramen ($9.50): Same as the other ramen, just didn't have good flavors. The broth is supposed to be the foundation of the soup and it didn't serve justice at this place.
-Honey Garlic Chicken ($4.50): Ok this was good karage, and I enjoyed the honey flavor.

CONS:
-The Ramen.

Decent, inexpensive ramen.

We stopped by on a Thursday evening, and we ordered bowls of the Tonkotsu soy and the Fukumini special ramen, as well as an order of the tofu and the honey garlic chicken. The honey garlic chicken was surprisingly tasty and tender, while the tofu was pretty ordinary. The ramen was also decent, the broth a bit salty and with decent flavor, although the portion size was also fairly large. All in all, it's a solid, off-the-Strip dining option.

There were eight of us and we all got a different dish and appetizers.  It was all very good.  Rice bowls were tasty though nothing special other than the flavor.  Ramen was good.  They made fried chicken and it was amazing.  It is a very small place so for a large group it could be difficult.

Everybody who is reading this review go get checked by a doctor.

I came here exactly 12:32PM on Sunday August 30th.

Came with 5 people sat at the bar ordered 3 waters and 3 diet cokes

GUESS WHAT???!?!?!

THERES A FAT CRICKET IN MY WATER AND I DRANK IT

Oh on top of that all they said was "sorry" and charged us for 3 diet cokes and I dipped out 0-100 real quick.

We are a family of 5 from LA and love sushi and great service!  We were not sure what to expect when we walked in the door, but were immediately greeted in a very nice way and taken to our table.  Got drink orders right away and then the food flowed out to us very nicely. Waitstaff was friendly helpful and quick.  My 3 little kids wanted edamame right away but for some reason that never came. They did get a yummy chicken veggie udon noodle soup that they all 3 shared,  we got a bunch of rolls hand rolls etc and the tuna carpaccio .....good but not the best I have had!  Mo


Desert was yummy! Kids loved the Mochi with chocolate sauce on top.


Overall great spot great workers who have fun and get the. Job done.

Went here during lunch time and we were seated right away since we got there 10 mins before they were opened.  There were a few ppl already there waiting.  This place is small so when it gets busy it might be a long wait.
- Honey chicken was delicious and edamame tasted the same like everywhere else.
- Spicy Ramen and Miso both were good.  Number 1 in rice selection was ok.  My son didn't like that much.
- Fast services.  Reasonable priced.

Fukumimi's ramen was ok. I like Ramen Sora better. Fukumimi only have regular size ramen which will not go by my husband. I like that Ramen Sora have regular and large size ramen bowl. The Cha-shu (pork belly) of Fukumimi was so thin and didn't taste as good and from what my girl friend says, "it smells."  Not sure if I'll come back here :(.  A little disappointed! Oh and they don't have chahan (japanese fried rice) either.

Best ramen in Vegas. Actually better than monta... Yes, I said it! 

Usually order the chicken karaage (very authentic Japanese style), and edamame for appetizers.  Then the fukumimi ramen for entree!  Deeeeeelish and def hits the spot to satisfy my humble ramen fix. 

Lots of parking in the lot, but limited seating in the restaurant (mostly for parties of 4 or less, unless sitting on the bar/stools).

Finally some ramen you don't have drive to Chinatown for. For those on the east side of Vegas, Fukumimi is on par (if not better) with those other notable ramen shops down Spring Mountain. 

Fukumimi is a nice cozy spot. The wooden interior and design had a relaxing feeling. 
Service was great. You get the traditional Japanese greetings on your way in and out. Makes you feel welcomed and appreciated. The staff worked together and didn't keep us waiting through the visit.

Now and most importantly, the food.

I tried the Tan Tan Men ramen and it was awesome. The broth was milky, rich, and full of flavor. Their noodles are probably the best I've had out here and cooked perfectly. I couldn't get enough of the minced meat, found myself looking around for the small pieces in the broth towards the end. My friend had the house special and was also very satisfied.

Overall, I was very happy with Fukumimi Ramen and will be coming back. 
Don't forget a stamp card!

Next to Ramen Sora, this also hits the Ramen spot.  I finally got to try this place with the BF and we both loved it!

I ordered the Miso Fukumimi Ramen.  The seasoned egg in my Ramen was my favorite part!  Their broth here is so on point.  It's creamy, not too salty, and the flavor totally knocks me off my feet.  The broth is also my favorite part; next to that lovely egg.  I swear...that egg!
The pork in my ramen was also good, but slices aren't as thick as the ones at Ramen Sora. 

My man ordered the Salt Fukumimi Ramen and was also in love with the broth.  He enjoyed the entire bowl too and loved it!  

We are definitely coming back to this spot for Ramen!

I frequent Ramen Sora for my ramen fix but decided to try Fukumimi Ramen for Saturday lunch. They were rated the best ramen place on Las Vegas Japan Times and I can see why this place is rated #1 in Vegas. 

SERVICE
Attentive and quick. Water was filled the entire time and short wait time! 2 thumbs up.

FOOD
I got their Kogashi Ramen. It's one of their Tonkotsu soup base option and is topped with fragrant garlic oil/fried onion. Broth was all black like squid ink and oh em gee...I loved it. Broth was extremely hot (just the way I like it in the cold weather), super flavorful and I loved their thin noodle. Chashu was next level...so tender. One slice of chashu kept me wanting more. They got everything on point. 

I also got their Soboro Bowl. Soboro wasn't flaky/dry like other places. The sweet sauce from soboro went perfectly with their white rice. I got their mini size but it was still a good portion. 

CONCLUSION
Their tonkotsu is flavorful and assari/light. I don't know why Monta is so popular, Fukumimi is much better in my opinion.

This place... I can't go anywhere else for Ramen. 
The food is always good. 
Service is a little overwhelmed, but usually awesome. 
Its like stepping into Japan, and then eating it! *Godzilla Roar*

I love fukumimi! 

Every time I come the staff is super helpful. Twice now I've brought children. Once an infant with my cousin and today with my two year old niece.

The waitress brought a princess cup and spoon for my niece! It was over the top for me in service. After the second time I know they do it for all the kids but really a sweet touch. Bringing toddlers to a restaurant makes me feel bad but they seem to welcome the idea. 

They have the best chicken kaarage in town IMO which they serve with a too small side salad with amazing ginger dressing.



Their curry isn't the best, but still good. The chashu bowl was also good, but not the best.

The flavors of all of the dishes aren't super salty. Everything is very light. 

Even after having my entire bowl of the house fukumimi ramen (which I always get) and karaage I felt satisfied but not overly stuffed. 

The prices are reasonable. Everything is under $10 dollars.

The fukumimi house ramen $9.50 comes with all the fixings (seaweed, 3 slices of pork, oil) so that's what I get and add corn. 

For the good prices, awesome service, and cleanliness I give them all five stars


Most recent visit today I noticed their addition of a few more appetizers and ramen to their updated menus! They use agedashi tofu in soy broth! I believe it was $3.90 The chicken karaage is $3.90 and the gyoza are $4.90 which they let you mix your own ratio of gyoza sauce and chili oil. 

The appetizers are made to order I am about 95% sure of.

I am not a ramen connoisseur, but I do like it, and my daughters love it. That being said, I thought Fukumimi was the best ramen I've had in town (better than Monta!). They had a wider variety of broths than most, including chicken, miso, salt, and spicy. I really appreciated the lighter flavor of the chicken ramen for a change of pace, and the chicken that came in the soup was really good, not fatty and "blobby" like some chicken in restaurants is.
Prices are average for ramen - $7-8 per bowl.
Ambiance is seriously almost exactly the same as Monta Chaya further south on Eastern, with a long bench, wood paneling and a decent-size bar.
As expected, our orders came out pretty fast. Service was friendly and efficient.
It doesn't really matter to me because I like what I like, but my husband was very impressed with the number of Japanese people (even Japanese-speaking) that were dining with us. So maybe Fukumimi is pretty close to the real thing?
Great prices and even better food!! The service was fast, efficient, and accurate. I can't wait to come back!

I can't believe my previous review was a year ago. My boyfriend and I have solidified this as the top go to place for food anytime we are hungry. We go here a minimum of 1-2 times a week; sometimes 4 or more times a week. I have changed out my favorite from spicy miso to kogashi. The boyfriend now gets the Fukumimi, which is basically the same salt ramen he was getting before but with extra pork. The gyoza are still the best gyoza in town (and perhaps even better than most I've had in Japan) and the karaage is still on point. I like their kimchee, but it may be a little sweet for others. Our friend seems to really like the curry here when he joins us. 

The staff is always friendly, and many of them recognize us. They do seem to get busy at random times, but we never have to wait too long. Even when there is a wait, it's well worth it. Truly, this is the place my boyfriend and I eat at most often, and we do eat out quite often, especially during the semester when we are busy.

My first real ramen experience was at Ramen Sora and I surely wasn't disappointed. My check in to Ramen Sora resulted to a ton of advice coming from other Yelp peeps from Las Vegas to SoCal. Either I have lots of love coming from my Yelp homies or they knew I was a newbie to this phenomenon called Ramen.  One common advice, if I like Ramen Sora, I will love Fukumimi. I knew that this visit was coming soon and when Elizabeth B set up the UYE, I could not resist.  

Somewhat armed with knowledge, one thing that I knew coming in was the noodle type that each place proposes.  The Tantan Men was highly suggested, but there was too much in it that I was not allowed to eat until after Easter. So, kept this place bookmarked just for their Tantan Men. I opted for Fukumimi's Tonkotsu Miso Ramen minus the meat, added 2 extra eggs, and 3 extra seaweeds. When it comes to taste, I admit the broth was perfect and creamy.  You also know it's creamy when you cannot see anything deep inside your bowl. So good that I didn't finish my bowl.  As a special touch I added the Karaage to my order, which is basically small fried chicken pieces.  But there's nothing basic about their Karaage. The Karaage is a tastier and super tender boneless chicken that's also lightly breaded.  This complimented the ramen to perfection.  

As for who's got it better than them? Well, depends on the person. I prefer the taste of Fukumimi, but the noodles of Ramen Sora. In other words, I'm torn but do not mind taste testing both and having a personal challenge for the rest of my life.

Couple of UYE call outs.  First time to hang out at a UYE with Elizabeth B, Ian A, Shirley B, and Joe L.  It's been a pleasure and great minds do think alike.  Another UYE with Terri R, Alicia R, Francisco A, and Chad S in a week's time.  This is becoming habit, this is becoming family. Thanks Elizabeth B. for setting this up. You're the best!!

PS: Ate "Food for You" aka Shirley B taught me a chopstick trick when eating ramen. That is to keep the chopsticks intact and use it like a fork and twirl the noodles together. Sort of like how you use a fork to eat spaghetti. Pretty slick Shirley B.
I love this place. Ramen is good, gyoza is good, everything I've tried was delicious. Only one thing I'm not happy about is the service.

Been coming here for a while with the wife, definitely will keep on coming back.

Service: Excellent - In contrast to earlier reviews from others around the summer (2013), we have nothing but good and friendly service. There was one exception, but they were just slammed that night by two large parties, but to the wait staff's credit they didn't lose their smile. 

Food: My first meal there was tonkotsu ramen. I just don't have the tongue for it. My wife, who's Japanese, loves it. However their tori (chicken) ramen is just perfect for me. My tip is to order it with extra chicken.

Their appetizers are fantastic and presented well. Their new agedashi tofu dish is probably my favorite in the valley and the gyoza is exactly how you expected it. However their karaage can be a bit on the greasy side.

Atmosphere: I really like sitting in this place, it's let well, but not too bright, the chef is stationed so he can see most of the customers faces, and every always seems in a good mood once that bowl of ramen is planted in front of them.
In our 5 day stay in Las Vegas, my husband and I visited 3 times. There was always a wait but well worth it. Our favorite was the fukumimi ramen add corn.

This place is right down the street from where I live. I discovered after living in the area for 2 years. Turned out to be really good. I like the honey chicken and the spicy garlic ramen. I have eaten here many times since the discovery. I mostly just go to jinya now, but if you need a ramen fix this place won't disappoint.

Okay, i have had every item on the menu and my 2 favorites are now the Tan Tan and the Tonkatsu (salt). I went back to Monta the other day (and coming from a ramen fanatic you can trust my opinion, there's a reason im the Duke here lol) and i swear to you Fukumimi is better! Their broth is just perfect. I am addicted and you will be too, check it out
perfection. Probably the best dumplings I've had in ages. Terrific kimchi. Near UNLV!  Off Trop @ Eastern on the northeast side, next to Baskin Robbins.

I was in the mood for something a little different from my ramen and this place delivers.  They have a few unusual broths, one that was a bit too sweet but still interesting.  I'll be back to try more flavors and sides!  I really like that they are branching out from making just the usual ramen that every other place has.

It's a small and intimate spot and I love the wood walls!
Service was efficient and friendly. Food came out fast too. 

I ordered the tan tan noodle which was their spicy pork in thicker broth. The broth was thicker because of the sesame paste and the taste was ok. I don't think I am a fan of sesame paste but at least I can say I've tried it. Also, the dish was not spicy.

In a word, awesome.

I'm not a ramen aficionado by any means. I've only ever had true ramen once at Monta and once at the Bacchanal Buffet (which I believe does it the Monta way). However, this is a spot I would love to go to not only because it's a much shorter drive from Hendersonvilletown (Northeast corner of Trop and Eastern, by the way), but also because it's really darn good.

I split the kara age (fried chicken) appetizer ($3.90) with my friends and ordered the basic tonkotsu (salt) ($7.50). The kara age had such good flavor even without condiments, and the salt, lemon, and salad are all nice complements. The tonkotsu ramen was fantastic. The noodles were soft, the meat was tender, the broth was rich and not overly salty whatsoever, and the half egg seems like it underwent some sort of magical transformation to make it seem almost not so eggy in flavor. The whole bowl was a great way to make yourself sweat again in these colder months.

My only regrets are that I didn't really mix well and thus ended up with a decent helping  of julienne ginger at the end, which is kinda strong for me in actual chewing (vs. merely flavoring), and that I didn't know that one of my non-present friends gets free appetizers each time because it's just four stamps (read: four people). We all got individual stamp cards for some reason. Then again, maybe my friend is super special or something, and I'm sure I'll go here at least 3 more times in the next few months.

Believe the hype, guys. Even if your name is Mimi.

This is a hidden gem in Vegas

Away from the busy spring mountain ramen traffic, this little restaurant is very good. Not as salty as other places and it offers unique appetizers. The Karage is very good, and the Tofu is delicious with a beautiful presentation. 

high recommended!
I've been here a few times now. So far, my preference is for the "Classic Ramen", which is chicken broth, chashu, egg, green onion & bean sprouts. Lighter than the pork broth.

This place is AMAZING! My boyfriend and I decided to try something new because we were getting tired of the usual Monta and Sora Ramen. This place was way better than both of those places. As a Las Vegas local, you only ever hear about Monta and Sora.

Back to Fukumimi, we tried their salad, gyoza, edamame and the spicy miso. Everything was phenomenal. We wanted to order double of everything to take home. The broth of the spicy miso was not heavily salted which we prefer. The spicy paste they used was just enough to heat our mouths. Not too spicy for us. The egg was cooked perfectly as well. 

The service was great as well. Very friendly staff!

we will for sure be coming back here again!

Instead of fighting traffic and the crowd in Chinatown I opted to drive to Fukumimi Ramen which is effortless to get to with abundant parking.

I was feeling under the weather and started off with their new fried chicken appetizer. It came with a small salad and the chicken was crisp outside and tasted marinated & tender on the inside. I followed with the Fukumimi Special ramen which was delicious and tasty.

Service is friendly, attentive and they take credit cards.

Excuse my language but this place is "F**KIN GOOD"!!!!!

I normally do not give 5 stars after a 1st visit but Fukumimi Ramen deserves it!!!
Everything we ate was so flavorful and just plain yummy.....

The inside is new and clean with a modern casual decor.... I think it should be bigger cause once people try their food I imagine it'll be packed pretty often....

We ordered the small chicken curry over white rice and one taste of that yummy curry and we knew we were eating at a "I WILL BE BACK" type of restaurant....

The Chicken Karaage was so damn good!!! The breading was perfection and it was seasoned just right - accompanied by a small side of mixed greens with a yummy salad dressing - all this needed was a side of Fried Rice (which they don't have) and I would've been a happy camper!!! 
Both small orders only cost $3.90 each - well worth the price if you ask me!!!

On to our Ramen - I had the "Fukumimi Ramen" which had the creamy pork based broth. On top of the soup was pork belly,bean sprouts,seasoned egg,and sea weed. The noodles were perfect - not too soft - more firm - This Ramen was delicious!!!!

The BF had the "Tantan Men Ramen" which is a Szechuan style spicy soup with a chicken/pork based creamy broth that reminded us of a curry. In the Ramen was seasoned ground meat,bok choy and red chile oil. I tried the broth and it wasn't a taste that I would ever imagine at a Ramen place - it was so freakin yummy!!!!
 
There are add-ins to your Ramen for a minimal fee that you can get like corn ect...

You also get a stamp card where if you buy 4 ramens on your next visit you get either free gyoza or free chicken karaage. I'm not losing that stamp card...LOL

Now on 2 past occasions we tried to eat at Monta which is supposed to be like the Holy Grail in Vegas for Ramen but on each occasion it was too packed and we gave up but I honestly can't imagine any other Ramen places tasting better than what I ate tonight.....   
So, I guess everyone should try Fukumimi Ramen before it becomes like a Monta :(

Walked in and I sat at the bar which I normally wouldn't but today I was wearing an extra long shirt so no free shows for the other patrons sitting behind me at the tables. All their beverages come in a can so if your expecting refills you will be paying by the drink. After getting the menu I asked the server which I told her that this was my first time here to get have some assistance on what they would recommend. My server suggested I try the Kara-Miso Ramen,  which if you don't like any spice then don't get this one. It wasn't Atomic Hot but it had a little bite to it the meat that came with was rather thin so it dissolved into the bowl, I did like that it came with half a egg and corn, if your using corn to see if your regular I would ask for extra to ensure you actually see it if it's for that purpose. 

The Kaarage (Japanese Style Fried Chicken) appetizer, I can't really call It an appetizer if it comes after your ramen it gets renamed a side dish to the ramen. 

OWNER OF FUKUMIMI, below is the definition of an appetizer. (I googled it so it's gotta be right)

appetizer
apt?zr/
noun
a small dish of food or a drink taken before a meal or the main course of a meal to stimulate one's appetite.
synonyms: starter, first course, hors d'oeuvre, antipasto, amuse-gueule, amuse-bouche
"tonight's featured appetizer is a dish of grilled oysters and roasted mushrooms.

Ok so the Kaarage (Japanese Style Fried Chicken) let's just say Fried Chicken is best left to those who know what Fried Chicken is supposed to be like, whether it's a style or not it wasn't my cup of tea, I see other reviews the people go ga-ga over it no we're not talking Lady GA-GA, to me it had a grizzled taste to it and if I have to work harder than normal to eat my food in expending calories that should be done on a tread mill or getting chased down the street by a pack of Pit Bull puppies...

For Vegas, this is my new favorite ramen joint. 

The best ramen I've ever had was in Queen's Square, Yokohama, Minato-ke, Japan. So now, all other ramen joints get compared to this experience.

Fukumimi manages to make a excellent tonkotsu (pork) broth that is the best broth in town. I always get the spicy version here, which to me isnt spicy at all, but adds good flavor. (On an asian scale of spice, its like a 2/10).

The charsui (braised tender pork belly), is hit or miss. Sometimes its really tender, and sometimes its not. Monta has better charsui, and it is consistently good..

But overall I like Fukumimi more.

Pros:
Great broth
Great flavor
Affordable Price

Cons:
Inconsistency on the char sui
Small restaurant (maybe 20-25 seats total).

I had the best ramen in this place! I had the spicy ramen, it was really good. And I will come back to this ramen place before leaving Vegas to have the fukumimi ramen. They both really good in different way..
Probably one of the best Ramen places in Vegas. A little small but excellent service.  Spicy miso is a winner!!

Came here for linner on our last day in Vegas with the BFF's.  The reviews here were hit and miss so I wasn't sure what to expect however I had to see for myself and I'm glad I did.

Orders some things to share:

Gyoza http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/fukumimi-ramen-las-vegas?select=thk-uibVpXaTt1aA87myVA#OXqKLZIdDF0zP5AdcNFENg  Nice flavored filling a little on the smaller side but its pretty good.

Karrage ~ http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/fukumimi-ramen-las-vegas?select=thk-uibVpXaTt1aA87myVA#EZbMXlry4Ef4DiW1Y_yLZQ  Typical in most Japanese restaurants and something that I definitely enjoy eating.  It came out hot and tasty.

Honey Garlic Chicken ~ http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/fukumimi-ramen-las-vegas?select=thk-uibVpXaTt1aA87myVA#8QLZ0rXxVN1Fk-IVPt-7qw  This I was not sure what to expect but I was presently surprised at how tasty it was.  The garlic flavor was very light almost non existent but thats coming from a person that luvs a lot of garlic so to me it was light.  Perfect amount of sweetness from the honey.  This was really good!

Kara miso ramen ~ http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/fukumimi-ramen-las-vegas?select=thk-uibVpXaTt1aA87myVA#zcJ8OaJXqiO6b-CJbjYAVg  This was what the waitress recommended when I asked which she preferred between this and the Tantanmen. When it first arrived I was a bit shocked with what looked to be a good amount of red chili powder.  I like spicy but there is a limit to how much I can handle it and was a bit worried.  I mixed it all in and took my first sip and I was hooked.  A nice miso flavor with a perfect amount of heat.  It wasn't salty at all.  You cant see the ajitama but it had a medium yolk which I luv with a light flavor.  The chashu was fatty and flavorful.  This was a great bowl of ramen!

Eyes ~ Oh that looks spicy!
Nose ~ Smells Yummers.
Ear ~ Everyone happy slurping ramen..
Mouth ~ Oh yeah eveything tastes really good!
Tummy ~ Very Satisfied.
Love these "hole-in-walls". Was able to be seated quickly. Courteous greeting and service. Karaage chicken appetizer was really tasty. Ramen had great broth and good, chewy noodles. Highly recommend.

I've been to several popular ramen spots throughout Las Vegas (and even in LA) and I have to say I still use Fukumimi as the bar by which the other ramen places will be judged. This unassuming little ramen shop sits just outside the busy Strip life where you can relax and enjoy a nice bowl of piping hot tonkotsu ramen topped with their tender and flavorful pork belly chasu and perfectly seasoned nitamago--ask for extra noodles when you find yourself wanting more, trust me you will. Our staple favorites range from the spicy delicious kara-miso ramen to the hearty tantan men ramen. Fukumimi also carries several complementing side dishes such as their juicy and tender chicken karaage as well as the savory agedashi tofu which can only be best described as 'umami'! So if you crave a quick and hearty meal, take a detour off The Strip and make the drive to Fukumimi--you won't be dissappointed.

I'm not a well-traveled, highly-experienced Ramen connoisseur. I've only been to one other Ramen place beside Fukumimi and I liked Fukumimi better, so this is where we like to go. So when my stepfather, the judo sensei/shinto priest who lived in Japan for over 20 years visited and asked where we should go for Ramen, I just hoped Fukumimi would live up to his standard.

We were a party of 5 and had to wait about 15 minutes for a table on a busy Saturday night. It's a little tough to wait in such a crowded front area, but luckily the turnover is really fast, and really, once we sat down to eat it was totally worth it. For an appetizer, we ordered gyoza and the Kimchi. The gyoza were wrapped paper thin, crispy on one side, and piping hot. Delicious. The Kimchi was perfectly spicy and a good portion. 

Almost everyone in our party had something different: the Miso Tonkatsu was creamy and had a light sweetness imparted by the addition of corn, the Salt (Soy) Tonkatsu was a salty, full-bodied soup given added depth with seaweed and green onions, the Spicy Tonkatsu was medium-spicy yet still almost creamy in it's richness, and the large size (sweet) pork bowl with rice and green onions hit the spot for a heartier eater. Oh, and PERFECT eggs and tender pork belly in each bowl, my favorite part. The proteins in these Ramens just melt in your mouth. 

My stepdad said this is as good as any highly regarded Ramen shop in every city he lived in in Japan. He just kept saying "This is SO good!" over and over. He and my mom are in town one more week and he's jonesing for more Fukumimi one of these nights after he plays judo. So thanks for making me look good when I recommended we visit - regardless, this will always be this girl's Ramen joint. 

Arigato gozaimasu!

Personally, it was on point and impressive a few years back when it was the Japanese guy making it. Now it's not him, and not Japanese cooks making it, and the Spicy Miso Ramen is now waaaaay too salty. I never complain and I had to let the server know because it was a little unbearable. I've never cared for ramen till I had a super good one in. Osaka Japan. Few years back it was like that, now it's meh..

Not my favorite ramen place,  but still really good, especially considering there aren't many ramen options on this side of town. Really small dining area, but I've never had to wait for a seat yet.

I like the tonkotsu ramen. They do have my second favorite karaage in town, though (first is Izakaya Go). If you order it to go, make sure you ask for the salt on the side, because they tend to leave it out. Gyoza is good too. They have a stamp card, so make sure you grab one to stamp for each ramen.

Always a great choice! Was packed tonight & everything was spot on! Service, quality not to mention everything came out really fast! Shout out to Lauren for being a proactive host.

Exceptional all around!

In my craving for ramen, we decided to come here due to all of the Yelpers rave reviews. Thank you Yelpers. 

The verdict:
We ordered the miso ramen and the tonkatsu ramen. Overall, it was just ok. It was decent ramen in a bowl, but I just didn't think it was THE BEST ramen ever that I needed to go back to a billion times over.  Broth was flavorful enough, but it was just lacking some sort of umph! I can't put my finger on what exactly was missing though.   We had actually ordered extra noodles just because we knew it wasn't going to be enough noodles and I'm always a hungry hippo. For me it's about the quantity and quality.  It is a little bit on the pricey side, but if your in a rush, around this area and don't want to wait this will be a decent ramen place for you to try.

Came in and asked for thin noodles for my miso ramen after 1 minute of ordering- literally one minute. And they said No. Then, not too long after my order, the ramen came, and the server just mumbled her words, but turns out that they changed my noodles. It was like- why say it so rude when you can just change it that fast.

Also, this particular server definitely had an attitude. I am not sure if it was because i was by myself and i only ordered one portion, but she did not bring any condiments or offer me any refill for my drink. When I was leaving, she just stared at me, no thanks no bye.

The soup itself was okay in the beginning but it got really salty as I went down, but still tasty. Only if it was not close to my work, then I wouldn't really come to this restaurant, but I hope I dont get this server next time I come.

Something has changed at this place where today we came here for our basic ramen on the eastside and found it to be deteriorating. 
Deteriorating in many aspects: service is now unfriendly and she insists the tip of 18% or 20% at payment time, the table wobbles and is annoying while trying to enjoy our downsized portioned ramen, and the establishment appears dirty and neglected. Most of all, the vibe is lacking any friendly spirit and appreciation of regular customers.
Probably won't come back unless it improves its operation.

I recently came to Fukumimi with a friend who has been raving about it for a while. I must say I agree, the ramen in incredible! I tried the spicy tonkotsu ramen and thought it was fabulous. I think this might be my favorite ramen place, just because other places their broth seems so heavy from the pork. My ramen's broth was very flavorful without being overpowering. I also ordered a Sapporo, for $2.90 that's a steal! 

The service is very nice and attentive, and the restaurant is small but clean. Big thumbs up! I will definitely be back soon! It's a great option if you are visiting the Aveda Institute.

2nd time here. Liked it more the second time around. I got the Kara miso spicy. I didn't add anything to it. The charsu was very tender, it's been cooking awhile. It was super red when it came out, thought it was going to be crazy spicy but it was perfect. Actually wasn't spicy at all but had a good chili flavor to it. The bf got fukumimi original, he enjoyed it but it needed some chili. 2 ramens to beers for around $30. Good value!

Well hunmnm the ramen are a little soft or maybe its only my tastesbuds.
Overall price is ok fir a bowl of ramen.

Been there for lunch a handful of times. Tonkatsu ramen was delicious. The broth had layers of flavor. Have the char siu on top. Karaage fried chicken bites are good with a dash of sea salt.  Always crowded never had to wait. Service is good.  Waitress will promptly take your order.

This is the second time I've been here, and have left a happy customer for the second time. The wait staff is super attentive and good arrives quickly. The tonkotsu ramen(salt) is very yummy. Super rich and flavorful. Noodles are cooked perfectly... Not too soggy. The karaage was hot and fresh as always. I will definitely be back

Food was delicious! It's a really cute small place. Their menu is very simple. No desserts. We went during dinner time at 9 PM Friday night. It was packed but we got a seat in less then 5 min. But waiting for our food felt like eternity. Overall, we would definitely be back!
Pretty good ramen, had a great time service was fast and friendly. Had to wait a while but we were a big group so it's understandable. Will definitely go back

I'm not sure how long this place has been around. But it's literally the best ramen place in Vegas so far. I guess you can call it a "hole in the wall" kinda restaurant a area you wouldn't expect a Asian restaurant. Great service awesome Ramen.
Pretty good ramen.   I got tonkatau salt ramen, and added corn.  My girlfriend got chicken ramen.   We also got honey garlic chicken appetizer.

Really good tonkotsu miso ramen, noodles were cooked perfectly. Serving size is fine, maybe a bit small but no complaints. Location is easy to find but I always find it odd eating in a strip mall. Pretty good gyoza, too.

The service was very friendly. We were seated at the closest table to the door and I don't recommend sitting there since every time someone goes in and out you are wafted with a strong blow of cold air (early spring).

The spicy miso ramen was very tasty and had a good spicy kick. I enjoyed the meal however I feel that monta and ramen ya are just as good or better.
Just took my daughter, son in law and grandson for lunch- it was yummy!! Good portions - good price. Great ramen. The Curry is good too!

I've been to a lot of Japanese noodle restaurants here in Vegas and this restaurant by far was the worst.  They don't give you a lot ...there's only one piece of meat & the soup broth is tasteless ........ Try KABUKI at Town Square & you'll like it....

Small yet inviting ramen specialty restaurant. Handful of menu items that wouldn't take you more than 3 mins to choose from. Very flavorful and thick miso soup base. An ideal place for lunch.

I've eaten at countless ramen places including Japan, Korea, Asia, EU and handful of other states in US.

Bowl itself was small but deep. I immediately noticed that ingredients and noodles were drowned in soup when I got my ramen bowl. As I was working on my bowl, I felt disappointment that all noodles were gone with about 7 mouthful. Dont get me wrong, soup base is pretty good 4/5.

For price of average $8ish I felt that it wasn't enough to make me feel full or satisfied, Im a skinny guy. Ratio between ingredients and soup was 1:2.5. I found myself fishing for solids and spent twice longer trying to get myself full by drinking the soup. Extra ingredients were little pricey to add. 

I would have loved it if the ratio was about 1:1.25. Little more generous portion of noodles and ingredients. I actually think that this business will do better if these things improve in the future.

Best wishes.

I just moved to Vegas & was craving ramen. I'm originally for the the Bay (SF, CA) and WOW! I was blown away. The Bay Area has some of the greatest ramen places I've tried (& trust me, I've had a fair share.. From Miami to NY to CA) and they are definitely up to par.

I had the Tonkotsu Miso Ramen ($8.20) and kaarage, which is basically Japanese fried chicken. Super yummy and delicious! I've been here three times so far, and have been greeted with great customer service each time. 

Highly highly recommend for great ramen! :)

I haven't always liked ramen but I must say that I really love this place! I try to come atleast once a month since I work over at the airport and its just a 10min drive. My favs are the fukumimi special and their agedashi tofu? Oh my gaaaaaaaaawd.

Went here with my girlfriend's for a late Saturday lunch and the place was packed. Well it does fill up fast since the seating is very limited so be patient when you go. I ordered a Fukumimi ramen and we shared the honey garlic chicken. I can't remember what my friends ordered but I want to go back to order these again!!!

This is my new go-to ramen house. I am so amazed with the quality of the food and the service. The place is small but it's worth the food. Portion sizes are a little small but I was able to get full off of one bowl. 
The waiters are so friendly and welcoming. I definitely recommend this place to everyone. We will be back!

I am quite amazed at how Fukumimi has impressed me. My friend and I started with their karaage, and wow! It definitely brought back some memories. This is how my aunt's tasted like and if I didn't order ramen I could've ordered more! Now onto the ramen, I ordered Tonkotsu-Shio (salt) and my friend got their miso. I thought there was too much garlic oil on my bowl but it didn't "foul" my ramen so I have no complaints. The noodles here are the thin kind and I'm a big fan of Sora's thick noodles, but as long as the noodles are cooked perfectly it's all good in the neighborhood. Their broth was delicious. It was rich and flavorful. I never finish "drinking" the soup of any noodle bowl (ramen, udon, pho, etc.) but for the first time I finally reached the bottom. I also had a taste of my friend's miso broth and thought that it was pretty tasty as well. So much so that I intend to order miso on my next visit. I'm not a miso fan so this is serious haha! My friend and I were disappointed there wasn't togarashi available. We thought that that was standard condiment to ramen. I'll have to come back several more times to finally decide which one is my favorite ramen-ya. 

ON A SIDE NOTE: I feel like Monta is overrated since it has dominated the ramen scene in Vegas for a long time now. People forget that there are alternatives and other "executions" of ramen, and that die-hard Monta lovers become stagnant in their taste profile (there, I said it). Maybe I'm just feeling this way because the last three times I've been there (within a span of 2 years), my broth was always freaking salty! Even their mini bowls were also salty. But I'm always willing to come back, hoping that they fixed their salt-happy ways and actually make their broth the way it was when they first opened. I miss old Monta!!

Eh, Fukumimi isn't bad. But it doesn't satisfy my craving for ramen. Broth is just OK, and charsiu isn't the best in town. I'd much rather make the drive down to spring mountain to dine at Monta or Sora Ramen. 
It's located in a somewhat sketchy area. I wouldn't come here alone after dark.
On a brighter note, their karrage chicken is bomb. Better than Jinya's. It's hot, juicy, and crispy with just the right amount of fat inside. I'd come back for that. But I'll have to get a taste of the other ramen dishes. Next time I'll give the cold ramen a try.

Love fukumimi! It's been my replacement for monta since they closed their hendo location. I will say they give you way more noodles than other places which is amazing. Only problem is the wait staff, they just aren't the most attentive. It is also a little dirty in there too. But the ramen is always on point.

I did like the chicken karaage and the mini salad that came with it (ps. the dressing on the salad is awesome). However, the ramen wasn't super memorable--the broth was too salty and it's kind of hard to get past that. The menu is somewhat limited to ramen, some appetizers, and drinks.
We were tired of waiting for Monta to reopen in Henderson.... found Fukumimi and it's absolutely amazing!!! Our favorite new spot!! Ramen is delicious, also try the karaage and pork bowl. So good!!
Hole-in-the wall, always get excellent and friendly service, the garlic chicken is awesome.

Really good Ramen in what feels like a very authentic Japanese Restaurant. We enjoyed our soup, only knocked off a star because it wasn't as good as my favorite ramen place in Austin called Michi. Very affordable pricing and a refreshing stop on my visit to Las Vegas. The answer is in the broth.. Go for it!

Solid 4 stars.  Cheap, quick, friendly service, tons of parking.  

For some reason I thought the chicken curry would have a fried chicken cutlet with it, but it is just pieces of chicken in the curry sauce, that was a little disappointing, but not a huge deal.

Shared a bowl of ramen to go along with that and it was tasty.  Definitely give this place a try, it is also inexpensive.

We came here for lunch.  There was no wait and the food was delicious.  Extra ramen is $1.00 which is awesome. Waitresses were friendly and service was pretty quick.  I highly recommend this place for your ramen cravings.

Definitely THE ramen place of town! Hands down my favorite. The broth here is not too salty, but also not too flavorless.

Downside - located on the East side near UNLV, so a bit of the drive for anyone not in that area. Also the venue is quite small so expect to wait if you're going around dinner time (especially on a weekend). Generally speaking, the waits aren't too long. I think the most I ever had to wait was 20~25 minutes but we were a party of 6 in such a teeny place.

Do note this place does include a bar so you have the option to sit there if no tables are available. :)

Onto the food... Well, I've tried just about every ramen plate on this menu that is not labelled spicy and I like each and every one. I personally prefer thin noodles over the thick ones, so you may notice some bias in my favorite dishes (hint: they're all thin noodles). Luckily one of the menus on the table should list out what is thin and what is thick.

My favorite dishes in order:
1. Kogashi - the menu describes this as a fragrant flavored ramen and that is 100% true. Drinking the broth side by side with the other flavors, this ramen broth has a strong flavor which I personally prefer. It is topped with fragrant garlic oil and fried onion. My favorite. If you like garlic-y and onion-y flavors, I bet you this is your favorite too (but trust me, it isn't overpowering and still delish)
2. Tonkotsu - I prefer the soy over the salt one (though the salt one is good too). This is simply but very delicious. Again, I like Fukumimi because unlike other ramen places, the broth is not TOO salty, but at the same time, it still has enough flavor to enjoy!
3. Fukumimi Ramen - they say this is their most popular dish (maybe because it's the name of their restaurant?) Either way, I do like this! 

This place has a stamp card for loyal guests and you are rewarded with free karaage which is Japanese fried chicken (with lemon juice) and it is also very delicious!

Great food at the price.

Ramen was better than average although a bit more salty than we have liked. However, we did order the tonkasu salt ramen.

Fried chicken was good.

Chasu rice bowl was very good.

Server was nice and quick. 

Would go back again!

Thanks!

Respectable ramen in this joint. Service was fast and friendly. They have a customer loyalty punch card which is cool for those that live close by and jones for Ramen regularly. My only complaint was the sewage smell that smacked me in the face as soon as I walked in ( you can't really hold that against them cuz who knows what the deal was) and the obnoxious and loud pop-music playing.  But yes Rhiana, I will shine bright like diamond while I slurp my noodles.

First off i am a die hard Sora ramen fan. So when my wife wanted to go to Fukumimi i was skeptical at first. the place is small and atmosphere was nothing to note....like a typical japanese ramen house. I ordered the spicy miso ramen without reading the description on the menu (my fault). I didnt realize the ramen didnt come with nori and it had corn which im not a fan of in my ramen. The noodle were as good as the noodles at Sora nice and thick perfectly al dente. The spicy miso broth had alittle sweetness to it that i kind of disliked, but it was still delicious. Sora makes a much better spicy miso broth in my opinon. So why did i give them 5 stars you might ask? Their fukumimi ramen ( which my wife ordered ) was friggin delcious! The broth is super hearty and flavorful. I dont know if they have a spicy version of that soup but if they do im there. I highly recommend the fukumimi ramen. When im on the east side of town and i want Ramen Fukumimi's my spot!

Tantanmen and Chashu bowl - 

I ordered the tantanmen and it hit the spot. Not the best broth but still good. Personally it  tasted a tad too peanutty to me, but still something I'd order again. Noodles aren't freshly made but cooked al dente so its ok. What I loved really was their Chashu bowl. Just thinking about it makes me hungry! Awesome service makes it five stars. 

All in all, try the tantanmen and chashu bowl. They won't disappoint. Their tonkotsu ramen is good as well. This place definitely a must-try!

This place always provides decent quality of real Japanese ramen and other appetizers.
And the cost performance I believe is beating anyone in this class of taste!!!  As a Japanese I come here twice in a row which you can sense that this is really good one :-)

After reading a few reviews, I was very excited to try this ramen place on our way back to LA. Arriving sometime in the early afternoon, our group of 7 people were immediately seated in the back. 

The waitress was very nice and the rest of the staff also seemed very friendly. However, I was less than impressed with the food. 

Gyoza: So many people raved about these dumplings in the reviews, I thought it was a must try thing. In my personal opinion, the gyoza was less appetizing than the frozen pot stickers I can purchase from Costco.

Mini Chashiu Bowl: I do not think the meat that topped the rice could even be called meat...let alone pork. The rice also tasted a bit over cooked (soggy). 

Ramen: The broth is good, but nothing worth travelling to. The noodles were mediocre and the only really great thing to rave about in this bowl was the soft boiled egg, and i think it's harder to mess up an egg than it is to make it delicious! 

If you are really close by and there's nothing else you really want, then coming here is OK. But if you are on the fence, I would maybe try for another place. There really wasn't anything that stood out to me here.

YES! finally a Ramen spot on the East Side of Vegas well South East but I'll take it!

Food:
Kara-age (Japanese Fried Chicken): 5/5
Very delicious, it comes with a side of mixed greens with house dressing and grey salt. It actually didn't even need the grey salt because the Karaage was already lightly salted but it was a nice compliment to gourmet salts.   

Fukumimi Miso Ramen: 4/5
LOVED the broth, it was very smooth and flavorful without the super saltiness of Monta (although I still love Monta). If you know me or have read my reviews you know I LIKE IT SPICY. So I drown my soup with sesame oil and Japanese chilli power Togarashi. Their Tamago (egg) was delicious! I just wished they soaked it in the marinade a bit longer, it looked very light but still delicious. The soft boil was perfect and yolky. Their Cashu pork was equally delicious and soft, I just wish they gave you more than just 1 slice but not too much, I felt if I order the extra (3+slices) it would've been too over the top. 

Service: 4/5
It was surprisingly empty when I went around 5pm on a Saturday, but the staff was still very nice and attentive and up beat even if they were slow. Our waitress was very nice and explain our questions very well. Except my table didn't get any straws for our waters and my friend said other tables were given straws. So I have this dislike of drinking water in restaurants from the rim of a cup where multiple people have had their mouths there too. lol

Location: 5/5
Love the location, East Las Vegas needs some Asian flavors. Seriously, its hard to find a sushi restaurant or anything in this area. I say PRIME SPOT! There's no competition. This is place has made it to my top 2 spot but hey if I'm closer to here than Monta. I'd go to Fukumimi.

3rd Ramen house in 10 days and now thinking I have a serious addiction problem. We had the mother-in-law with us, who's been on a strict low sodium diet, so what better way to mess with her than take her to a Ramen house ...pure evil. 
I was intrigued by the Tan Tan Men (I prefer Tan Tan Women...groan, I know). Since starting this Ramen quest of mine, I've started to experiment at home with making my own version of Tan Tan (Wo)Men.
