I was curious how Fukumini's meat compared to Sora's and mine. The flavor profiles of all 3 are very similar with tasting the likeness of Toban Djan (Chili Bean Sauce), sweetness from Mirin and hints of garlic. I think my recipe is pretty close.
Service was excellent and on point. We arrived just before the dinner rush and were seated right away. There was a bit of anxiety on our part during the first few minutes of walking in as the aromas permeating  were quite unpleasant and offensive. But the poopy odor soon dissipated and were replaced by more pleasant cooking bouquets.
We started with an order of GYOZA which was the best I've had. It was well seasoned and something better than any of the dumplings I've had in Chinatown.
The TAN TAN MEN was delicious! Flavorful rich broth that wasn't too salty and thick noodles that had a nice chew to them. My bowl was the envy of everyone at my table who ordered other varieties such as the Classic Ramen in a chicken based broth and the Tonkatsu Soy Ramen. Fortunately for my MIL, they offered a low sodium version of each broth to save her from sporting kankles. My wife who is a picky eater, which is why I suggested the Classic Ramen, wanted to switch with my bowl of Tan Tan Men after tasting it. Being the picky eater, she gives me her Chashu so I thought it would be a win/win situation. We will probably be back sooner than later so she can get her Tan Tan Women.  The Chashu was very tender. My daughter didn't enjoy her Tonkatsu Soy Ramen as much because she said it wasn't as well seasoned, but getting her nana's accidental order of extra Chashu made up for it.
I think Fukumini will be a regular spot for us to hit up on cold nights since it's on our side of town and similar to Ramen Sora. Oishii desu!

Has it really been that long ago?

Time sure does fly looking back at my review for 2013. The food hasn't changed, and is just as great as the first time I stepped into this place. What DID change was the amount of consumers! Their door was partially open and come to find out it was because a bunch of people were squeezed in the enterance waiting to be seated due to the cold weather (yes, it actually gets cold in Vegas). I don't recommend coming with a big group unless you arrive early.

I'm actually glad I had to wait 30 minutes for a table and it's actually the only reason I'm bumping up this review to a 5th star. During the whole time, I got to witness the two awesome waitresses kill it on the ramen floor! Not once did I see them take a break during the rush which was really impressive. The cooks were also on top of everything, making sure the food was coming out at a stead-fast pace. Great teamwork, guys!... and ladies;)

Had to try something new which happened to be Kogashi Ramen for the chilly afternoon. The only way I can describe it is by the char taste it had? It wasn't bad, just different. My date had the Tonkotsu which by far is my favorite right next to Fukumimi itself. Karaage this time around was perfect! I already made my choice to have the Spicy Miso and Honey Garlic Chicken for my next visit since there's only a hundred photos of it uploaded.

Ambience is very clean and on the average side for noise level, so there's no reason for you not to stop by for some great ramen. 

Concerned about the wait??? Call ahead and take your ramen to-go, DUH!

Came here late at night with the brother to satisfy the craving and it was correct!

I got the "Fukumimi special" I believe and it was really good! It's their "whole Sha-bang" ramen in their menu basically. It had the right amount of savoriness and a generous portion of noodles, pork slices and other garnishes. The broth was hella bomb! Definitely lifted my spirits on a cold night. Probably the best ramen in Vegas and I've tried the ones down Spring Mountain.

Okay now you're probably wondering why I gave it 3-stars. The service (at that time) was bullshit. Our Eastern European-ish server chick came off as ICY and didn't care to check up on us. That bitch just sat around doing nothing; she asked another server to  take our orders and she only put them on the table and hinted at us to give HER a tip - have the fuckin' audacity! We just gave her a dolla.

Nonetheless, I'd come here again when I'm in town and craving ramen! :)
Not bad I've been here a few times, only wish they had more chicken Ramen selections. But over all a great Ramen spot

Comfort food!  Nothing better when you're not feeling well than a big bowl of noodles and yummy broth!

Even the picky eater will eat noodles!  

Small small place, but they are so friendly and the good is really good.  

We all tried something different and they were all delicious.
Staff are prompt. The food is absolutely delicious. My favorite is the curry rice and honey garlic chicken.
Being a Hawaiian girl, I gotta have my ramen and this is the place! Noodles remind me of the Sam Satos noodles which are oh so delicious! Spicy Tonkotsu and Spicy Miso my favs so far!
The ramen is amazing here. They offer a stamp card to get free food. Prices around 8 to 10 dollars. Give it a try I think you'll love it

* Customer service: 5/5
The people who work here are very gracious and remember us. Greet and seat immediately, very attentive (periodically check if assistance is needed), and food is served within 15 min..

* Cleanliness: 5/5
Very clean, no matter how busy.

* Food: 5/5
I have been here several times with my BF and we always order the same thing because it's so damn good! I order the Soy Ramen which is a thinner soup base compared to the Miso Ramen. It can be a little salty but nothing too overwhelming. It comes with noodles, a boiled egg, a thin slice of soft char siu pork, a piece of seaweed, and bean sprouts (which I ask for on the side). As for the taste, it is very savory, fresh, and original.

As for my BF, he orders the Tantanmen which is a chile base ramen. I have "tried" it but never really eaten it. He loves it, but from what I have tried, it is a little spicy from the chile, and has a very herby and earthy kind of taste (I think they use sriracha for flavoring). It comes with bok-choy, noodles, a scoop of ground beef, and some other vegetable. You'll definitely want to get a side of rice with this one.

Sodas are served in a can, I don't think there are free refills. Items can also be made to-go.

* Atmosphere, wait-time, and menu size: 4/5
Restaurant is located on Eastern in an older plaza and is right next to a Baskin Robins (which tastes great after eating here, since it can be a little salty). Restaurant is very casual and tiny but even during the busiest hours, I have not had any trouble getting a seat. As for the menu, it is small and very straightforward.

* Portion size and price: 5/5
GREAT price and large portions! Both soups fill us up and cost only $8.99 each.

* Recommend or return?
Of course I will return! They also gave me a punch card for a free item after several visits. Make sure you ask for it.

Though, for those of you who are coming here for the first time and don't have a normal "noodle diet", I recommend taking it easy (don't rush eating). Because, the first time we ate here, it felt as if the noodles formed a rock in our stomach. We were miserable for the entire day and had the sh***. Though we returned for a second time and received a normal experience.

Great restaurant. raman was tasty we ordered a salt based thin donkasu raman. other than a bit salty, it was a great dish after a long drive. the generous portioned fried chicken was juicy and fresh and it came with some fresh salad topped with house sauce(super yummy), the chasiu bowl with generous toppings smelled heavenly, and tasted like a mouth full of jamming flavors layering on top of each other. service was straightforward and pleasant. the popular raman look a tab longer but the other speedy dishes made it up for our hungry souls. at the end of the meal, the check came out $16, wow it blows my mind how great of quality they are able to maintain for the little profit. very happy, we will be back!

Craving ramen on a cold night so this was the closest place from where I was from yelp. Wait time was pretty long because it's such a small restaurant but it was really good. I got the tonkatsu miso ramen, the house salad, gyoza & the honey garlic chicken

Price was really reasonable for all we got/portion sizes & everything I would say was a great experience plus the 2 female servers were nice

Returned to fukumimi ramen after a long break, and reminded of why I don't love it as much as my go to spot. 

The good:
1. we got a table right away, which is great for a Saturday night. 
2. Also they have a stamp card; every 4 ramens you earn yourself a free appetizer when you come back. 
3. Staff is very friendly and quick to help you out 

The bad:
1. We got the miso ramen with pork, and thick noodles. Problem is...it just doesnt taste as good as monta chaya.
2. You pay more, 8.20 (fukumimi) vs 6.95 (monta) the thing is, you do get more toppings but you get less noodles. So you get a half an egg, and a scoop of corn, that you would pay extra for if you wanted it at the other place.

We will come back, but probably only when we're in a hurry and don't want to wait.
Awesome authentic Japanese ramen me and my family love it!!! Fukumimi ramen is one of the best!!!

I don't want to write too good as it may be too crowded soon after everybody notices. But this ramen shop is superb and they would be even successful if they were located in Japan.

Soup was one of the best I ever had, and the noodles were ideally boiled to coordinate with the soup.

I wonder how they did it....

Omg a Ramen place near the airport! I love it!  Trying out the Fukumimi Ramen since it has extra pork Chasu.  I always order extra Chasu anyway, so this one suits me perfect.  The broth, wow so very favorful and delicious.  

The Fukumimi Ramen was just the right portion for tiny little me that chows down OOdles of noodles.  Fukumimi Ramen already had the extra Chasu, 3 pieces of seaweed, sprouts, hard boiled egg, and lots of green onions...other places you have to order all the extra trimmings.  BONUS, you still can get more if it doesn't meet your expectations.  Top it off with some Kim Chee, oh wow that was yum.   

I found myself diving in pretty quickly and demolishing it in minutes, that I still have that some what hot feeling on my tongue that I ate too fast.  LOL.  I like to portion out my meat with my noodles and I had more than enough meat along with my noodles so I was a very satisfied girl.  

I saw the waitress delivering Karaage to other tables, when I bring my other half, I'll get all the other things on the menu.  I do like to taste everything, but don't like to waste, so he is my partner in crime to balance out my need to try it all!

This place does seem to get busy, but if it does, I'm sure people will be in and out in no time, kind of like me, haha.  I did come in here by myself.  This place is a lot larger and roomier than Monta.  Same ambience like other Ramen shops. 

Yelpers, this is a must try!

Before today, I didn't get it.
My idea of ramen was of the six cent variety.
When I went to Japan this year, I knew to avoid Ramen because it was pork-based, and I never went to Monta or Sora because I was told the point of ramen is pork broth.
As everyone would guess, my inability to try a tasty Japanese dish is rather difficult.  I just assumed it was noodles and broth with lots of sodium.  However, upon learning Fukumimi had chicken ramen, I knew I could finally taste what the excitement is all about.
After proctoring the LSAT today, I worked up quite an appetite and headed over to Fukumimi.  I ordered the chicken ramen and not long after, the chef brought out to me a steaming bowl.
The bowl was a huge amount, with broth, noodles, chicken "chasiu", bean sprouts, negi (green onions), and a half egg.  This chicken broth would make a Jewish grandmother's toes curl!  It was sooooo flavorful.  I have had my chicken soup training (my aunt told me it would make me marriageable) but mine does not have this richness.
The broth itself is a star, but with the noodles, sliced chicken, green onions, sprouts, and the soy-soft boiled egg, it is truly a great balanced meal.  The noodles were the perfect texture, and I added some shichimi to add some spice to the bowl.
I saved the egg for the end, and it was perfectly cooked.  I love eggs like this!  This was truly OISHI!  The chef told me he is from Kyoto, so we talked about Kyoto and I showed him a few pictures from when I visited this May.
Chicken ramen with tax is only $8.11.  If you are like me and prefer that pigs fly rather than sizzle, this is the only spot in town to indulge in ramen.  The restaurant itself is quaint and clean, the staff is very friendly, and the food is yum (though my options are limited!) - they gave me a stamp card so for every 4 bowls of ramen I buy, I get a free kara-age (or you pork eaters get a free gyoza).
Now that I had it "as is" I can add corn and seaweed to it when I am a tad hungrier :)

The miso ramen soup was delicious.  the honey glazed chicken appetizer was the best.  I love the atmosphere at this place, it's small and casual dining experience. hope this helps you choose this fabulous place!

I have tried many ramen places in Vegas and this is by far the best one. They get the broth just right and the noodles are never undercooked or over cooked. Although the portions are not as big as I would like, they offer many delicious appetizers to start you off. 

The place is always busy so if you come during dinner/weekends/holidays expect a wait. The food is definitely worth it. They also have a stamp card where every 5 ramen gets a free appetizer. Once you try this place you will definitely be coming back.

Definitely recommend this place. First time walked in and was greeted with sincerity. Not the fanciest looking place but im more attracted to the food and service. I will definitely be back to try more of their menu.

First time eating here and got diarrhea. The chicken karaage was piping hot but for some reason it was slightly pink when I bit into it. I was hungry and by the time I noticed it my swallowing reflex already kicked in. So I finished the other pieces too since I already ate one so damage was done. BAD IDEA. Had stomach cramp that afternoon and continuous diarrhea all morning the next day. Not a pleasant experience. Not coming back because i don't think their ramen is that great either. Also halfway through the meal a delivery guy came in with boxes of produce and just walked straight through the middle of the restaurant to the back. Usually you'd think the kitchen would be connected to the outside so they can drop off delivery without going through the restaurant for everyone to see.

Once again back to back days this place is that good my peeps. Trust me ;) the age dash tofu is a must and the honey garlic chicken you won't want to share with anyone. I got the tonkatsu-salt and WOW. Come and the Ramen will satisfy!

Solid Ramen option on the east side. Very small, so it can fill up quickly. Wish the KARAAGE was more crisp, but it was very juicy. The pork and soup base just doesn't have the punch of Ramen Sora on the west side.

I got a to-go order of tori ramen with corn and a side of gyoza. Everything was very hot, fresh, and very affordable. I have to say my favorite part was the gyoza because not only were they moist, but I got more than four. I've never been somewhere that gives more than 4 gyoza, and that alone makes me want to come back!

Awesome place to eat, never fails. Food is great. This place is always busy. 
The thin ramen bowl with pork is a must have. Garlic chicken for an app is perfect to share.

If you are a big fan of Monta or Ramen Sora, this place doesn't quite meet your expectations. Everything from the food to service was average or needed a lot of work. Needless to say, if you live on the east side of town I definitely respect the practicality of frequenting this place to have your ramen fix, but I'd say the trip to Monta or Ramen Sora will be worth it in the end.

2 stars for food. Probably the best ramen in town. But the waitresses are extremely disrespectful. They would be so nice and sweet to you but will talk behind your back in Thai expecting no one to understand but we did. When we were eating they said "these people are not gunna tip because they're young" and after they fill another table's water they said "this bitch asked for water but didn't drink it, I hate these type of guests so much". Then they gave us the bill when we were half way done with our food and rush us to pay and complain about how we still haven't paid even though we weren't done eating. I hope the owner reevaluates the type of employees they hire.
Very inexpensive and also super awesome.  Got some kimchi and gyoza and some ramen and some pork bowl w my girlfriend and we loved it.
Chashu bowl was delicious and the Karaage was some of the most tender and flavorful I've ever had.

I don't know if it was because I came here on a gloomy rainy day and this steaming bowl of goodness just blew my mind or if it was just good, but i do know this place left an impression.

i ordered the fukumimi ramen and it came out perfect and was everything my life ever wanted.  I normally complain about the temperature when i eat ramen but this place made it nice n steamy.  The broth was rich and was packed with porky deliciousness. 

They have other options and this place is definitely worth coming back to.
Very unassuming restaurant, in a deserted strip mall with lots of shady characters all around but that's what makes it fun. Food was pretty decent and service was good will be back.
Right next to the airport, I always make this a pit stop to warm the empty stomach before the trip back home. Super flavorful broth.
Good ramen, cozy ambience and friendly service. Price can't be beat. Cool little place.
I love this Ramen house. I recommend eating in. If you order out, make sure you get extra noodles!

I want to give this place a 5 star rating FOR THE FOOD because I would highly recommend going here; however, if I could go below 1 star for the customer service, that would be the rating. I'm not upset that the food wasn't given to the right people on the table and of course an honest communication error was made by getting the wrong bowl of ramen that belonged to another person on the table (how would we know when we don't understand the server clearly and the food sound and look similar as well). I wouldn't feel right for eating or even paying for something I didn't pay for so I informed the server about getting the wrong bowl of ramen, but instead I get a rude response saying that I should've traded bowls with my friend who's already halfway done with the bowl that should've been mine and when I said that I didn't want the bowl, the servers gave us a hard time about still paying for the bowl we didn't want to eat and also saying that we should've known what we ordered. YES WE KNEW WHAT WE ORDERED BUT WHEN YOURE GIVING ALL THE FOOD OUT AT THE SAME TIME IT WOULD HELP TO BE MORE CLEAR ABOUT WHAT YOURE GIVING OUT! On top of all this, we were never checked up on or giving refills on our drinks, or even a thank you. Long story short, I'm not asking to get free food but I just wanted the right bowl of ramen I came for.

I've waited a bit to post this review...and skipped on chances to go back. My one and only visit was on a Saturday morning...and I was there right when they opened the doors. Parking is great and at that time of morning there was no line...although the place did fill up fast. 

I sat at the counter and had a great view of the kitchen which can be a double edged sword. While the kitchen was clean and the staff worked well together, things started to sour for me when I saw a box of Sysco produce come out of the back. I know Sysco supplies a lot of the businesses in the valley but this just turned me off. After watching the kitchen for a bit my bowl of "spicy" fukumimi ramen finally arrived. 

For a dish that was supposed to be spicy I reached for the spices a lot. And the charsiu....was ok, but not as good as other places I've had around town. The broth was good, but yet I've had better. Long story short for the East side....this is passable. But it's not all that. 

Let's be blunt. Ramen Sora smokes this place. And while Monta is a bit of a drive for me and Fukumimi will do in a pinch when I can't get to Monta...the fact is Monta kicks their derriere all over the place and still stands supreme as the best bowl of ramen I've had yet. 

I will go back and try Tetsuro's Tan Tan Men recommendation but for now...it's good...but not great. I'm giving Fukumimi a 3 Star reality check.
This is one of my favorite ramen places and their gyoza is really good and doesnt feel all flour. I miss this place a lot.

So there are tons of Ramen Noodle Houses in the Las Vegas area but Fukumimi is the best in town (hands down!)

I'm going to keep it simple:
-Best Broth
-Kid Friendly
-Great Service
-Best Chicken Karaage w/ salt

YUM YUM YUM!

This place has pretty good ramen and small bites. Definitely one of the better ramen spots in Las Vegas. 

Their honey ginger chicken appetizer is so good! And it's free after your 4th purchase (or there's also other appetizers.)
The spicy tonkatsu definitely had a kick. Regular tonkatsu is a good go to. It did seem a little creamier and less pork-tasting than I'm used to though. 
I like the thick noodles that they use, haven't tried the thin. They don't give you that much, though. Their onsen egg is good, but you can tell its prepared and not cooked fresh. The toppings are a little underwhelming too. I don't remember there being the usual green onions or bamboo shoots that most ramen places put in. 
I think I would've left still hungry if it wasn't for the appetizer. 

Thumbs up for the service, prices, and flavor. But thumbs down for the small portion sizes.

I entered the "ramen game" a lot later than everyone else because having eaten so many ramen and noodle/soup dishes in my childhood, I was not excited. I heard ALL the buzz about the major players and decided I finally needed to give them all a whirl for my own Battle Ramen.

Fukumimi was my second stop of the three. My fianc (who is a HUGE fan of ramen!) and I came for dinner and had amazing timing - no wait and we got a table next to the window. I ordered the Tantan Men (Szechwan style spicy W soup of pork and chicken, with sesame sauce and red chili oil, topped with seasoned ground meat and bok choy) and Ruben ordered the Spicy Miso Ramen. We also ordered a side of Curry Rice (small) and Gyoza.

Our verdicts? Meh. Everything was good, but not as good as other ramens we enjoyed in town. I like the Tantan Men's unique flavor and depth, but I didn't love it over other Tonkotsu and Miso broths I've had. It was also the first time I couldn't finish my bowl. Ruben preferred the noodles and broth of other ramen shops. He also didn't think it was spicy enough (the guy has a stomach of steel). The curry was good; reminded me of the Japanese curry I ate back home (Hawaii). The gyoza was tasty too and I loved their dipping sauce.

For both of us, this is our last choice compared to Monta and Sora. We also determined that it was definitely a preference, not the quality or taste of the individual ramen shops. Even both of us like different ramen. What we could agree on was that we didn't like the noodles here (I like the thicker, wavy noodles with more bite).

My husband and I have made this place are weekend spot. Food is amazing, try the goyza. They are a little piece of heaven. Staff is really nice, and kitchen is quick. Defiantly the place for ramen. Thank you for making our Saturdays that much better.
First time there, and wonderful service! Our waitress answered all of my questions. Food was so delicious! And the presentation was beautiful!

I think this is the only Ramen restaurant on the East side of Las Vegas. Fortunately for the east siders (like me) this place is great.

I've been to plenty of other Ramen places on the west side and California, and I can tell you Fukumimi is one of the best so have ever been to for the price. A party of two will struggle to get a bill over $30 here. This is one of my favorite places to eat when I'm watching my wallet.

They have appetizers that range from $2 to $5 (that's really the most expensive, $5...). They make their on Kimchi and I love the Kimchi tofu, which is only $4. I also love their house salad, which is nothing more than greens with their house ginger dressing. My wife has to get it every time, as it is a simple and delicious salad for only $2.

They also have rice bowls, which are their only other entree options besides the Ramen bowls. We've had a few of them before and they are good, though they don't blow me away. The curry bowl is my favorite, though I have had better Japanese curry. None of the bowls will probably disappoint you, but I would stick to the Ramen.

The Ramen ranges in price from $7 to $9, which are pretty decent prices given the portion size. They have all the typical tonkotsu Ramens as well as chicken Ramen. They also have Tantan Men, which is a spicy peanutty broth with ground pork. Not every Ramen spot had this dish, but it is well worth trying if the description above sounds good to you. The Tantan Men is my favorite and seems to be very popular here. They also offer quite a few extras like extra meat, noodles or veggies (see the menu, I took a pic).

Oh, and they have $2 dollar Miller lights! And that's not just a happy hour special that's all the time. Most bars in town don't sell domestic beer that cheap. Though don't get me wrong, this isn't really a drinking spot. They only have a few beers and nothing stinger. Though it is a bargain price for a beer at a restaurant.

Not much in the way of dessert here. Though there is a Baskin Robins next door.

Where else can you go, get two beers, a salad, an appetizer and two entries for $26. That was our last bill here, and we were stuffed with delicious food. If you want  to eat well on the cheap, this place is a gem.

I ate here for dinner with my girlfriend. First of all, I'm not a ramen critic and I don't know what technically good ramen is. I just go by taste. 

All I can say is: it wasn't bad. It wasn't the best ramen I've had, but I enjoyed what I was eating. 

Taste: the broth was okay. Wasn't anything special. I had the tonkotsu ramen (salt). It was okay, didn't have a whole of flavor. My girlfriend has the tonkotsu ramen (spicy), she thought it was pretty spicy. I had a taste and I didn't think it was that spicy or had that much flavor. 

Service: the staff were very friendly. Nothing to complain about.

Overall: I would say if you are in the area and want some ramen without having to drive far, then come here. If you want the best (in my opinion) go to Monta in Chinatown or Henderson.

Having spent a few years in Japan roaming the streets looking for good eats. Ramen houses were always the best with no need for trying to understand the kanji menus as a rockie. When I came across this place serving tan tan mein noodles I went bizarre about wanting to try some. I came during lunch time on a weekday and it was pretty packed so I took that as a great sign. The place is on the smaller side but it made me feel at home in Japan even with the modern design. I sat on a tiny two person table towards the wall. When the nice pretty asian lady came to take my order it was a big dissapointment from the start. I was in the middle of ordering and the table next to me began speaking to her in her native tongue and she straight up left me with the words in my mouth to get them sodas. Kind of rude I would say! I asked for an order of gioza and they told me they did not have any! WHAT? Why have it on the menu if you do not serve it, let alone carry it? You can not eat ramen and not accompany it with gioza! So I ordered tan tan mein noodles with much anticipation. When my bowl arrived, the bowl looked liked they had poured milk in it. The noodles were creamy?!?! Real tan tan mein noodles are composed of a spicy broth not a spicy milky broth like if it was curry. I understand there are many versions on how to make tan tan mein but this one was wayyyyy too creamy The ground pork was alright but it did not have great consistency, it was a bit like sand in my opinion. I'm on a tan tan mein fix so if anyone knows of a better place, please do tell.

Must have been faith for me to find this place. I woke up craving ramen looks on Yelp and this place was a good 10mins away. Not much on the menu to choose from... Pretty simple which I like. I order the tantan men because I seen someone on Yelp mention it.. and I'm glad I did... The ramen is so damn good... And the appitzer rice with curry is good enough to just order that alone. I will be making this a regular spot... Especially after a long night of drinking

All my friends have raved about it and I'd say their options of thick versus think noodles along with the different broth options are unique. I do love the creativity and the twists in broths so expect to be surprised! 

I would give this place more of a 3.5 to be honest as I wasn't exactly a fan of the broth I had. Something felt like it was missing.

I had the spicy tonkstsu ramen and maybe the spicy was overkill to the point I could not appreciate the broth itself or what I was eating. It's not that it was too spicy, just it masked all the other flavors of my ramen. Could be causing why I'm not giving the 5.

Noodles - definitely fresh and perfectly chewy so that's good! Next time I'll be back to try the thin noodles as the thick ones are a bit overwhelming as well.

Either way it does warrant another visit to verify but I do believe in first impressions.

Things to look out for:
They do get lines like monta so if you can come early do. 

No reservations 

It's in a shady part of the city in a near empty plaza. Their sign didn't turn on for me so I had trouble finding it. By the way it's next to the ice cream shop on the side of the grocery store!

So I've been going to this place for a while. Now it's the only Ramen restaurant I go to now. I usually get the Spicy Tonkotsu. On the downside it's a pretty small restaurant and they do get busy at times but the wait times aren't that long.
The place is a hole in the wall, but all of their food is delicious. I would definitely recommend this to anyone who want to try something different!!!

This vegas ramen hit the spot. It's out of the Vegas strip but definitely taste better than a lot of on the strip foods

Prices are typical ramen spot prices. But this is one of my faves I have tried.

Worth the drive. Some wait. Delicious
Tried this place while on biz trip.  Food quality is decent, price is reasonable and service is good.  I would come back again for light and quick dinner.

Today's visit was my first time here... I ordered the Tantan Men with the honey garlic chicken...I wasn't sure what the white stuff drizzled on top of the chicken was... When I found out it was mayonnaise I quickly told them not to put any (yuck). When the food came out, I was pleasantly surprised with how good and tender chicken was... I'll come back just for this dish alone. The ramen noodles were okay... The broth and spices were delish... I found myself ignoring the noodles and just drinking the broth. They charge extra if you want them to prepare it spicier than normal... They charge extra for just about everything (even water)...the service was okay, I was greeted when I walked in, everyone was nice... That's kind of where it stopped. I had to flag the waitress down each time I need something, I was never checked on during my meal. Overall, everything was pretty good. If I come back, it'll be to-go only...

Ramen on a 110 Vegas Summer Day and a misty humid evening I'm not prejudice to year long ramen. And I've hit up almost every spot here but there's always something that I'm not jumping to come back to however I think Fukimimi might be the exception. I've only been here twice but everything I tried has been good. Agedashi tofu, Fukimimi ramen, honey garlic chicken-very Japanese style so don't assume, karaage, chicken ramen and gyoza. Yes I've tried almost there entire menu LOL. I hope they add apple juice to the menu for the children and expand possibly as it's even smaller than most already small ramen spots!

Not sure how the Ramen taste, sure hope it's better than the Kimchi they serve... I ordered a  Kimchi bowl and it literally had two bites of kimchi on top of a little bed of rice. The Kimchi was the worst tasting Kimchi Iv'e ever had. Took one bite and tossed it. So disappointing.

Not bad, but I wasn't very impressed with my meal here. With other ramen options in Vegas, I don't think I would bother going here again. I'm sad to say that since I really wanted to like this place. Maybe I'm too picky about my ramen, I don't know. I guess I've just been to many other ramen places and really enjoyed my meals there.

The service was good, no complaints there. The place has a cute wooden interior and is clean.

I only had one bad experience there where they served me bad chicken curry.  Other than that, the several times I've been there the service is great and the food is delicious! My brother who lived in Japan said the ramen is authentic and reminded him of being back there.

I actually prefer this place over the ever so popular monta. It's always either fukumimi or jinya that I go to. If I'm feeling hungrier than usual, I always get the Fukumimi Ramen. It comes with bean sprouts, 3 pieces of seaweed, extra pieces of chashu, green onions, half an egg, and thin noodles. Price point wise, I think you get more for your money at this place than other shops. There's usually always a wait for this if you go around 7p so get there at 6 if I don't want to wait, but it does go by fairly fast. Try the gyoza and the agedashi tofu. They also have the best stamp system I've seen. 4 bowls of ramen and bam! You get a free appetizer. Pretty simple to achieve... I just never remember to bring my stamp card or I lose it. This restaurant is in the most random plaza next to nothing basically and tgey still get busy. That's when you know the place is good.

Strip mall whattttt.  So people trolling the storefront but once inside a legit Japanese noodle house. Warm clean and inviting.   Staff was humble menu was easy to understand good options just wish menu had traditional pictures.   I ordered the Miso ramen and my only complaint I could have scarfed down ten pounds of that Pork.   Price met value and a my only complaint its small so watch what you say your neighbors can hear you haha.  Will be back.
Definitely the best raven I've ever had in the U.S. The soup is extremely rich and has so much flavor. Highly recommend this place.

Two stars based on comparison to other ramen bars we've been to.  Its a cute little neighborhood noodle house, but the soup was just barely passing. The soup was very basic. Nothing special.  Not gross or inedible...just nothing special.  Would i come back....nah.  Id rather stick to Monta Chaya or Jinya.

WOW, best tantanmen and karaage in town!! small little place in a old plaza, next to baskin N robbins ice cream place. Real authentic japanese ramen is found here. Price is fair and food is obliviously good. I try to come here every week but its a little far distance from my place, but if it was close by, I would be heading there every DAY!!!!

Ordered the miso ramen. The service was speedy. The broth was seasoned perfectly. The noodles were not to soft or to firm. I forgot to add an egg. The prices are decent. The only thing I would change about this place is leasing a bigger building.

My boyfriend wanted a simple soupy dinner before heading to the airport and we found this spot off-strip for a decent price. My ramen was $8.20 which is reasonably priced. We waited around 10 minutes before we got seated since i was dinner time, they were started to get packed. We got seated and was ready to order our Kogashi & Fukumimi ramen. My garlic oil broth was super rich in and the thin noodles were deliciously paired with the flavorful chashu  and fried garlic pieces. The egg was a bit on the saltier end, but still good. My boyfriend also liked his ramen, too, so this spot is definitely solid. I wanted hot tea since it was windy and cold out today, but unfortunately, they only sell cold drinks. Would recommend if you want a solid ramen meal.

This may just be the East Coast talking, but I've not had better ramen than this before. I had a hankering for. Ramen because I've got the sniffles and was in Las Vegas for work. A quick Yelp search and flat tire later, I finally found them. The guy behind the counter was gracefully trying to remove a belligerent vagrant as I entered the place. He could have been mean, as she was swearing up a storm, but he was calm and kind, which really made a good impression on me. 

But vagrant relations was not the purpose of my visit, so on to the food!  I had the karaage (Japanese fried chicken bits - $3.90) and tantan men (pork, miso, and sesame paste ramen $8.95). Both were superb, and the price was right. 

My craving satisfied and with no angry homeless people blocking my exit, I left a happy customer.

My friend recommended me to Fukumimi and I was really excited to try their ramen! But all of their base was Tonkotsu, and it was mixed with an additional flavor such as soy (shoyu), miso, salt (shio) etc., so it didn't really have a solid flavor. I ordered the Tonkotsu Miso Ramen, and I wasn't quite sure what the main flavor was, it was just all jumbled up together. 

We also ordered appetizers, the Gyoza & the chicken karaage. I absolutely love karaage and was super excited to try them! But they were EXTREMELY salty, and after one bite, I drank more than half of the water that I had. It was so salty, that when I ate my ramen after, all I got was salt flavor. My tongue was still burning after I got home, and I had to drink several more bottles of water to get rid of that burn I had. It was so painful I never wanted to eat karaage again. 

The waiters were okay, they never asked us how we were or anything, but weren't rude or mean. Just not very friendly? I'm really disappointed with Fukumimi and I will probably never come here again.
I love this place, come here almost weekly from Boulder City for the salad and the agedashi tofu  best ramen place I've been to so far!

Went to Fukumimi on lunch with some friends, after having been converted to the delicious joys of ramen by Monta earlier this winter. While I can't say I like Fukumimi quite as much as Monta, it's wonderful delicious ramen very fast.

Pros: Unlike Monta, the wait is maybe 5 minutes as opposed to 45.
- Prices are very very reasonable, you can be full and happy for less than $10
- Seriously delicious toppings, and most of their ramen comes with them already added, so you don't need to look like a confused white person quite as much.

Cons: Something about the thinner, firmer noodles compared to Monta just wasnt as enjoyable.
- Almost a little too salty broth

Either way, will definitely be coming back here again when I'm out towards Henderson and once it's winter once more.

Pros: closer to my house than china town

Cons: a little salty, only one type of noodle(thin), kind of expensive for the portion, and they don't have gyoza!

Great food, but for the third time, they have brought out only one of our orders and say that they didn't know that we ordered two things...why would I watch the other person eat lol. We've changed the way we order too just in case it was our fault and they might've not heard us, but alas, it happened a third time. On the verge of losing some regular customers. Get it together please. I used to love recommending this place to people.

Update: our friends said that on their last visit, the chicken that was served was raw..

After seeing so many great reviews and hearing great things about Fukumimi, my bf and I decided to give it a try. Ramen is one of our favorite dishes and we are always up for trying new places. We thought that maybe we would be able to find a new ramen spot. When we first looked at the menu we were surprised by the low prices, the lowest we've seen. Especially with it coming with corn and chashu?! We thought that was awesome. I ordered the Tonkatsu, miso ramen with nori (which our server didn't refer to as nori and seemed a bit confused until she realized it was seaweed). 

After a short wait, and being served I realized why the prices were so low. The bowls are really small and they actually don't have much food in them at all. After my first sip of the broth, I was sadly let down. There was almost no flavor. In my entire bowl I maybe had about 10 kernels of corn and 1 piece of chashu. I wish I had known. I would've asked for extra and paid for the extra. My bf ordered the Kara-miso, spicy miso ramen and he was so disappointed. The broth tasted like hot sauce. He ordered the chashu bowl as well and was honestly more excited about that.

After finishing our food, we awkwardly waited for about 15 minutes for someone to come back and bring us our check. The new server even took the couple's order next to us, ignored me, took care of two other tables before she acknowledged me and brought us our check. 

There is honestly nothing special here. The ramen tastes instant and I really hope the ramen in Japan has something better to offer than this place. We left feeling very unsatisfied.

*SUPER* SMALL PORTIONS
ZERO SPICINESS

I'm really unhappy with my meal here. 

First I ordered the tan tan men. The menu said that it was spicy. It was NOT, so I asked for spicy sauce. The waitress gave me some chilli flakes that had zero spice. Then I ordered chilli PASTE. The paste wasn't spicy either! It was pretty much gochujang and just made my soup sweeter. :/

I literally finished the noodles in under 5 minutes!! I got a few small bites out of the bowl and then I was done. I was so shocked! 

I ordered another bowl because I wasn't even full yet.(I don't even eat that much btw)

Then I got the "spicy" miso. It was not spicy either....!! The egg and the pork were good, the broth sucked! So I hurried and ate it and got out of there. 

I spent $20 to get full and I'm a small girl with a small appetite. 
Oh and guess what? They charged me .50 for that 'spicy' paste. 

What a joke..

Still consistently amazing. I bring all my visitors here for something new. No complaints, was a hit by all friends who never had real Ramen before....and no the little cheap salty  processed Ramen packs from grocery are nowhere near the same. If that is what you think, then you need to visit Fukumimi.

Noodles were inconsistent quality. Half well cooked while half little cooked. 

My first time here, my last time here. Never back

Wow, just wow. There were so many wrong things about this ramen. Compared to LA, this just falls really short. Hadn't eaten ramen in a while since I've moved here from LA. Thought this place would be a good place to try cuz of the good reviews. I ordered the spicy signature ramen. First of all, for the price, the bowl was too small and the portions were too small. This is coming from a girl....Seriously, only one slice of pork? Didn't know pork was so expensive...? They're wasn't any ginger or chili oil.  I ordered spicy...but to me it was just plain salty. Is that normal? The quality of the ramen noodles was also very disappointing. It tasted and looked like instant noodles you buy from the market. I can only hope the other ramen places here in Vegas are better than this.

Got the Kogashi ramen. Omigurd...so garlicky and savory. I will definitely be back to try other flavors. Plenty of noodles and just the right amount of meat, green onions, and half a hard boiled egg. Too much for me to finish in one sitting, but I'm weird. 

The service was perfunctory. Neither bad nor great. The restaurant must have been a sushi bar in its past life, because that's how it's set up. Small, no frills, not many decorations or much character. They have loud 90s pop overpowering conversations, with a completely different station blasting from the kitchen, making a disconcerting stereo effect that makes you dizzy.

The ramen alone, however, is enough to bring me back. I'll order to go next time.

Came here on a Saturday night with my man friend and were pleasantly surprised at the emptiness of the restaurant.. ( I really hate waiting.. who doesn't?) Any who.. we already knew what we wanted to get before coming here.. 

Karaage _ Like everyone has already said.. It is delish!!! Crispy but not oily~ good portion too~!

Fukumimi ramen_ i asked to add some garlic oil to it but I don't know if that even made a difference. I thought it was pretty tasty.. Pretty rich but not TOO porky.. and not overly salty like Monta's ... & Noodles were cooked perfectly.

Tan Tan Men_ It was my first time trying this dish and I thought it was pretty good.. It had some sort of deep nutty flavor to it.. I don't really like nuts that much LOL so i was good just stealing a couple bites from my bf~ 

Kimchi_ my BF really liked their kimchi haha it is more of the fresher variety so it didn't have that fermented sour taste that I like.. 

Nice waitresses & chefs, fast service! Check it out if you're in the area ;]]]

I was deserately craving ramen (as per usual) and decided to give this place a shot since I had heard such great things and had yet to try it.  First of all, the people who work there are so cute and sweet!!  It was a Wednesday night and the restaurant was pretty empty.  It's set up very similar to the other ramen joints: small, with wooden tables and some bar seating.  I got seated right away and ordered the Fukumimi Ramen, which says it come with extra chasyu and nitamago.  The serving was huge and it was absolutely delicious.  The broth was heavenly and just the right amount of saltiness and porkiness.  It didn't taste heavy at all.  The noodles were also perfectly cooked.  The Chasyu was melt in your mouth tender.  The only thing that was surprising was that I only got one half of an egg since I thought the Fukumimi Ramen came with extra egg.  

I also ordered the karaage chicken which I thought were just okay.  It's more like chicken breast rather than chicken wings.  Maybe I waited too long to eat them because they weren't all that crunchy on the outside and a tad bit oily.

I would say that this is right up there with Sora.  I haven't been to Sora for at least a month now so I will have to go back soon so I can make a valid comparison.

Service was great! Very nice workers and the food was pretty good. I love ramen and the food quality wasn't the best I have had but I'd definitely go back!! If you're on the side of town definitely go there but I really struggled finding it!

Thank you fellow yelpers for guiding us here. Streamlined menu with a good assortment of dishes and appetizers. Limited seating, fast and efficient service and it looks like they do a solid take out business. We enjoyed what we ordered and got a punch card for our return visit.
Very nice ramen spot. Good apps (karababe) and great ramen. Wife does the original with thick noodles and I always get the spicy miso one so good. Highly recommend

This place was initially hard to find almost look like a hole in the wall. The quality of food was great. the servers were courteous and I cannot believe how reasonable they're pricing was. Definetly recommend.

A great find, thanks all you yelpers!  Just wish it was not in a dying strip mall......

Thanks all you yelpers for helping me find one of my favorite and recent noodle places.  Reviews from Judd L, Nelson Q and Lisa R were making my pavlovian response take over and we went there on Sunday afternoon about 1:30 pm on a New Year weekend. Would have been perfect if the tour bus of people weren't there occupying the whole place....

1.  Ambiance - Small, perhaps it can seat about 35 people using all seats and  counter area.  Clean, small waiting place, open kitchen

2. Bathroom - You know how I am about asian restaurants (usually chinese) with good food and terribly awful bathrooms. Well this place is elegant.... Gotta have nice toilet ambiance to really relax....

3.  Service - I really like going to a noodle place and not everyone is yelling Irashaimasu so loud that I feel like I am at Disneyland.  The staff is very nice, efficient, pleasant, well mannered, attentive, japanese speaking.

4.  Food 

Karaage - Oh this is a delicate and tender morsel of chicken.  Steaming hot, incredibly tasty.  It does not get better than this.

Edamame - Traditional with your basic salt and not all the fancy stuff like other places. This is just right to whet your appetite.

Chicken Bowl - If you are not liking or feeling like slurping, then this is it. I would probably have ordered the Chicken Curry Rice Bowl, as this one looked tasty but a bit sparse.  The wifey ordered it and we were all just getting over colds, so really did not share.

Fukumimi Ramen - A bit of pork belly, tonkotsu, egg, seaweed, very tasty and very nice broth. The broth was not over powering and was very simple but tasty.

TanTan Ramen - Interesting. Not too spicy, a more complex broth and a bit over powering. I prefered the delicate and light broth of the Fukumimi Ramen.

Miso Ramen - Tonkotsu with the miso sause.  My daughter liked it and she is quit the critic, so this must have been good.

GK says, check this place out.  Do not go during main eating hours as it is small and crowded.
The special of the house Fukumimi Ramen was just like I remembered from visiting Kyuushu in Japan.  Very authentic!  Oishikatta!

After a tip from my fellow nihonshoku reviewer, I went there on my scouting trip. 

The ramen here is interesting in that it is tonkotsu based yet have options of different flavors such as miso, shio, etc, but not plain tonkotsu.  They also have tan tan men but it was sold out so I went for spicy tonkotsu and my daughter tried tonkotsu miso along with a side of karaage.  

Tonkotsu spicy was fantastic.   You can definitely taste the rich tonkotsu base but the spicy miso with which it is flavored with added a thick kotteri flavor full of umami.   Excellently executed.   Tonkotsu miso was closer to tonkotsu than a miso ramen in my opinion and it was very good, probably better than monta.   As this is more of a tonkotsu place, it should not be compared to Sora.   Chicken karaage was perfectly done with a slice if lemon, flavored salt into which you can dip the chicken and a small salad.  

My only complaint is that I didn't get to taste the tan tan men and that it's on the East side far away from my house.  I would rate their tonkotsu higher than that of montas as I have noticed some inconsistencies in monta recently.  For pure miso ramen I take Sora all day with their thick curly noodles.

I like this place. It's very fair priced. I got the spicy miso ramen. There was like one piece of meat in it, but then I realized you have to add on. It's okay though because that left more room for me to try other things. I also had the chashu bowl which was good. My favorite was the karaage! Squeeze the lemon on top and bam! So good! This place is perfect when you're looking for something good to eat and not break the bank.

So we originally were supposed to go to another spot to eat, but they were closed today! So sad. We quickly had to yelp another spot to go eat at. I stumbled upon Fukumimi and it was not too far and had great reviews. I have to say I'm not mad at all because this place was very good! 

Upon arrival there was a bit of a wait, but we didn't have to wait very long and we had a group of 8 too. This place definitely gets busy. So I'm sure it's expected for people to wait. There's a parking lot so the parking situation is very good. 

I ordered the spicy tonkotsu ramen and added corn, chasu and butter. I also ordered the honey garlic chicken and karaage which came after my ramen came out. The ramen was very delicious and chasu was very tender and soft. Highly recommend adding butter to your ramen. Honey garlic chicken and karaage was so juicy and delicious! The only complaint I had was that my bowl of ramen wasn't piping hot. I LOVE eating my soups and food steaming hot. Regardless I still thought it was delicious and still thoroughly enjoyed it.

Very quite and nice atmosphere for ramen and many different choices. Fast and friendly service. If you're from Hawaii like I am it's nothing like Hawaii it's very authentic Asian ramen but it's delicious.

We're down with the ramen and we're down with new ramen places in Vegas.  This city is big enough for plenty of options in my opinion!

Small place in the shopping center next door to Baskin Robbins and the Japanese Specialties Market.

The Husband ordered the Fukumimi Ramen ($9.50), which comes with extra pork belly, chashu, seasoned egg, green onions, bean sprouts, and seaweed.  It also has the pleasant drops of garlic oil on top too.  Midway through his ramen, he bit into a hard chunk of noodles.  It appeared that some of the noodles were stuck together and never got cooked through.  We showed the waitress the clumped up noodles and she took his ramen away.  She asked if he would like another one and got that order in immediately.  She apologized profusely and checked often to make sure the second round was fine.  It was and the Husband ate it all up.

I ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen, Miso flavored ($8.20).  Along with the standard pork belly, green onions, seasoned egg, and bean sprouts, mine came with corn too.  No garlic oil unfortunately.  My soup was creamy and full-bodied and very rich.  Quite tasty in my opinion.  I was pleased with my soup choice.  I also liked their soft boiled egg, the seasoning part of it made it even tastier.

Other unique choices on their menu include: the Tantan Men which is a Szechuan style spicy soup with ground meat and bok choy; and the Tomato Ramen which is a cold ramen with sesame sauce and vinegar.  There are also rice bowls available should ramen not be on your craving.

We noticed quite a few older Japanese clientele eating here during our meal.  That's always a good sign to us.

Overall, we like it and we'll be back!

Can we say SUPER DELICIOUS RAMEN! We came here as our last stop before leaving vegas to go back home and honestly this was a great "hangover cure"! It made me feel so much better :] The soup base is very clean and not too heavily salted, which is what I like. Usually some places I always ask them to give me low salt, just cause sometimes you feel like you're drinking salt water. The ramen was also very tasty and chewy! I like their decor it was simple and clean! I like that they only have a handful of things to choose from, so you know everything is all their specialty. Not some jumbo mumbo put together ramen. Service was also great and on spot! Definitely would come here again if I'm in vegas and feeling that ramen mood! ^^

Server supposedly named Carra, did not uphold professionalism when handling an issue that occurred that could've been easily fixed. Initially, the server had given the wrong order to the wrong person and when the issue was addressed, the server stated "You guys should just trade bowls. You should just eat his order. I'm not going to pay for it." Person should not be in the front of the house, rather wash dishes in the back especially with the rudeness and attitude.

I've been at this restaurant a few times and experienced great service. However, last night I had the worst service from the server on the right (If anyone knows her name, lmk). I brought a few of my friends over here who have never ate at this restaurant before.

First of all, she switched my friends' orders. It could have been an easy fix, but she told my friend that she HAD TO EAT the Tantan men that my friend didn't order. The server loudly said to her co-worker "I'm not paying for that!" If that server handled the situation in a non-escalating manner, she would have gotten a big tip from us - party of 10 (and use some of that tip money to "pay for the ramen").  On top that, this particular server was slamming objects around. She did not refill our waters or check up on us. 

We normally don't leave without tipping, but that server didn't deserve ANY. #bye

No wait, better noodles, cheaper and more choices of drinks vs. Ramen Sora. If they had fried rice as good as Ramen Sora I wouldn't bother going to Ramen Sora anymore. Fukumini also does a frequent buyer rewards card and all you have to do is get pass your fourth bowl for a  free appetizer.

My friends and I happened to be around the area and we were craving ramen. We yelped and found this place. It's a small restaurant but the seating was nice. It wasn't too crowded when we came in. 

My friend ordered the Chicken Karaage and it was delicious. The drizzled mayo on top looked overwhelming but it wasn't surprisingly. Though, I felt that the chicken was undercooked due to it's chewy texture instead of firm. The batter helped with a crunch and overall we enjoyed it.

We also got a Chasu bowl, I have never tried one before but I found it tasteful. 

Every time I try a Japanese restaurant I have to try their Agedashi Tofu. My favorite dashi sauce is at Ichiza in Chinatown but Fukumimi's Agedashi is coming up at number two. Two really good sized deep fried tofu pieces and their dashi sauce was not salty at all like some other places. FIVEEEEE STARS!! 

As for the ramen, I got the Kogashi and my friends all got the Tonkatsu (Miso). 

I was very pleased with the Kogashi. I don't even know how to describe it. It was perfectly salted and the broth was very good. The noodles were thin and that's how I like it although I didn't know there were bean sprouts, not fond, but I ate them anyways.

Overall, I really do like this place. I recommend trying it absolutely!

A NYers review. Not my favorite place. I've had plenty of Ramen soup. Everything about the soup was OFF. The noodles weren't right, the chicken broth and Miso were greasy... i ate half and sort of started to get grossed out from the fatty smell. I did get the Japanese fried chicken appt, good gosh, i could not bite into in the chicken. Gross. Nah nah.. i dont recommend!

I hesitate to tell anyone about this hidden gem, because I don't want it to get any busier! This place is delicious...we had the honey garlic chicken, curry, and ramen. Broth is full of flavor, noodles and char siu tender. Amazing food, we will definitely be back!
I love Fukumimi the Tankatsu Spicy Miso is so delish! Broth service & timing are on point. Can't go wrong here
We've been here quite a few times and each time it's consistent and yummy. The 2 fukumimi ramen's and the chicken bowl satisfy this family of four.
Fast service, fresh ingredients. I had the Miso ramen and my girlfriend had the salt ramen. Amazing! We'll definitely be back for more.

Honestly not a big fan of this place. I ordered the tonkatsu ramen and didn't think it was particularly special or even that good. The broth has good flavor but it wasn't super thick or rich. I think the main culprit were the noodles.  It was pretty bland and didn't add much to the meal besides my carb load count. There was also very little cha Siu meat that comes with the ramen. 

I haven't had a lot of ramen in vegas but I definitely don't think I'll be coming back to this one. Service was great, the place was small and cozy, but I left pretty unsatisfied with my meal.

Still one of our favorite places to visit when we come to Vegas! We have a stamp card, so after every 4th ramen we get a free appetizer.

The place is tiny, but usually busy. There's very limited seating so if you come at a prime dinner time on Fri/Sat, you can expect to wait. Worth the wait though, and it's never been more than 10 minutes. Classic ramen shop with all wooden benches and seating, which creates authentic ambiance.

We are pretty much creatures of habit and always get the same thing when we come. The chicken karage appetizer is so good! Perfectly crispy and a good sized portion - usually about 6-7 pieces. As for ramen, I get the classic Fukumimi ramen. Nothing crazy - thin noodle, green onions, pork belly, seaweed, and soft boiled egg. THE EGG. It always makes me ecstatic when a ramen shop has a soft boiled egg. The pork belly is also to die for - I've never had more tender meat!

My husband likes a thicker noodle and a bit of spice so he gets the Tonkotsu Ramen Spicy. Same ingredients as Fukumimi minus the seaweed. 

We'll keep coming back - love this place!

So delicious!

In town for a conference and stopped by thanks to Yelpers' reviews. So glad we did!

BEST. KIMCHI. EVER. Ordered a plate of it as an appetizer and ate half of it like that, then ate the rest with the ramen.

Edamame is great. I know edamame seems like it's all created equal, but their soybeans are plump and wonderful. They use a great flaky salt on them, too.

Spicy ramen was amazing. Pork was incredibly tender, and the broth was flavorful and complex! It's good with kimchi in it, too, if you're into that. I am.

The chicken ramen is great. More basic than the spicy ramen, so if you're looking for a flavor experience, go for the spicy. It's not super spicy (at least to me).

Service was excellent; our server was adorable and friendly, and the whole kitchen staff asked when we left how the food was, and we were pleased to report how happy we were with the food.

GO. GO EAT RAMEN.

This establishment is my favorite ramen place to go to when Ramen Sora is too busy. It's near my house and very affordable. The portion sizes are huge which is a plus because I eat like I'm four people. I am always in and out of this place because the service is so good and the food comes out very quickly. I have never had a bad experience the few times I have been here.

It was a odd rainy day in the valley and a bit cool even. A cousin from out of town wanted soup and we were on this side of town near other family members. 

They do shio, miso and tonkatsu, tantan men broth. They offer chicken broth based ramen for those who aren't down with the pork base. There are cold noodles salads, rice bowls and some appetizers as well. 

I haven't had tantan men ramen in ages, but I used to be in love with it when I was a kid. It's a bit Chinese influenced ramen, with a chile sesame soup with ground meat, scallion, bok choy. If you like dan dan noodles, you probably would enjoy this. Fukumimi has a solid tantan-men with a good broth and nicely chewy noodles. 

Mini chasu bowl was also good and for a "mini" it was a sizeable portion. The only thing is I thought it was going to be sliced chasu like what is in the ramen, which I think I prefer. Instead, it is shredded up pieces that seems to be mixed with a bit of soy. 

I also tried a bite of my cousins karaage. It wasn't bad, but could have been a tad more crispy even though I enjoyed the flavor and texture overall.

The service was decent enough, my drink was refilled a few times throughout the meal.

The rest of my party was happy with their meals. I haven't tried the rest of their ramen offerings, but I'm happy to find a place that offers a solid tantan-men which is a variation that no other ramen shop makes in town.

Found this place yesterday while in Vegas. I had a craving for ramen and googled yelp ramen las vegas. 

I was going to try another place at first but yelpers dogged their soup base.

Im so glad i came here. I ordered the spicy ramen with extra pork...it was deeelish!!!

My new fave ramen spot while in Vegas! Since Im here so much, it helps to know where to eat!

I decided since I always eat pho that it was time to try ramen. This was close by and since I'm no ramen connoisseur I figured this place would be a good place to pop my ramen cherry. We started off with chicken karaage. Crispy tender dark meat fried to crispy heaven. Very good. For ramen I decided on tantan men at first but my boyfriend told me I would not like it and to try something else. I went with the chicken ramen because pork ramen didn't sound appetizing to me. I forgot what my boyfriend ordered but it had seaweed. I felt like the broth was boring and not at all something I enjoyed. The bowl was very small portion too. I left hungry still. Very underwhelming I've come to the conclusion ramen is meh... And pho is love. I will stick to what I like And ramen is definitely not it for me.

The best ramen in the city.

This is exactly what a ramen place is meant to be: a small menu whose broths and noodles are executed perfectly, fresh ingredients, reasonable price, and a simple but nice looking dining room.

I've most often gotten the fukumimi ramen. It's a bowl with extra pork--delicious, delicious pork. I'd give any bowl in this place a shot, though.

This place got some pretty good reviews so we decided to give it a try, it was also close to our hotel. We both ordered the tonkatsu soy ramen with high hopes and to our dismay we were a bit disappointed. The broth didn't taste as good as we've had before and the soft boiled egg was cold and tasteless. However their customer service was really good. They greeted their customers upon entering and exiting the restaurant. If I do come back, I'll probably try something else.

Yum. Still have not had a bad meal here. Fukumimi is still in my top 3 ramen spots! Something new on the menu is the kogashi ramen, which has thin noodles and broth has black garlic oil. Another new menu item is garlic chicken appetizer, which I will have to try next time. The appetizer I always is the kim chi!!! It's different, but I love it...it has a slight sweetness to it. Guess what? Filled up my stamp card! Free gyoza or karaage next time :)
Went here a few days ago. Had the Classic Ramen. Oh god! It was the best. I can't say I'm an expert on Ramen because this was the first time I've had it in a restaurant but I'll definitely be back.

This is a tiny, informal lunch place. Good ramen dishes. Pleasant servers. In a nondescript (even ugly) strip mall setting, but don't be turned off by that --- the restaurant is good. But strictly as a lunch spot: I certainly wouldn't take a date here!

Quality ramen with a twist.  A newcomer to the ramen scene.  This time on the East side.  Ain't nothing wrong with that.

Noodles - hardly seasoned but chewy.  Check.
Chashu - tender porky goodness.  Check.
Salt, soy, miso, spicy broths.  Check, check, check, check.
Ramen that showcases it all - very flavorful "Fukumimi" (tonkotsu topped with everything).  Check.

So what sets it apart from the big boys, Sora and Monta?  Tantan Men; a simple, almost naked bowl of noodles swimming in an exceptional spicy sesame broth.   The broth is so intense, you can't see the noodles through its mustard yellow liquid.  Tender baby bok choi breaks the one dimensional texture.  Thanks you Godzilla X for bringing this elixir to my attention. 

PC Tip:  While manners dictate you should drink all the ramen broth,  those with a weak constitution or first time connoisseurs should make an exception for very rich and spicy tantan men.   Just sayin.

Excellent chicken karaage (crisp with the hint of ginger flavor).  Good curry rice (strong with bits of tender pork).  NO GYOZA.  NO TONKATSU.

A very worthy addition to Vegas' ramen scene.

We found this ramen place after a long delay at the airport...we used Yelp to find a place nearby and this place was indeed a solid four stars. I ordered the salt ramen with a side of chashu rice and beer. Note, they do not have any hot beverages...so I could not get hot green tea, just iced. The bowl of ramen was good and so satisfying on this rainy day in Las Vegas. If I had a ramen carving in Las Vegas, I will definitely stop by here before heading to the airport.

One Sunday night, I drove across the town to get Fukumimi that had been on my "have to try" lost for a while. Around 7 pm, there was a few tables occupied and I was able to be seated immediately when I walked in. I ordered Tonkotsu ramen and Karaage. Karaage came out first and it was nothing special, but the powder type of salt was interesting. When it comes to ramen, the first thing I noticed was the ramen bowl was like the half size of other ramen shops in town and so the portion was. I was debating if I should order another one after one bowl or not and my decision was "no more". It was a bit salty for me and I was not really into the flavor of the broth while eating the ramen. But overall, It was not bad. If I live close by this ramen house and I'm craving for ramen, I would come again.

Fukumimi is so legit. This review is sans all the geographical, technical ramen nonsense and all about the delicious food.

The Karaage is my kind of fried chicken. Lightly breaded, lightly fried, nice and moist. However, maybe it was the batch we got but it seemed under seasoned. Nothing some chili flakes (they didn't have togarashi) and sriracha can't fix but I wonder if the breading was supposed to have more spice? They gave us a frequent diner card that'll get us a free app every few bowls. Without a doubt, karaage will be my choice.

Just saying, whoever designed this menu needs a lesson in menu-writing. And I don't mean graphics! It's totally confusing! There are so many options: Fukumimi Ramen, Tan Tan Men, Shoyu, Shio, Miso, Tonkotsu, blah blah blah. I can totally appreciate options, but there isn't enough description to figure out which one to order. A well-written menu doesn't make you scratch your head; it's supposed to inspire you to eat, well, everything.

With my menu rant over with, I'm back to talking about how much I love the food. After a few questions to the waitress (who was super nice might I add), I finally decided on the Fukumimi Ramen with the Miso broth (you have a choice).  I think the Fukumimi bowl is like your "deluxe" bowl at Sora: half an egg, a couple slices of pork, a few nori, menma, green onion. Then of course you can add any extras you desire.

Broth was rich and flavorful without being too salty. They add black garlic oil at the end which adds even more depth. Noodles aren't as thick as I like but still nice and chewy. I swear, with all these ramen places opening, there are so many different types of charsiu in Vegas now. Their pork is less tender than most places and more chewy. It was also cut really thick. I'm all for delicious pork but because it didn't just melt in your mouth it was a little more difficult to eat.

Fukumimi runs a little east for me. UNLV is as far east as I usually go so I probably won't be here as much as I like. If I'm in the area though, I'm for sure going to try to stop by. It's down the street from my favorite Middle East market by the Liberace Museum so maybe I can work it into my usual hits!

This place is pretty good. The flavor is nothing unique or phenomenal, but it is definitely tasty, close to UNLV, and cheap compared to other ramen places. The servers were really nice too. Definitely a bang for your buck. Would recommend if you want a quick bite after school or a quick, casual meet up with friends.

I stumbled across this place by accident really. The first time I saw it I noticed it was in a very seemingly lonely plaza on the corner of Tropicana and Eastern, not really an attention grabber but in my search for some great Japanese ramen I figured I would give it a shot. With my affinity for small mom and pop businesses this was totally a place for me and let me tell you, it didn't disappoint one bit!
When I walked it, it had a very welcoming environment. You're greeted as you walk in the door and are told to pick a seat of your liking. A menu is presented, one with few choices but those few choices are there because that is what they specialize in and what you will love even if at first you think you won't. I chose the Japanese fried chicken to start. The seasoning was perfect! Simple seasoning of salt, white pepper, floured then deep fried. Super juicy and tender served along a mixed greens salad with a Japanese vinaigrette. Very tasty! The ramen that I selected was the Tonkatsu Ramen (salt). I am a big fan of this type of ramen so when I ordered it I had very high expectations. The presentation of the ramen was beautiful. The stock was dark and full of flavorful collagen, the pork was cooked to perfection the point of it falling apart in the broth and the half egg on top had a perfectly creamy yolk that any egg lover would die for. The ramen noodles were al dente as well. The base of the ramen was extremely flavorful. You could tasted the love and time that it took to make this delicious dish. 
I would gladly visit this restaurant again to try the different types of ramen that they offer. To anyone that is searching for some delicious ramen on the east side of town, definitely go here! You don't have to go to Chinatown to get some great Japanese ramen!
The best ramen I've had in Vegas. My favorite is their spicy ramen (I think it's the Kara-Miso?). For appetizers, I love their Honey Garlic Chicken and their Agedashi Tofu :)

With nothing visibly vegetarian on the menu, I decided to order the fried tofu and a side of edamame. I prefer my tofu firm, thoroughly marinaded and fried. Unfortunately the tofu was on the softer side, unflavored, with a lightly crisp glaze, sitting in a salty soy sauce broth. I tried to enjoy it, but it just tasted underwhelming and mushy. Like something made as an after thought. I mentioned my disappointment to the waitress, but I don't think she knew what to respond or how to follow up so gave a polite laugh and left it at that. Shame, I found the minimalistic atmosphere interesting and I hoped it would become a new Date Night option.

3.5 stars rounded up!

I've been wanting to explore the Vegas ramen scene a little more and landed on Fukumimi Ramen (from a friend's recommendation as well as Yelp reviews). Came here on a Sunday night for dinner and my friend and I were seated right away at the bar (the tables were all occupied)

FOOD:
- karaage - good! Not too bready, served piping hot with a small salad and you dip it into their salt/pepper mix. We dipped it into the chili powder and that made it even yummier!
- Fukumimi ramen - this was pretty good! Rich broth, but not too salty. Generous portions of noodles (on the thinner side, kinda soba-ish)
- Tantan men (with an egg added) - rich, thick and creamy broth. The ground pork was sweet and savory at the same time and the noodles were more eggy and curly.

SERVICE:
Can't complain! Seated right away, food came out hot and quick. Friendly smiles all around. 

VENUE:
Cute! Rather spacious for a ramen spot. Tables along the right side and counter seating on the left. Casual, relaxed vibe.

PARKING:
Plenty! It's located in a HUGE plaza where most things are closed before dinner time so you'll have you pick of any spot you want.

My friend invited me here, claiming this place has the best karaage and ramen in Vegas. So I decided to give it a try with my husband and our friend. We put our names in the wait list. I saw people constantly coming in and coming out. I figured with this many people, this place MUST be great. We waited avout 15 minutes and were sat at the bar. It took about 10 minutes before anyone came to take our order but with how busy and fast paced everything was, it was reasonable.
We ordered the agadashi tofu, karaage, and the honey garlic chicken as appetizers.
The agadashi tofu was standard. Nothing particularly about it made it special. I wish that there was daikon radish included. Daikon radish probably made me like the dish more.
The karaage truly was delicious. It came out very hot. It was crispy and the meat inside was extremely juicy and flavorful. I don't know how it is marinated but whatever it is, somehow the karaage is very special.
The honey garlic chicken lacked of garlic flavor and it was more towards the sweet side. It made me think of barbecue sauce. The sauce would have tasted better on rice.
As for ramen, I had a regular tonkatsu miso ramen. I took out the bean sprouts. I believe that bean sprouts add an unnecessary crunch to ramen. The chasiu was very tender and melted in my mouth. The ends were seasoned with pepper which I found interesting. Soft boiled eggs are my favorite part of ramen and unfortunately here the egg was simply over cooked in my opinion. The broth was very hearty and satisfying though.
I docked 1 star for the over cooked egg and that when I tried getting the server's attention for a water refill I was completely ignored. I drank all my water and my husband's water but was still ignored.

Finally had time to drive all the way across town to give it a go!

Tried the "Tantan Men" ramen, which was a Szechuan style spicy ramen with red chili oil!  I also tried the Fukumimi ramen, which comes with extra pork, egg and nori. Everything was good here, but I think that "other" ramen place a little better.  They do give you plenty of pork though, just didn't enjoy the taste as much truthfully.  Pic :

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/fukumimi-ramen-las-vegas?userid=eZZyuJDouIg4p-GYB3PV_A#zY0F82mi3QlwIK-v6L1qTQ

What I really liked was the SOBORO bowl! It was super yummy, with marinated ground pork and veggies! I kept eating my son's food, because it was that good lol!  Plus we got some extra nori because it is one of his most favorite things ever! We did have to pay $1 though, where most places are usually free for the baby....but still worth it.  Check it out :

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/fukumimi-ramen-las-vegas?userid=eZZyuJDouIg4p-GYB3PV_A#UHZ-q-EvOcCzZHpcWngIxQ

Check it out if you are on this side of town....Southeast, near Trop and Eastern

The best ramen in Vegas! I've been to several ramen spots including monta and Fukumimi kills the competition. My boyfriend and I go here at least once a month! He gets the tan-tan and I get the miso ramen with extra egg. You must try you won't regret it!

Where is the flavor? My husband and I went here since our favorite spot Monta is temporarily closed. Unfortunately our cravings for ramen were not satisfied by trying out this place. The ramen broth was beyond bland, even after we added chili oil, vinegar, and soy sauce the broth was still pale and flavorless. No second chances here.

I always eat at Fukumimi Ramen but I never gave them a proper review. It's the only ramen place close by our house and that is one of the reasons why I keep coming back. Another is that, I love their gyoza. I always try to make my own gyoza but I still end up craving the gyoza from Fukumimi. 

Never forget to try all their ramen, even the spicy one! I always go for the classic ramen but from time to time I pick the Miso Ramen and don't forget the gyoza! Their karaage is a bonus, the flavor was just right. 

If you are not into ramen, they also have curry and other meat bowls you can choose from which are as filling as the ramen. 

I will come back and collect my free ramen bowls.

I enjoyed this ramen bowl of goodness for sure. You would never think that on the eastside part of Las Vegas that they would be putting out a great ramen dish. I've been to ramen sora, Monta and other ramen places but I think when it comes to noodles and broth this is my favorite flavor IMO. It's a perfect portion as well and I didn't feel overly stuffed. Only thing was maybe the pork cha-Su could use some work.

I almost gave this 4 stars because the serving is small but I just remembered that the price was under $8 for a bowl of very good ramen so I bumped it to 5.
