I got the tonkotsu salt and added corn, the ramen was cooked "al dente" and the broth was really tasty. I ordered a noodle refill (kae-dama) and they were a little under cooked but that makes sense since they would've been sitting in my piping hot broth had I ordered it ahead of time.

They have beer, the waitress was very attentive, they brought my check to me after I finished without asking, they were pretty busy but not packed, the waitresses were checking in on the patrons often. The staff was all working, no one standing around. 

Solid place, it's small so a big group might have a hard time. I might come back and try the katsu curry but I'll definitely be back for ramen.

Is a great ramen place here, love the Japanese style tantan noodles. The soup was very different and tasty although a bit too salty. The best was their Fukumimi ramen, the soup as GREAT, the pork was tender and the noodles was done just right. Iwould say is wayyy better than Monta.

Small place, ok service. Honey garlic chicken is a must get. Spicy miso ramen was really good, broth had a lot of flavor. Fukumimi ramen was ok but nothing special. Reasonable prices. 
Solid 4/5

Kind of disappointed honestly. I was really looking forward to some multi-dimensional ramen! Not worth $8 per bowl in my opinion. It would't be hard to do it better at home for less than half that price. The noodles were undercooked and the broth was lack-luster. My husband's spicy ramen broth was good and the salad was OK. Asked for a glass of water, never got it. It also bothered me that they turned several people away starting at 10:30pm when they advertise their hours until 11pm. Our check was brought over while we were still eating and we were bugged every three minutes after that. I don't like feeling rushed, especially when they aren't scheduled to close for another 20 minutes. Maybe my ramen sucked because they were trying to close early or something. Either way, not cool.
I may give it a second chance at some point in the distant future.

Try the Honey Garlic Chicken Karaage, very tender, juicy, crispy and an explosion of flavor. I ordered their Tonkatsu Ramen Spicy with extra Chashu and the missus got the Fukimimi Ramen. First spoonful of broth, amazing. Very flavorful and wholesome. Like a shio-orgasm in your mouth.

All the best in here! My 2 kids love it...the Fukumimi Ramen,the Gyoza,the Chicken Karaage are the best!perfect taste for my kids!
Just can't stop coming back here!

I persuaded the BF to try this the other night.  He is a big fan of Japanese food, I not so much but I thought he might like it.  Turns out we both did!  I tried the karaage chicken appetizer and we both thought it was as everyone said earlier :KARAAAGE!!!! It is delicious, light, meaty, tasty, not greasy, and HOT.  He tried the tantan men and liked it but it was a little different than he's used to.  He wants to try the classic or tonkatsu next time.  I absolutely fell in love with the salad and the salad dressing was the best!!  The greens were delicate and tasty and the salad dressing, some tomato onion I'm not sure but it was delicious.  Service was quick and the seating comfortable enough.  We will definitely be back!!

A must stop on your Vegas ramen tour! We went late one Friday afternoon, and the spot was empty. I love the wooden interior; it feels clean and like you're entering a quiet little place outside of the Vegas bustle. 

The service was smiley, which is always appreciated. After perusing the short menu, my husband asked for a recommendation, and the waitress actually said she liked the chicken ramen, which is a unique offering. He went with her lead and enjoyed it.

I went for my standard ramen order which is miso. I was pleased to know that they don't include bamboo shoots, so I didn't have to ask them to hold 'em. When the bowl hit the table, the only slightly disappointing aspect was the size. It seemed a bit smaller than other ramen bowls. However, it still delivered a big flavor, including corn niblets and  bean sprouts! The noodles had the right chewiness, and the broth was a savory treat. The pork belly could have been a bit more luscious, but overall, it was a ramen experience worth repeating.

Amazing. We had appetizers and ramen and they were delicious. I would definitely come here again. The place is small but cozy and they have good service. We were greeted when we came in, our server didn't ignore us and came to our table constantly. I didn't get pictures of everything we ate but everything was good we had potstickers not sure what the actually name was on the menu and they were the best ones I've ever had. Point is it was delicious and it's a place I will continue to come to.
Best place in Vegas for Ramen.  Chicken Karaage and Gyoza are also a can't miss. Always come here at least once whenever in Vegas. Good and affordable comfort food

So we been coming here for about a year now love it but today one of the worst servers that we have had any question we asked with a. Rude response the we get our food not only to ask if everything was ok or anything  then we are about to start eating when bringing the check not even have started to eat are u kidding me wow seriously food was great but that waiter couldn't even get her name wouldn't give it to me  u might want to go home but this is just rude and bad I will be back because never had this happen before plus the food is amazing but trying to kick us out and not even finish food horrible
This place is up and coming with constantly very good Ramen! They are as good as Monta and almost as good as Sora.

Fukumimi Ramen with Honey Garlic Chicken. 

The ramen - at first glance, the bowl is smaller than your normal bowl which means less broth. The broth itself was probably the best quality of this meal. Next would noodles, no complaints. These are decent noodles. The cha shiu could be juicer with more fat to lean meat proportion and the soft boiled egg is prepared cut in half, which you already know it does not have an oozing yolk.

The chicken was too salty and the fried batter was too thick. The mayo sauce on top makes it too heavy and even greasier. I would not get this again. 

As rated as the best ramen in Las Vegas, I am not sure to be disappointed or satisfied. This meal is barely passable as a 4 stars but if this is the best that Las Vegas has got, I know I won't be visiting anymore ramen shops over here.

Time to eat ramen since I love ramen and I am craving karaage.

Ordered tonkotsu soy ramen and spicy ramen.

Tonkotsu ramen-soy ($7.50): I love the texture of my white straight noodle but the broth is lacking flavor.  
Tonkotsu ramen-spicy ($8.20): not that good either.
Karaage (6 pcs for $3.90): juicy but not crispy and not tasty.  Too bad because it looks so crispy from the outside.  The only flavor I taste is salt...super salty.

Friendly service.  I think they have a punch card for regulars because the table next to me asks the waitress.  Not sure though since they don't offer it to me and I don't think I'll be back.

2 stars!!  I am spoiled by better ramen in LA County.

Fukumimi ramen is not yummylicious!!

Looking for a quick Japanese ramen fix this is the place...kara miso ramen is the best if you love spicy like me,  fukumimi ramen if your in a mood for the regular one... honey glazed and chicken kaarage are the bomb...  small place so make sure call if you want to know if their busy...

Absolutely horrible service and food. The restaurant will make you leave upset. 

1. No greeting. Very slow service

2. We ordered honey chicken because it looked really good in picture. But when we took a bite, the chicken was raw. So we complained. It sounded like they hear a lot of complaints like this. So without even looking at the chicken, they said it is dark meat, so it will be little bit red. 
I have servesafe manager certification and I work in the kitchen. I know the difference between darkmeat being red and chicken being raw. However their response was "even though we cook again, it will be red. Do you still want it?" So of course we told them NO. And asked them to bring us menu to order new dish

3. They did not bring us a menu after the chicken incident. So we had to walk up to the counter to get a menu.

4. I have never been to any ramen place that does not serve ramen in 15 minute when I literally ordered just one ramen.

5. I normally don't care about the service. Since what I want from the restaurants is good food. However, their below average service pissed me off. No greeting. No saying thank you or enjoy or here is your bill.

6. They got 0 tip from us. Only thing they served that was good was a can of coke.

I seriously dont know why this place has good review. If you know how to enjoy ramen, go run away from this place. There are plenty good options out there. This one is not even worth to give a shot for change. Please believe me.

Our favorite ramen restaurant in Vegas, so far. The parking lot is huge. The restaurant is small.  We do like that it's not in Chinatown.  Which is a major plus! 

The ramen is good and tasty without being salty or oily. The karaage is one of the best we have tasted outside of Japan!

Best Ramen place I have been to in a long time. I live in Arizona but travel to Vegas every month for work, this place is a must when in town! Reminds me of the traditional ramen spots in Japan and the service is awesome. I typically get the Miso with an extra egg.

Little hole in the wall ramen place. My favorite place to have ramen! Compare it monta or the ramen out at bachi, fukumimi has a very good balance in the soup. Try pairing with honey garlic chicken. Usually order miso ramen, but their rice bowls are the bomb too.

I recently moved to Boston, but I was home for the holidays and looking forward to getting ramen at one of my favorite spots prior to moving. I arrived with my friend 6:50pm and we had another friend meeting us at 7:00pm. We were seated and looking over the menu planning to order an appetizer and a couple of drinks when a large party of 6 entered the restaurant. Upon their arrival my friend and I were asked by the waitress the location of the third person. We informed the waitress that he was 5 minutes away. She proceeded to tell us that it was first come first serve and that we would need to get up out of our seats and wait for our third person to arrive. I should note that my friend sent a text message telling us he arrived at fukumimi at 7:00pm.  We had already left. I understand the need for businesses to fill seats to maximize profits, but I cannot believe that we were already seated and then told to get up. I've never experienced this degree of horrible service in a restaurant. I will not be coming back and I doubt the other two in my group will be either.
I love the Fukumimi Ramen Special.  It has the right amount of toppings.  Plus their stamp card is great.  You get a free Chicken Kaarage after your 4th visit.

Food is great, service needs improvements, seating needs to be whoever showed up first and not making them wait 10 minutes on empty seats. Follow up after you receive your entrees. I wonder who runs this business?  Other than that foods is worth it. This is my 6th time here, I'll give it one more try in a week or so.

Fukumimi Ramen $9.50 - recommended by server. 

I had no expenctation about this place since I've tried Monta Ramen & Sora Ramen. I was not disappointed at Fukumimi Ramen. Broth is mild and flavorful.

Another place that serves appetizers after the main course comes out. Didn't appreciate that much, service was slow and not very attentive.

Broth was very delicious, their noodles aren't made from scratch and come from a package which were decent. The 2 chicken appetizers were good but we were too full to finish them.

Not sure if we will come back, we seem to like Monta better even though they have long lines almost all of the time.

We were in dyer need of some hangover food so instead of our usual Pho , the group decided on ramen. We came here on a whim, I think most of us wished we went with pho instead. 

The ramen was just OK at the most. I guess if you are near by it's ok instead of driving somewhere on the strip.

A nice little ramen spot.

Environment: The restaurant is small, only having maybe 10 tables as well as bar seating. However, the overall decorating is cute and cozy. The only thing that I will say is that the bathroom could use some renovating.

Food: The ramen was delicious. I got a garlic tonkatsu ramen and the broth was delicious and creamy, and their variety of additional toppings was extensive. Additionally, we tried the chicken karaage appetizer which was very tasty and juicy and came in a very good portion for the price. Additionally, the little salad that it came with was delicious as well.

Service: Service was good also good. Servers were prompt with service and repeatedly checked up on us to make sure that everything came out alright and that our drinks were always refilled.

Overall this is a nice hole-in-the-wall ramen spot in an area of Las Vegas that is devoid of many ramen options.

I had the Fukumimi. Kind of mediocre. I immediately noticed the lack of Asians working here as a bad sign. I did like that the broth wasn't overpowering so you could enjoy straight broth once the ingredients were gone. Service was fine. Monta and Sora have tastier ramen though. Could have it again but wouldn't go out of my way to.

As soon as we sat down, the waitress brought out bowl and children's  silverware for our toddler. Never in my time as a mother have I seen a restaurant offer that, I was very impressed. 
The menu was small, simple and to the point. My husband ordered the tantan men and I got the tonkotsu soy. The pork belly was super tender and the broth was very flavorful. $18 for the two of us is amazing while on vacation. We would be regulars if we lived here.

Tried almost all of there ramen :) ! My faves are kogashi ramen and tan tan men. There karaage is so yummy too crispy and juicy. The Japanese chef always delivers excellent food. I gave it 4 stars because "some" of the servers take long to get orders and when you call them they ignore you sometimes which I don't like :(

We came here on a Monday evening and order the
1. Fukumimi Ramen with egg and corn 
2. Tan Tan man Ramen with egg and corn
For $25

- Next to Baskin Robbins. 
- No Japanese chefs yelling welcome in their native tongue fail. 
- Tight seating. Uncomfortable wooden chairs.
- Luke warm broth, but hot noodles. Sections of the soup had different temperature!? HAHA. 
- Small portion relative to price. 
- Great flavor. Savory, pork-esque, slightly creamy. 
- Half an egg only. Just order extra for a full egg. 
- $1 for a full egg. 50cents for canned corn. 
- Null service. Nothing to really discuss. Here is your drink, soup, and check. 
- A bit too much fat on the pork belly for my liking. 
- I recommend the fukumimi ramen. Not too thick, rich flavor and taste over Tan tan.
- Tan tan had minced pork. Cheap. Broth was creamy and noodles were different compared to fukumimi.
- Stamp card! For every 4 ramen you buy, you get 1 free serving of gyoza! 
- 5 would be Shin Sen Gumi or any SoCal equivalent. 4 for Monta. Then you have this place, which is a decent alternative just to try something different.

This place was good. The fukumimi ramen with soy broth was delicious!! The Gyoza (6) was delicious as well although It was smaller than I expected. It is likened to monta Chaya in Las Vegas and Ramen-ya in Hawaii where they offer a choice of larger (6) Gyoza or regular (8). Hubby has a rice bowl which he recommends if you enjoy eating rice.  Grandsons enjoyed the spicy as well as regular ramen.

We went here late at night and the place was empty I could do cartwheels, weeee! Nice, clean and bright place.

We saw GARLIC OIL on the menu so, we got 2 bowls of salt Tonkotsu ramen. I wanted to see how it compares to black Shisen ramen that I love so much but it's all the way in L.A. Honestly, Fukumimi's version was milder and less garlicky and only comes with one piece of chashu (sad) but I don't know where else in town to get garlic ramen. This'll do for now until I find another place that has it.  We also got a soboro bowl (pan-fried ground meat on top of greens and rice).  It was alright but not worth sabotaging my diet for.  I couldn't finish my bowl of ramen so I took it to go.  I finished it this morning and it was still good and got rid of my headache.

Other items on the menu aside from ramen: karaage, chashu bowl, curry rice, chicken bowl, kimchi, kimchi bowl and edamame. Next time, I'll ask them to put more garlic oil and order extra chashu...I'll try the Tantan Men too.

Service is good and quick.
Tonkotsu soup is not too strong

The fukumimi ramen is awesome. If u have the opportunity u should try the tonkatsu ramen miso, it's another family favorite. 
If rice rice dishes turn u on then the chasu bowl is the way to go. 
If tapas is ur way then karage chicken, honey garlic chicken, Gyoza, agedashi tofu is the way for you.
There salad dressing here is excellent and there salad cost $2. Take a chance give it a try.

First time in, I got the Fukumimi ramen, which comes with thin noodles.  The broth was great and the portions were perfect.  I'll be back.  The only reason I'm giving it a 4 is because the noodles were standard, not anything to write home about but not disappointing either.  I'd definitely go back.  

Also got the honey chicken, the edamame, and the gyoza.  All ok but the ramen was the star.

Price was shockingly affordable.

I've had to keep making myself come back here because the first experience was meh - but I'm completely satisfied with this place right now and keep it in mind whenever I'd like to a have a bowl of ramen

All the appetizers are completely nomz - my couple favorites are the honey garlic chicken, the chicken karaage and the gyoza - pick any of these and you're good to go.

One ramen bowl that particularly stands out would be the Spicy Ramen - just the right hint of spice and flavor but not overpowering enough to where you can't finish the bowl without coughing throughout the whole meal - I'd recommend this bowl if you do like spicy.

However, each time I come here, I hardly ever leave full in the stomach but it absolutely hits the spot every time and I do leave satisfied. Prices per bowl are around $7.xx to $8.95

Would recommend, go check it out!

**Summary**
      - Ramen - Their ramen is authentic and has the perfect amount of flavor.
      - Area - Being on the corner of Tropicana and Eastern, the neighborhood is not as great.
      - Decor - However, the inside looks newly renovated and completely different from the outside surroundings.
      - Saltiness - I like the salt level at this place. It's not too salty like some of the other ramen places around town.
      - Pork Belly - Their pork belly is just delicious. It's probably about as good as the one from Ramen Sora.
      - Flavors - The flavors are salt (shio), soy (shoyu), miso, and spicy. I particularly like shio for its simple, yet elegant flavor. The broth for miso and spicy are a little too thick for me.
**Ordered**
      - $9.50 Fukumimi Ramen - Their version of the deluxe ramen. It has pork belly, egg, seaweed and sprouts.
      - $3.90 Karaage - Lacking in flavor, but you can't pretty cheap for what you get.
**Recommendations**
      - I'd recommend this place for a nice authentic ramen restaurant.

This is our go-to ramen place. It's always pretty packed but the wait is worth it. The food is consistent so we always know we're in for a good meal. 

Today we ordered -
Tonkotsu Ramen (miso) - the broth is pork based. The flavors are well developed and ridiculously delicious. This one comes with the thicker noodles, which I prefer, chashu, egg, and corn. I always order this or the spicy miso.
Original ramen - this one has a chicken based broth and you can taste the difference. It's a little lighter than the pork based broth but just as flavorful. This one comes with the thinner noodles, chashu, egg, and bean sprouts. My kiddo always orders this one. 
Honey-Garlic chicken - oh man, this is a must order. We get it every time. It's the karaage chicken coated in a sweet and savory sauce then drizzled with some kind of mayo-looking sauce and topped with sesame seeds. It's crispy on the outside and always juicy on the inside. 
Chashu bowl - this was our first time ordering a bowl. It comes with shredded pork that has a slightly sweet sauce on it, strips of scramby eggs, pickled ginger, green onions, and seaweed all over white rice. The pork was really good and everything mixed together made for a perfect bite. 

The service is always great here. Staff is friendly and helpful. They always offer my kiddo the chopstick trainers, which is a thoughtful touch. Food comes out fast and is always fresh and piping hot. I know there are tons of ramen places in town but this one is, hands down, my favorite.

Polite and attentive staff, good food, and cozy ambiance is what you will get when you go to Fukumimi. 

The karaage chicken is boneless and not the chicken wings like other places try to pass off as karaage. The chicken is lightly coated, crispy on the outside, while the meat is juicy and tender. Paired with the mixed greens tossed in a miso dressing, it was perfect.

I had ordered the tan tan men; a spicy broth mixed with ground chicken and pork. This preparation comes from Chinese influence and incorporates bok choy in it. I thought that it was the perfect balance of richness, a touch of sweetness, and saltiness. I finished mine in no time and started to eat my friend's salt miso when she couldn't finish it. Yet again, I liked the balance in the broth. The color was opaque and it tasted as if bones and meat had been simmering in it for hours. 

The best part was that I still felt full around dinner time. Usually Japanese food leaves me hungry a few hours later. Fukumimi is definitely stick to your ribs kind of food.

We love ramen and this was really good. We came around closing and we felt welcome and the staff was really nice. Service was perfect, menu had a lot of choices. Ramen was done just right, very tasty.
We will be back.

A very limited menu and small space, but that's all you need. This is glorious soup and noodles in a bowl, and not much else, which is absolutely fine. The best ramen in Las Vegas. They're all pretty good, but the spicy miso ramen is probably my favorite.

Kogashi Ramen is good. We also ordered karaage and gyouza. Cant go wrong with that. Checkout the place and see for yourself. Dont ignore Fukumimi because of some negative reviews. Wife and daughter had the miso and spicy with thick noodles. They were good as well.

Kogashi Ramen $8.20. Which is rousted garlic with tonkotsu soup.  I loved it!  I forgot to bring stamp card to get free meal.  Lol

My husband had Karaage and Gyoza.  These were great.

An OK ramen shop, but not my favorite. Have been here a few times and always find it a bit forgettable. 

Their ramen options come with two ramen noodle types, thick and thin, which might confuse some people, like it did me, at first. The place is pretty small and is always very busy when Im there. The service can be hit or miss, but overall is quick and friendly. The ramen usually comes out pretty fast as well. 

I always go for traditional tonkotsu miso ramen, but I never find the broth flavor quite satisfying. tonkotsu should have a deep, rich, salty broth, but their broth always seems a bit thin and lacking on the flavor. That said, it will totally satisfy your ramen craving and seem to be very popular. As others have said the noodles are hit and miss, sometimes overcooked sometimes undercooked. I also find it kind of strange that they sell soda in can instead of having a fountain. Overall a pretty decent place if you are craving ramen.
Started coming here a few years back when the other Ramen place I went to closed. Glad I found this little spot on my side of town. The servers are always friendly. The food is great!!

Just came in from a road trip wanting some ramen, so we stopped in. My husband insisted I try their name sake, fukumimi ramen, egg, pork belly, noodle, green onions, and broth!

I thought it was good, I liked the combination of ingrediates and the broth was rich and seasoned well! 

Good service good food!

We've been eating at Fukumimi for several years. The perfect selection of Ramens,appetizers and drinks. I like a menu that is small and to the point to me that means they can make everything tasty. 
 I don't eat meat so I usually get the kimchi rice bowl or a veggie ramen. 
 My wife loves the chicken karaage appetizer and I love the house salad with ginger dressing. 
  As far as the Ramen flavors I really enjoy the spicy broth best. I enjoy thick noodles at times and other times thin. 
  The restaurant is very small and intimate. You'll only be seated if all members of your party are present I imagine do to limited seating. When it's real busy we eat and leave right away so people waiting can have they're turn to eat.

Solid ramen joint.  The spicy is great. Just try to go during the off peak hours.  The service is great and the food is total comfort food!  It is small so during the lunch break it gets super crammed.

Fukumimi is my favorite ramen restaurant in Vegas so far. I get the Fukumimi Ramen which already comes with an 1/2 an egg! I don't have to order and pay more for the egg like at Monta. I also loveee the fact that the Fukumimi Ramen comes with an extra piece of Chashu pork which is just enough for me! The Chashu pork is super tender with not too much fat either. The soup base is very savory and noodles are cooked to perfection. Service is quick as well. What is there to not like about Fukumimi?!
I just love this place come like once a week service phenomenal and food. Love the whole staff. They all so friendly and nice.

Placed a phone order for pick up. Ordered the karage and the spicy tonkotsu. The karage is by far the best I've had. Very flavorful and crisp even though I took it to go and it had been sitting out for awhile. But my friend said they left out the side of salt seasoning it should've came with but it was still delicious even without it. The tonkotsu was good too but I felt like the serving size was kinda smaller compared to if I had dined in and I felt like the toppings were kinda skimpy alsi. The broth was packed with flavor and the right amount of spiciness to it.

Small spot that's overshadowed by the colorful baskin Robbins next door. Don't let the covered up window confuse your they're open.

This challenge of eating at all the ramen spots in vegas is hard. We decided to order the Fukumimi and Kogashi ramen with curry rice on the side. The Fuku has thin noodles and extra pork in it. WIN! my Kogashi was more garlic infused and had the same toppings as the Fuku. I added chili oil in mine and it was the cherry on top. It was a good amount of ramen to broth.

Our curry rice was a perfect side to balance out the strong flavor of ramen. Our bill came out to $23 and my millennial budget-limited heart soared. I'll take it!

I drank like 4 cups of water and every time I put it down their servers were right there with the water pitcher. Service was on point and quick. We had no wait for a party of 2. They have a small restaurant so be sure to plan out or call in advance if you have a group of 5 or more. 

We totally forgot to grab stamp cards. Which is a fail for me! Don't forget yours!
Big hit. Great price, quick service during off hours. I make this a weekly stop. Gyoza is nice, spicy ramen with ground pork is fun also. Try everything!

My daughter found this place on the web. She spent some time in Japan and tries to share that with me by finding these cute little places that are authentic and close by.
This place has off the chart ratings and with good cause! The staff is friendly and helpful. The food is yummy and she tells me it is much like a place in Japan would be. I won't be visiting Japan any time soon however she tells me this is an authentic place.
we will return soon

This ramen place is good and I like how close it is to UNLV. Definitely a quick fix to your ramen cravings especially since the food comes out pretty quickly. The staff is super friendly and we were seated right away given that it was 100 degree weather and a weekday. Last time I waited was over the winter when my family and I waited almost 20 minutes, but the staff was really accommodating to my handicapped grandma! The only think I don't like is how small the space is but other than that it is definitely a place I would recommend to a friend!

Second time was even better than the first! The pork belly consistency and flavor is now similar to monta and the shio tonkatsu broth is light and not overly salty. The karaage is not my favorite since it was slightly oily and not crisp on the outside.  However you can't really beat the value for the portion they give you and it comes with a small side salad.  I wish they had put the dressing on the side since some of it caused the karaage to get soggy.  Overall solid establishment and 4 ramen purchases gets you a free appetizer...so make sure to get the punch card.

Great flavors but I had serious food aversion for the next 4 days that accompanies diarrhea for the next 3 days. I didn't eat anything else except for this place. I will not be returning again. Right when I walked in, I constantly questioned the cleanliness of this place. Definitely not the neat, well organized ramen shop that I'm accustomed to.

I got the "Fukumimi ramen" which came with extra chashu, seaweed (or as the menu said 'sea we') but the star for me was the broth itself.  It came out hot, rich and salty (insert perverted joke here). I honestly could have had another order since I scarfed down the bowl in seconds flat.  Fortunately, my friend ordered a small chashu bowl as an appetizer which left me satiated.  

They NEED to get the gyoza going.  Just this past week alone I have been to a German restaurant that didn't serve beer and now a ramen restaurant with no gyoza.  They said their gyoza machine is down and will be up soon.  I wasn't sure whether the machine made them or cooked them but I wasn't up for questions when hot ramen is staring right at me.  At least they had beer.  

Testuro P. said "You should try the Tan Tan Men next time, it is the best thing in the world.".  So that's what I am going to do.

The ramen is okay, I like the appetizers more. Veggie ramen was not my cup of tea. Tasted like a cold sesame noodle salad. The fukumimi ramen was aite, I've had better.

agedashi tofu and chicken are pretty good. Bae is in love with the honey garlic chicken, it's better when extra crispy. The agedashi tofu has a tasty dashi sauce when eaten together.

Their green tea is from a can, so that isn't recommended.

Service is eh, the older lady seemed unsure of some of the questions I asked.
I love this place, its like a hidden gem in las vegas! Monta and other popular places got nothing on fukumimi . We come here like twice a month

Decent Ramen but, shakey customer service. Initially when walking in, its small and somewhat dirty, felt like a fast food dinning set up. It was small but packed on a Tues night. Ordered the classic ramen, spicy ramen, and honey garlic chicken. Honey garlic chicken was great except till I tried to eat my third one and realized it was raw and the other ones as well. When I notified staff (plus beforehand I informed her I was going to pay for it regardless), just so no one gets sick; This young lady told me that next time I should ask for it well done. Needless to say decent ramen 5/10 personally, not the cleanest, and shakey customer service.
Working close by is convenient since they are consistently one of the top 2 or 3 spots in town for ramen. Always great service from wait staff and cook staff!
Best ramen in Las Vegas! I liked Monta ramen but I thought the broth was tastier here. The Char Siu rice bowl is a yummy side as well. Just wished it was closer to the strip.

I'm from Hawai'i and during my trip to Vegas I wanted some ramen. At home we love ramen and there are many restaurants that serves ramen. When searching on yelp I came across Fukumimi and read the reviews.  We figured we'd give it a try and we were extremely impressed. 

We ordered take out to take back to our hotel. Included in the order was ramen, gyoza, edamame, and the agedashi tofu. Like I said ramen and Japanese food places are plentiful in Hawai'i and we have a certain standard of what to expect. We got back to our hotel and opened up everything. From the first taste of the broth we knew this place was a winner. As we tried all the side dishes we were even more impressed. 

I really wish I could have eaten here again before we left but unfortunately we found this place towards the end of our trip. It's not a far drive from the strip which is perfect. Can't wait to visit Vegas and eat at Fukumimi again!

Our favorite place for ramen, hands down.  I recommend the Tonkotsu Ramen, it's outstanding!!  Their gyoza is right on with exactly how I remember it being prepared during a 6 month stint in Japan.  A definite must to eat here, though I'd rather you don't, so I can...

Best ramen I've had, hands down. The atmosphere inside is very welcoming. The waitresses were very helpful with the menu. I got the fukimimi ramen because I enjoy a lot of toppings inside my ramen. I added a bunch of extra toppings like butter, sea weed, egg, corn, and chaschu (pork belly). The taste of their broth is very authentic and they take the time to make the bowl itself look beautiful upon arrival. I always put sauce in anything I eat, it's a habit.. This is probably one of the only places where I didn't need to add any extra sauces to it, which is really hard to do. This japanese ramen at its finest! Also had a large chaschu bowl which tasted amazing, their pork belly tasted great and the bowl itself complimented the ramen well. Only drawback is that this place is really small, I would call ahead to see what the wait time is. I don't recommend big parties here, keep it intimate when you decide to give this place a try!

My fiancee stumbled into this place last week and sent me countless mouth watering pics of the Fukumimi Ramen.  I had to try it for myself.  I said to myself, "this place must be good," considering my lady isn't a big ramen eater due to her carb conflicts.  

So we come in on a Sunday after a long night of partying with good friends...once inside, you can immediately smell the fresh handmade ramen being drained from boiling pots...good sign.

The service is fast friendly and accommodating...another good sign. The crowd, diverse and was a good mixture of sophisticated, casual, multi aged and ethnic heads that I would like to think have a respect for some Japanese ramen other than meals out the instant dinner section at your local grocery store.

I checked out the menu and could see myself ordering numerous dishes...so if in doubt, go with the flagship dish, which was the Fukumimi ramen.  Let's throw in some karaage chicken as well...HiYah!

As the bowl came out, it was aesthetically appealing to say the least.  A pair of nori paper sheets lined the far side of the bowl, the ramen was nicely bunched and the broth was drizzled with some additives that made the dish look mouth watering.  

5-7 minutes later...

The bowl was demolished and the verdict is...not bad.  I would say its more on the modern variations of ramen versus the authentic versions Monta offers.  The broth is good and not overwhelming with too much or too little flavoring.  The Chashu is similar to red charsiu roast pork versus the fatty version Monta offers.  I personally like the fatty version, but I can see others settling for the healthier choice. 

I still remember Tenkaippen back in Waikiki, Hawaii, which I worked for a day, and it reminded me began to think of all the ramen places back home, including Goma-Tei that I would say is the closest resemblance that I could compare to Fukumimi.  I would rather Monta, now that I know to add more hot water to their broth since it is a little salty for my taste.  Worth a shot, enjoy.
This place is soo good I always get the spicy chicken miso with corn I haven't been in a while but I highly recommend this ramen place
Love Fukumimi Ramen. I always get one of the Tonkotsu bowls. I only wish they had more than 1 piece of pork like Monta does.  Otherwise, great consistent Ramen, with a nice soft egg.

Ate here for the first time on march 19th 2017 and I think I am going again later today. 

It was a great bowl of ramen and value is great compared to others. Broth is the right amount of salty (spicy ramen is what I had) and the thick  noodles had a good amount of chewiness. They also have thin but I didn't eat that one. Extra noodles is only $1 so feel free to add more. The pork was good but not as soft as sora or monta. The broth is where it's at though. 

Karrage was also good but I only had a piece as the other members of my party devoured it. The gyoza was good but standard.

I consulted the local ramen expert, Tetsuro P., before coming back to Fukumimi a second time.  The first time I didn't know the difference between this place and Ramen Sora or Monta.  I learned that the curly noodles at those two places are actually Sapporo style ramen and Fukumimi is Osaka style (I think that's right).  That explains why Fukumimi's noodles are different, being straight and thinner.  Upon Tetsuro-san's recommendation, I ordered the Tonkotsu-Miso fusion ramen and it was definitely a delicious choice.  Knowledge is power!  Ultimately, I prefer the Sora Sapporo style noodles, but the broth at Fukumimi is better--let's fuse those!  Domo arigato to Tetsuro for schooling me.  
Also, this second trip to Fukumimi was Elizabeth B.'s first UYE.  It was a fabulous evening with: (roll call)  her, Joe L., Mel C., Chad S., Alicia R., Francisco A., Ian A., and Shirley B.  Fun times at Fukumimi!  The end.

THANK YOU, GPS, for screwing up and sending us in circles around this ramen restaurant!!

When we finally found Fukumimi, we were a little skeptical because it didn't look like much from the outside.  It was located in a nondescript seemingly vacant strip mall.  The exterior of the restaurant boasted no more than their restaurant name and a lit "OPEN"  sign, betraying what we were to soon find out their cozy, modern inside.  The decor was spartan chic in a way that only Japanese can be.

As expected, the menu was fairly limited.  Unlike other places, they offer only rice bowls...no fried rice (I do enjoy Japanese-style fried rice).  Up until this point, the aroma of the restaurant did a lot to convince me that the ramen may be legit.  But I still needed more...so I ordered the purist's favorite tonkotsu ramen.  Hubby went with the Fukumimi special which from what I can gather is just a supersized version of their regular tonkotsu ramen.  We also ordered the recommended karaage as well as a small chicken bowl.

Chicken bowl - comforting, pretty decent, well-flavored
Karaage - BEST I've ever had.  Moist, lightly battered and tender...served with a mini salad and some special salt / lemon wedge
Ramen - The broth was excellent.  Rich without being overwhelming and definitely well-seasoned and flavored.  The garlic oil was a great addition and the egg (of which I ordered extra) was perfectly cooked in that the yolk was jelly-like instead of yellow and chalky.

Service was nice, very friendly...though I don't know why but the ramen chefs seemed to be talking about me, somewhat disconcerting until I got distracted by the food.  (I swear, I'm not vain...but they could probably tell we were out-of-towners.  A quick scan of the cars parked outside seem to yield that everyone in the joint is from NV.)

Definitely a must-visit...the wait wasn't as ridiculous as the other highly-touted ramen place.  Hopefully one day they will see fit to add fried rice to their repertoire of dishes.

I am still thinking about Fukumimi over a month after my visit. I was really waffling over which ramen place to visit on my last trip to vegas because there are just so many that look good! I'm glad I decided on Fukumimi.... hidden in a creepy strip mall next to a closed down discount super market, Fukumimi is definitely nondescript. I was nervous walking in, but it's cute on the inside. My friend and I split their gyoza and I had their spicy ramen with corn. The gyoza were some of the best I've had.... not your typical frozen crappy gyoza you find at many Japanese restaurant... but really crispy flavorful dumplings, worth the money. The real star of the restaurant, however, is the ramen. My spicy ramen had a good heat level....a delicious gooey egg... sweet corn.... chewy noodles.... it was one of the best ramen bowls I have ever had. I ate almost the entire bowl (I seriously almost made myself sick...but so good!). The prices are reasonable and the food is top notch. Try it, you won't be sorry!
The place smells so good and it's got the best dumplings I've ever had , and the ramen soups are so good .

Over a year later, I finally came back to give this place another try! My friend had a full stamp card so we got the free chicken karaage, which was pretty much the same as last time, but crispier. I definitely liked how tender the chicken was and the contrast between that and the crispy exterior. However, the batter is already very salty and they still provide dipping salt! I dipped it anyways because i can't control myself around salt ugh.

This time around, I got the tonkotsu salt, which was actually to my liking! At only 7.90 I got a huge slice of tender  chashu, half an egg, some beansprout, and a little bit of green onion. The noodles were tender but not too soft and the broth is not bland (like I mentioned in my last review) but not too salty either! It was light and the slightly smaller-than-normal portion is perfect to make me satisfied.

Service is still the same. The tables and chairs could definitely use some sprucing up. They're all scratched up! In any case, I'll definitely come back here when I'm craving ramen and I'm in the area. Crossing the strip is just too much of a hassle for me otherwise, sorry Fukumimi. But hey, I like you guys now so you got that going for ya!
Kogashi ramen is the best! Best karaage in town! Awesome food and excellent service. Long line during dinner so better to go early.

Leave the strip to eat here. Best food we had in vegas. You will over eat trying everything and still manage to under pay.
I don't know who Mimi is, but if they did something bad to these genius chefs, then I got to double down. Fuku Mimi.

Wanted to like this place but it was okay. Service was friendly and attentive. Sat at the bar area as tables were filled up.

Had the spicy ramen with butter. Ramen noodles were perfect texture, broth was okay, nothing special. Also had the chicken karaage and it was ok. The mini curry bowl was ok as well. Nothing was bad but nothing was spectacular either.

Jinya, Sora and Monta are still my top 3 ramen places in Vegas.

Food: tonkotsu shoyu ramen with thick noodles. Thick noodles is a must as the regular noodles don't seem like ramen noodles. They are too thin, more like a somen noodle. Gyoza was authentic. 

Service: fast and efficient. 

Location: in a strip mall.

Super good ramen!! Once we walked inside we were greeted right away and it was packed! We didn't wait long for seats, but didn't mind waiting because it smelled so good :) try the Japanese fried chicken it was sooo good!

.
Went yesterday 1-24-16 around 8PM for dinner.  This restaurant is located on Eastern and Tropicana next to Baskin Robbins.  It's kind of a small space....there's room for maybe 20 people.  It was quite crowded. 
. 
For just over $25.00 we got some ramen, two appetizers, two drinks, a salad, a chicken curry, and some tasty corn and rice for my boy.  I was wondering why it was so cheap but then I saw a sign on the wall that said "Free appetizer with purchase of ramen".  
.
I got the tonkotsu ramen (soy) and it was a very generous portion.  The broth was flavorful and just the right temperature.  It had a nice big slice of pork, a perfectly soft boiled egg, a sheet of nori, and bean sprouts.  The noodles were cooked perfectly.  Next time I think I'll try it spicy! I wanted to add some spice but there are no condiments on the table and I wasn't quite sure what to ask for to make it spicy.  *White girl problems*.  Sriracha?? I dunno. 
. 
Chicken Karaage- Delicious dark meat chicken lightly floured and fried to perfection.  Juicy, flavorful, crunchy, delicious! 
. 
Husband had the chicken curry and was practically licking the bowl after he inhaled it.  I got one bite of it and it was heavenly.  The chicken is mixed into the curry which I've never had before but it was really good.  Their rice is just about the best I've ever had...perfectly cooked, sticky, and aromatic. 
. 
This is really close to my house and I have a feeling they'll be seeing a lot more of me.  My only complaint would be that there is absolutely *no* place to wait inside the restaurant.  The foyer is microscopic.   Also while we were there a young man turned in an application/resume and all the staff members gathered around and laughed at it before they trashed it.  Kinda unprofessional but none of my business.

Best ramen East of the strip.

When youre on the West side, there are greats such as Monta, Sora, and Jinya. I've tried them all so I tried Fukumimi to explore east Vegas ramen. 

It was wednesday night and the place is full. Sign-in sheet available and only two chairs inside for waiting. Theres a counter section that seats about 6-8, and moveable tables for maybe another 20-30. The place is the size of any Monta so I wouldnt recommend huge groups here. 

I ordered the Tonkotsu Salt ($7.50) and when it came out, the presentation was great. Nice bowl, nice looking broth, and smelled yummy. But looking down into the bowl, I felt it was a little plain. But nonetheless, I dig in and it hit the spot. 

Again like my reviews for other ramen, I love the thin, straight noodles. However, the noodles in my bowl were clunky and all stuck together. This ruined it for me. It made me assume that they get their noodles from a refridgerated package and they attempt to boil it to loosen it up. 

I hope that it was just this one bowl. My next bowl here will still have the good flavor.

Been here about 5 times and the two times I'm here I ordered my Karaage Chicken SUPER GREASY and I mention it to the server then she said no it is the salad dressing and the chicken suppose to be GREASY NOT CRUNCHY! I was politely ask to fix my Karaage issues but she come back with the same chicken saying I will just take it off the check instead of fixing it correctly!!! The owner is not here by the way!!! VERY DISAPPOINTING, NOT SURE IF IM GOING TO RETURN TO THIS PLACE AGAIN!!!

I've been here thrice already and to sum it up:

1st visit: mediocre. my order of tonkotsu ramen was suspicious with its weird broth buildup on the top. tonkotsu ramen (salt) $7.50.

2nd visit: hated the tan tan men. $8.95

3rd visit: had tonkotsu ramen (soy) $7.50 and this visit was probably the best of the 3. I actually really liked the noodles this time and the broth was normal compared to my first visit.

Overall, it's very far from my home but I definitely wouldn't be dropping by unless we were in the area and really wanted ramen.

Still worth a try for anyone thinking about it, though. Service is good and the establishment is small & cozy so it's kind of hard for them to ignore you. 

They also have stamp cards and you don't have to get a bazillion stamps before you can get something free -- in this case, karaage (6 pcs).

Fantasic! One word!  AWESOME authentic, and delicious. I have been twice now. almost guaranteed that  you will be waiting just a few minutes before being seated. But well worth it. the spicy Tonkotsu ramen and the tan tan men are fabulous.
Great Job Fukimimi!
This place is really good especially for the price. Not the best ramen I've had but the place, food and service are always consistent.
The best Ramen! My favorite is the Fukumimi Ramen, but Tantan Men is really good too! Plus their staff are great! Too bad it's a bit far from where we live. But the drive is always worth it!

i think i've had way better in the past ... 
Every single white person eating there was speaking japanese :) which i thought was crazy but in a good way .... 
the servers and cooks seem genuinely happy and good peeps .. positive vibe from them

Besides the random homeless lady walking in and disturbing not just me but every customer eating in there... The workers kinda just let her bother all the customers because they didn't really stop her. 

This place is legit. Guess location is the problem? Figure I try other ramen spots before my go to. 

Been here once. I hope to not get bother by a homeless if I eve eat here again.

Pleasantly surprised at how much I liked this ramen.   

The broth was thick and rich with a lot of deep flavors.   The pork inside was a little fatty but had great flavor.   I got a double portion of egg and I'm glad I did because it was just the right amount of salty deliciousness. 

The others in my party seemed to really enjoy their meal as well.   2 of them (my bf included)  hate ramen and were able to get other items on the menu to satisfy them. 

My only gripe with this place is that there are no condiments on the table.   I like to add spice and ginger depending on my mood and I'd appreciate being able to do this. 

Definitely will be back to try some of their other items.

The beauty of Yelp. You see a friends check in, and then you decide that's what you want to eat for dinner, and then find a new place near you. That's how my discovery of Fukumimi Ramen came about. 

I walked in the door at 6:30pm and the place was packed. Maybe 12 people huddled inside waiting for tables. You walk to the counter and put your name on a list, circling yes or no for counter or table. Being a single, I opted for counter and still that took about 20 minutes to get a seat. I almost walked away to my second choice when I first opened the door, glad I decided to wait. 

I had the standard Tokonsu Miso Ramen. Includes a slice of pork belly (recommend adding another), egg, corn. I found the broth to be very good, not salty like Ramen Sora. A nice balance of flavor between the corn and a few light chili flakes didn't make it overly sweet or overly spicy. For me it was perfect, I could taste the chili but it didn't make me walk away as I've been known to do with spicy foods. 

I liked it better than Ramen Sora, and better than Monta (who I really like). The building is small, maybe table room for 16 and counter space for 6. 

Located next to the Baskin Robbins store on Eastern and Tropicana. I'll definitely be back and happy to find Ramen on the east side and not have to drive to Chinatown.

i have been here 3 or 4 times. Always terrific. The prices are great. 2 people can eat there with 2 bowls 2 starters, and a couple of sodas for 28 $.  The garlic chicken is stupid good. I always go for the spicy tonkotsu. Really a true gem in a not so known area.

This place is delicious!! I always end up getting the spicy miso ramen and it's definitely amazing! I love how the flavors blend and its a fast ramen joint! I go in and place my order and within 10 minutes it's ready! The gyoza is delicious as well. Glad for a ramen joint off the strip and not too far from where I live.

If you are a ramen fan this a must. First the ramen is $7.50 and that includes an egg. What a deal and on top of that it's good ramen. Lots of extras you can order if it's not on the menu just ask they will accommodate. It small homely looking place but well worth it. When I go to eat I like to pay for food first then decore.

We got take-out ramen when we were in Vegas for the night - 2 Ramens and some honey garlic chicken. The ramen was good, hearty and spicy, but I'm not sure take-out is the best way to experience ramen. That's on me though, I feel the same way about pho, and I'm not gonna dock them for that. 

If you're gonna go take-out, grab the honey garlic chicken - I wish we'd ordered 2x as much. A classic sweet/spicy Asian dish that hits the same notes as some crispy beef dishes I've had in Chinese restaurants, almost a teriyaki kinda thing, but it's own thing too.

Excellent ramen in Las Vegas, just off the strip.  Nice to find "non-standard" Vegas fare to change things up from the buffets and burger joints.  Didn't try my standard shoyu ramen, but the tried the Tan-tan ramen, and that was quite tasty as was the karaage chicken.  Definitely recommend, and will return next time I'm in Vegas.

Friendly staff and good food! 
Since our go to Ramen place has been closed, we decided to give this place a try and it did not disappoint. There was 2 tables available but there was a party of 17 that wanted to eat, which pretty much would have taken half the restaurant. This place is small and would not recommend taking a party here! They said it would be 10 mins but I think not even 5 mins of waiting the lady said go ahead anyways and I thought that was nice because I was starving. We ordered agedashe Tofu and it was really good, it's two big pieces and very flavorful. 
Our ramen came out just in time and it was a good portion. I forgot the exact name of our dishes but my husband got something with black oil and he swears it's better than Monta's. My Spicy Miso with Thick noodles was okay not crazy about it but definitely would love to try other dishes.

We were pretty tired of eating at buffets day after day, so we needed some good ol' comfort food, Japanese style and Fukumimi did not disappoint!   

They are located in a sorta shabby strip mall next to a small Japanese market/video shop and as soon as we walked in, it felt like we were back in Japan.   All the staff were Japanese and all the customers were too.  Enough of that lets talk about the food.

We got the spicy tonkotsu, shoyu ramen, gyoza, chashu bowl, and chicken karaage.  ALL WERE EXCELLENT.  I docked one star off because our waitress was in her own world...her service was non-existent.  It seemed as though she didn't want to be there.  

Perhaps it was her heavy ass eye-shadow and make-up that was bringing her down...lolz

Anyways, in the end we'd come back here again.

So delicious and affordable. Best ramen place in Las Vegas! The staff is really friendly and helpful. It's a really small place, granted most ramen places are, so just make sure your entire party is there or they won't seat you until they are. I loved it here!
One of my favorite ramen spots. I will say the only ramen worth getting is the tonkotsu shio ramen or the fukumimi ramen. The curry is also really good here

I thought this place was going to be awesome due to the reviews I was reading before heading over. However, it wasn't all that I thought it was going to be. 
My mom, who I was with, ordered ramen and she said it was good. No elaboration. I ordered the curry rice along with an order of the chicken karaage. Both were okay. We were both a little disappointed in the portion sizes. They were a little small for the price. 
We decided not to eat there because it was a little busy and we didn't want to be squished up to another party because the restaurant is small. What we did like was that everything was packed separately. The noodles were separate from the broth. When we got home, we ate right away but the food wasn't hot. It was less than a 10 minute drive from the restaurant back to my house, so that was surprising. It also took almost half an hour for us to get our order. 
The food was okay. The curry didn't have anything noticeably special about it. There were no vegetables and the chicken mentioned in the description was also missing. I was glad I got the karaage to go with it. But I was a little disappointed in the karaage. It was a little on the dry side. 
Overall, I don't know if I'd be going back again if I was the one making the decision. The prices were okay, but not really for the quality of the food. Maybe we went on a bad night, but I was hoping it was going to be better.

I have been craving for some authentic ramen for awhile now since my favorite ramen house closed,,so after yelping I decided to try this joint,,and OMG! what can I say it hit the spot and so much more!! their broth is perfect and not too creamy/fatty as monta.. It was just the perfect amount of serving and everything is just so good..I think the best part is that its location is so close to my house and now I dont have to go to Chinatown just for ramen..Im so excited for the weather to get cooler so I can have an excuse to eat it everyday!

The place is good but unfortunately we have to look for another ramen house. They're always closed whenever we go up there which is contradictory to what Yelp says. It's a gamble to know if they'll be open.

This place is creeping up in ratings:)  I tried the Fukumimi Miso style.  I don't think I've had as  generous a bowl of ramen anywhere else.  You get three large pieces of charsiu that is fatty and the most delicious I've had yet.  You also get seaweed and a seasoned egg.  I've not made it out to monta house yet, b/c this place is just that good.

If you need a quick meal in under an hour, come here!  Super speedy service.  The ramen is delicious (try the one with the red ginger) and so are their other bowls.   Reminds me of some ramen places I use to eat at on the lower east side in NYC.
I orderd Tonkutsu Ramen (Spicy) with thin noodles...the broth so good and yummy belly pork. Also, Karaage chicken was so delicious but Gyoza just so so.

On a ramen tasting mission and found this place. Small is an understatement but what we were seeing and smelling and seeing past our eyes during the wait was amazing. The appetizers were off the hook: kimchi, and honey garlic chicken WOW! Garlicky Ramen I had

There's quite a few ramen places around this Las Vegas Valley. On a cold Vegas evening, getting over a cough/cold, ramen sure hit the spot. The service was fast and provided great suggestions for what we should order. 

We ordered the TanTanMen  without any meat selections because we assumed there would be some, but only realized after our bowls had come out. The soup base was delicious! We also ordered the chicken karaage and with a squeeze of lemon and the salt/pepper/spices dip it was too tasty that we finished it prior to finishing our bowls.

GREAT ramen place!! I'm getting addicted to Tan tan men. It's so delicious. I am happy to live in a city with so many great ramen restaurants. 

is it better than Monta?? I don't know or care. Both are top notch. They are located in different parts of the city. Fukumimi cannot be missed in east LV.
I ordered the spicy tonkotsu ramen and an order of karaage. Both tasted amazing! The servers were nice as well and the wait for the food did not take long at all (10 min at most).

The spicy tonkonsu ramen is the best! 

I had tried pho and wasn't a fan so I was hesitant to try ramen but I couldn't have been happier. It's tasty and it's just the right portion and spice. The environment is pleasing. 

Overall fukumimi is great!

I googled ramen soup and this place popped up as #1. It did not dissatisfied. Because I am sensitive to pork I ordered the chicken bowl, salad and dumplings. I also ordered a beer. The bill came to about $16. Small, quaint place. Very friendly service.

Fukumimi ramen's okay. I'm so used to monta I don't think I'll be able to adjust to another ramen place. What's good though is it's located (hidden) by UNLV next to Baskin Robbins. It's actually pretty good if you don't wanna drive all the way to Spring Mountain or Eastern to eat somewhere else. Their service was friendly and seating was plentiful. They have all different types of broth like miso, spicy miso, soy, etc. The bowls are about $8-$9 and it comes with pork, egg, and mushrooms. You have to add everything else for a tiny cost. We ate on a rainy day so the atmosphere made it perfect for ramen. I enjoyed my time. Just not something that's amazing. But just a-ok!

Real Japanese food made by real Japanese people! So yes they are added to my safe to eat Japanese food list in Vegas BUT with all of the new ramen-yas that have popped up over the past year I would be hard pressed to come back here after our first and only experience here... 

I know this is a harsh statement but I have good reasoning! So hear me out my faithful followers. Trust me I wanted to love this place...

Me and the gf came here late one night. We were the only patrons I the joint. 
I ordered karaage and Kim chee for starters, a bowl or shoyu ramen and the gf  got miso ramen. 

The karaage was on point! I put my seal of approval on it as being legit Japanese. 
The same can be said for the Kim chee. For those who eat Kim chee on the regular can tell the difference between the Korean and Japanese subtle of Kim chee so kudos for that!

All was fine until the ramen. 
First off it took 15+ minutes for us to get it after we finished the karaage (keep in mind we are the only people in the place) 
Girlfriends bowl comes out first and is a proper bowl of miso ramen. She is nice enough give me a taste while i wait. Noodles maintained a little firmness, the broth a little sweet but still rich and flavorful. All that was missing was a little pat of butter (eh don't knock it until you try it!) So I figure the same nomness can be expected in my bowl... Nope! I got soggy skinny tan tan mein noodles in my shoyu ramen. The error many have gone unnoticed by the unassuming gaigin (white person) whose only comparison is top ramen. But to a Japanese person this was a blatantly obvious  screw job.  It was like they gave me noodles from another order or screwed up my order and said he'll never know.. So sad to say I had a sad bowl of ramen. I think that they knew they screwed up because we were not checked on by the waitress till we were both almost done with our bowls. By that point the noodles would be soggy anyways. No point in crying over soggy noodles right? (Ancient Chinese Proverb) I quickly paid the check and bounced... 

Maybe it was a fluke but it should not have been done and for that I have to say I will not be back...

I had the Fukumimi Ramen with thin noodles and an order of the Karaage. The ramen was delicious! Better than ramen that I had in NY! The broth was tasty and not overbearing. Tried the original Karage and it was cooked perfectly, and just the right crunch. Will def come back to try the Garlic Honey Karaage.

If you plan to frequent this little ramen restaurant on a regular basis, be sure to ask for their stamp card.  You get a complimentary order of gyoza or chicken karaage after ordering four ramen.

Also come early to beat the dinner rush, unless you are not in a rush.  The food here is pretty good. I ordered the Fukumimi Ramen, with all of its extras on my first visit, and the soup was flavorful and very delicious. I did not care for the thin ramen noodle that was served, but that is a personal preference.

The Chicken Karaage was good, but we might have been too polite and let it sit on the plate too long, because it was a little greasy by the time I ate my first piece.

Service is friendly, efficient, even when the restaurant is at full capacity.

A great ramen spot on the east side of town.

Ambiance: 4/5  Cozy little spot that is well lit and clean, with view of portion of the kitchen.  It has no fancy decor, but ramen is fast food and who has time to get distracted by anything except that steamy hot bowl of noodles and brothy goodness once it is placed on your table.

Service:  4/5  No compliant.

Food:  4/5  Wonderful flavor, portion is not huge, but enough to satiate most appetites. 

Price:  4/5  Competitive.

Parking:  4.5/5  Plenty when I went in the evening, even when the restaurant is packed.

Solid 4 stars!

I've been deciding how many stars I should give this place. Been here many times with friends and every time we were satisfied with the food. It is a very tiny place so it is suggested to come right when it opened or at a none-regular dining hour. 

I like tonkotsu ramen a lot and this place does not disappoint. Their broth is always hot with egg cook to perfection. I also love their karaage chicken which is lightly crispy on the outside and very juicy on the inside. It also comes with some greens to help you ease the greasiness and cleanse the palate. 

Our most recent visit was last Saturday at around 2pm. We waited for about 10 minute or so for a table because we usually don't like to take the bar seat. Ramen was nice and hot like how it usually is but this time the karaage has a pink color to it. Karaage was very hot however the inside was slightly pink and we didn't think much about it and finished the entire thing. Later on that night my sister and I both had diarrhea. Mine stopped after one night but hers lasted about 1 day. 

I still like the ramen and karaage at this place but I'm not sure if it's worth it for the chance of getting diarrhea again.

The ramen was good and I love the crunchy chicken with mayo and with honey. The only big let down for this place was their chashu bowl, my husband always orders the chashu bowl every time we go to a Ramen place, sadly he did not like the chashu bowl here. The place is small, so not really advisable for large groups. It is really far from me but overall I would come back here, just won't order the chashu bowl.

Just found this gem on Yelp! And it didn't disappoint me! A little ramen place with authentic taste and savory broth. I was surprised how they made the broth for the ramen. It's one of the best broth I ever tasted! It has all the right ingredients and flavor. The proper way to make an authentic ramen!

I highly recommend the place if you are craving for an authentic Japanese ramen! I will definitely a regular!

Love the food here!! The decore leaves much to be desired but the food is so tasty!! Service is quick and you get a full meal for under $10. They tend to be busy during lunch but I have only waited 15 minutes at the longest for a table. I highly recommend trying Fukumimi!!

Deliciously ramen experience !!! Love it here ate twice in two days cause its that good . Awesome inside design chill vibes and great hang out as well too!! Try their Fukumimi Ramen first best to start with!!

I am a huge Ramen person, and this place hit the spot. Great portions and it was very tasty. I'm not from Vegas, so trying different ramen places around, this was really good. It was on the opposite side of town where I was staying but it was worth the drive. Very flavorful.
I admittedly just ate a bowl of rice and two eggs here but by golly was it the best bowl of rice and eggs I've ever had!

It's ramen weather, it's ramen weather!

The weather is getting cooler and as I ready my scarves and sweaters, I also look forward to trying new noodle soup places. My OG Ryan B and I decided to embark on a foodie adventure this evening by trying Fukumimi Ramen. It was my OG's first foray into the world of ramen, so we were both excited about this new spot. 

We opted to start with the karaage appetizer and I ordered the spicy ramen with added corn. My OG chose the Tori Ramen. Our food came out quite quickly. The chicken was hot and fresh. Definitely a pleasant surprise. I definitely recommend this as a starter. It had great flavor and was very juicy. The ramen was awesome too. Nice flavor and well-developed broth. The corn added a nice crunch and I always enjoy sprouts. The more of those the better. 

I still prefer Ramen Sora, but I have to say that I did enjoy it a bit more than Monta. I'm so glad to get this checked off my bookmark list and happy that I got to enjoy it with good company. Service was standard and efficient.

The very first time I had a bad smelling ramen, the steaming broth smells like a dead pig. I still ate because I was hungry but as soon as I got a little bit of it, it wanted to come back out. It did not taste bad, just smells bad. Ewe, still grossing me out until now, will not come back.

The "Cold Hot Ramen" is spicy! I guess that's what it is by definition. I ordered it unaware of the spicy part and couldn't finish it because of this, but it was delicious regardless. I like all the dressings put into it, such as shredded seaweed, ginger?, Half egg, etc. Also got the Karaage Chicken which was always a favorite of mine back in Cali. When I went to the tea places that offered this snack...its priced well here for an appetizer, but isn't the exact appetizer I was used to. It doesn't have the white pepper topping and no long wood sticks to eat it with! But does come with lemon slice to add. Bigger than just popcorn chicken, and the order I got was sorta chewy, thus not sure what part of the chicken they used to deep fry! I'd still get it again. I am on my second take out trip here, and trying the Tomato Cold Noodle, in hopes that it is just as delicious as the spicy version. I'll review it later.
Worst service!!!! They had me wait 30 mins after I ordered and still was told another 10 mins before they could make my ramen. Very slow service here.

My friends and I were in Vegas to celebrate birthdays and decided to come here after a night out. 

We arrived past 1 pm and it was pretty busy. People were waiting outside. It's also a very small place. There is the bar and maybe like 10 tables or even less. We would check up inside pretty often, but the hostess was no help at all. It kinda seemed like she didn't know how to seat. I only say that because, we had told her our party would be okay to split. So we sat at two different tables. Then we got moved to sit altogether, and then she asked us to move tables again. Which was kind of annoying because as a hostess, you should have a sense of where to seat people and what would work best. 

The wait for the food was not too bad. & It was pretty good, but I don't think it's anything special. I've had better ramen at other restaurant, with a bigger quantity and the same prices. My friends who even go the spicy ones didn't think it was even that spicy. They just kept adding more chili oil, powder, and paste. 

Overall, this was place was not too bad. But nothing special about it.

Very small location. On a busy night be prepared to wait a little. The ramen is worth the wait. The menu is straight forward. Staff was attentive. Their checkout system is kinda unique. The waitress handed us an iPad as we split the bill. She swiped our cards & had us sign right at our table, kinda nice.

This place is good. The chicken Karaage was delicious and reasonably priced at $3.90 and came with a little salad. My boyfriend and I both ordered the Tantan Men, wish it came with an egg, but you can add it for a buck I think . My sister had the chicken ramen, the only ramen she could eat because that doesn't have pork. Food was out fast. Nice small place. Next door is a Basken Robbins so you can have ice cream after like we did!

Totally bumming that this fabulous ramen place in my part of town is so popular now!  I love this place and eat ramen here often. I usually get the tonkotsu spicy ramen and it is perfect every time.   The small side salad has amazing dressing and is fresh and healthy too.  Be prepared to wait, as it is a small, authentic place.   The service is very quick and efficient once you get seated.  I highly recommend even though I know this place will keep getting more crowded!!

Fukumimi Ramen is one of my favorite restaurants in the valley. The space is quite small but it makes you feel warm and nice. It feels like those ramen places in Japan in the movies, because it has a ramen bar and wooden theme inspired restaurant. You can see the chefs whipping up some ramen on the other side of the bar.

The price is very affordable for all types of people. The spicy miso ramen is my favorite. The restaurant is gets a little busy near lunch time because of the limited spacing, but it is a good place to go when you have time!

Thanks to Yelp!, we found this little gem close to our hotel but far enough away from the strip madness. It's super tiny and at lunch time we had a 30 minute wait, but for me it was well worth it. The honey garlic karaage appetizer was so good! The noodles in the ramen were so fresh and chewy, I'd recommend getting the thick noodles!

Why have I never known ramen could be so good?!  All this time I've avoided ramen joints due to repressed memories of broke college days.  How ignorant I feel.   I work in the area and all this time I could've been enjoying this tasty "Tonkotsu Ramen" regularly.  I thank you fellow Yelpers for your accurate ratings and pinpoint suggestions!  Went with the Tantan Men this round and can't wait to venture through the rest of the menu!
Can't say I can yet compare this one to other ramen spots but 4 stars all the way for now!
